author: {'steamid': '76561197998089428', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1707522670}
review: Costume Quest 2 builds upon the magic of its predecessor with even more whimsy and charm. Developed by Double Fine Productions, this sequel retains the delightful Halloween spirit while introducing new costumes and imaginative settings. The turn-based combat system remains accessible yet strategic, keeping the gameplay engaging for all ages. The humor is sharp, the characters are endearing, and the art style maintains its vibrant and playful allure. With a perfect blend of nostalgia and innovation, Costume Quest 2 is a sequel that not only lives up to its predecessor but surpasses it, offering a delightful and heartwarming adventure for fans of all things spookily fun.

review:
Not as good as the previous one, plot is solid but it has 5% the charm first game had. Not enough goofiness, plenty of turns to hate the new combat mechanics... they somehow managed to make it worse, enemies are just bullet sponges, changing battle stamps to creepy treats was a huge missteps, game would be 50% faster if the fights werent so damn long and boring.

Still a good game, but after GOI DLC, this feel like a cheap sequel game.

review:
RPG decente con tem√°tica Halloween lo suficientemente entretenido como para darle una oportunidad y que adem√°s no quitar√° mucho tiempo de tu Backlog: alrededor de 6-7 horas son suficientes para completar el juego haciendo todas sus misiones secundarias y disfrutando de la mayor parte del contenido que tiene para ofrecer.

[h2]Lo bueno[/h2]
[list][*] Combates por turnos con sincronizaci√≥n de ataques y defensa a la Mario RPGs
[*] El combate, aunque poco, va evolucionando un poco si sigues las misiones de cierto personaje
[*] Unos cuantos coleccionables/secretos escondidos por todo el mapa para los que gustan de explorar
[*] Cierta variedad de personajes con los distintos disfraces, que cambian las habilidades, afinidades y c√≥mo interactuas con el entorno fuera de los combates
[*] Con objetos equipables que refrescan un poco la experiencia de los combates
[*] Perfecto para Halloween, si no te van mucho los juegos de miedo
[*] Completamente en Espa√±ol
[/list]

[h2]Lo malo[/h2]
[list][*] La traducci√≥n al Espa√±ol tiene unos cuantos errores sueltos
[*] Las afinidades de los monstruos le dan un toque, pero no tienes forma de adelantarte a los enfrentamientos y conocer qu√© disfraces te van mejor para cu√°les
[/list]

Si buscas una experiencia con un RPG decente, que no se arriesga mucho y no quieres tener que invertir mucho tiempo con √©l, Costume Quest 2 es una muy buena opci√≥n que mejora algo la experiencia que ya present√≥ Costume Quest a√±os antes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085030183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1698586596}
review:
Costume quest 2 √® il seguito diretto del primo capitolo (inizia dove finisce il primo), come il suo predecessore √® un mini GDR, i nostri personaggi dovranno raccogliere ed indossare diversi costumi di Halloween (diversi opzionali e ben celati nelle varie location), i quali ci daranno accesso a particolari poteri. A differenza del primo, dove si potevano raccogliere dei francobolli che attivavano particolari abilit√†, qui ci sono delle carte (usabili in battaglia) che conferiscono abilit√† e bonus. In pratica a livello di gameplay il gioco √® pi√π rifinito (e meno facile anche se non ho mai visto un game over) ma meno divertente del primo (che era una novit√†), il classico more of the same senza infamia e senza lode.

PREGI:

Costumi simpatici che attivano abilit√† uniche
Missioni secondarie che spesso richiedono l'uso di uno specifico costume
Diversi costumi sono opzionali e vanno scovati all'interno degli stage.


DIFETTI:

I combattimenti sono sempre facili, hanno solo aumentato i danni fatti dai nemici (√® praticamente impossibile morire)
Alcuni livelli sono noiosi 
Per via della storia, l'atmosfera di Halloween √® meno presente
I combattimenti richiedono solo la pressione di un tasto al momento giusto (per fare pi√π danni e per pararsi), ci si stufa presto di questa mancanza di profondit√†.

VOTO: 7

Costume Quest 2 √® il seguito diretto del primo capitolo, migliora alcuni aspetti ma nel contempo ne peggiora altri (l'atmosfera del primo era decisamente migliore e poi il gameplay era una novit√†).
Consigliato solo a che ha giocato il primo capitolo (che reputo migliore).




PC in uso:

Processore Intel Core i7 6700K 4.00GHz
Memoria ram 16 Gb 2133 Mhz
scheda madre MSI Z170A GAMING M3
scheda video RTX 3060 Asus Duo OC
sistema operativo Windows 10 64 bit

review:
[b] [i] > Be me, looking for a Halloween game.
    > Find Costume Quest 2.
    > "Let's give it a go!"
    > Start the game.
    > The game opens with a dentist as the villain.
    > My worst nightmare realized in pixels.
    > Kids in costumes again, but this time on a time-traveling quest.
    > Who needs Doctor Who when you've got candy and costumes?
    > My party includes a cardboard box. Seriously.
    > Cardboard Box is OP, defeats monsters with its "box of doom."
    > Still can't get dental hygiene out of my head.
    > Candy corn is currency, best economic system ever.
    > Trick-or-treating through time and space.
    > Gather more candy to save the world.
    > Humor and puns galore, costumes with superpowers.
    > Do epic battles as a unicorn, french fry, and pterodactyl.
    > Realize I'm an adult laughing at kid's jokes.
    > No shame; this game is pure nostalgia.
    > Dentist villain still scares me more than any monster.
    > Dental bills in my nightmares, but I'm having a blast.
    > Costume Quest 2: Because what's Halloween without a cardboard box superhero?
    > 10/10, would recommend for a sweet, punny, and slightly terrifying time! üç¨üéÉü¶∑üëª [/i] [/b]  

[i] (Interior: A Hollywood studio office. The executive, played by Ryan George, sits behind a desk. In walks the enthusiastic creator, also played by Ryan George.)

Executive: Alright, so what have you got for me today?

Creator: Okay, picture this: it's Costume Quest 2!

Executive: Ah, the sequel. People love sequels. What's the scoop this time?

Creator: Well, we've got the same kids in costumes, right? But get this, they're time-traveling this time!

Executive: Time travel, nice. So, where do they go?

Creator: Everywhere! Ancient Egypt, the pirate age, and even the future!

Executive: Ah, expanding the universe, I like it. Any new characters?

Creator: Absolutely. How about a villain who's a... wait for it... dentist?

Executive: A dentist?

Creator: Yeah, they're terrified of the guy. He's got a whole army of toothbrush-wielding minions.

Executive: Toothbrushes as weapons, that's a twist. What about the costumes?

Creator: Oh, they're wild. You can be a unicorn, a french fry, even a pterodactyl.

Executive: I can already see the merchandise. But can you top the first game's cardboard box hero?

Creator: You bet. We're bringing back the cardboard box and giving it even more ridiculous powers.

Executive: Love it. What's the message here?

Creator: Well, it's all about the power of friendship and teamwork, you know, the usual. But with a lot of candy.

Executive: Candy always sells. And the humor?

Creator: Puns, dad jokes, and some adult humor slipped in for the parents.

Executive: Perfect. This sounds like a deliciously spooky adventure. You've got the green light!

Creator: Awesome! I'll get back to work on those dental villain puns. Thanks!

Executive: No problem. And remember, it's all about the teeth-chattering fun! [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198868374621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1700528933}
review:
The game has been a family favorite for a long time.  It is a tradition for my wife to play this game, every year.  Though we have both titles (Costume Quest 1 and 2), my wife prefers this game, over the second.

The game is easy to pick up and play, full of humor, colorful characters, and fun moments.  There are many secrets to unlock and strategies to execute.  What we love most about the game is fun it is to play, time and again, no matter how many times we have loaded it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111591705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1698142299}
review:
I beat Costume Quest 1 100% about 5-6 months ago, and given the feedback that this game was basically the same, but with some minor changes, I thought a little break would be a good idea. It definitely was the right choice, as the feedback from other reviewers was correct. The game is 90% the same. The major differences include needing to refill your health between battles, a few extra combo/counter moves in combat, and the replacement of stamp abilities with card abilities with cooldowns. 

The refilling of health would be a good touch, if there weren't constant health fountains in every single area making the fear of death pointless. The additional combo mechanics were a welcome addition. Card abilities seemed to get some negative feedback, but honestly, I didn't mind the system all that much. The new costumes don't quite have the same charm as the first game, but they are still pretty good. It's a shame the costumes from the first game couldn't also carry over to this one for one big costume frenzy.

The game is incredibly easy, I didn't lose a single battle in my initial run. I was about half-way through the run though when I realised I had accidentally blocked myself off from an achievement. If you want to get 100% in a single run, there is only one thing that you can accidentally be blocked from doing. One achievement demands you complete every single battle with the candy corn costume in your party. So I completed my initial run, and then had to redo the entire game with the candy corn in my party. While definitely more challenging, as you're basically handicapped the entire game, I still only lost 4 battles, and I ended up beating the game a second time around in about 3.5 hours, and at about level 7 in combat strength. So if you bother to farm enemies more, the game would be easy to run deathless, even with the handicap.

Play Costume Quest 1 before buying this game as the stories are linked, but honestly the story in this game isn't special enough to say it's a must play as the first game has enough closure already. I'd say I enjoyed the first game more than this one, but this was still a fun little distraction from better steam games. 

Score: 6/10 (Decent) (6.5 was my score for Costume Quest 1)
Blind Any% Runtime: ~4-5 Hours
100% Runtime ~8 Hours
Recommended Value of game: ~ $5

author: {'steamid': '76561197970753301', 'num_games_owned': 857, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1696998832}
review: Well it took me three Halloween seasons to finally finish this game, which I think pretty well illustrates both how charmingly delightful it is AND how annoying it is that nobody bothered making sure the game was playable on PC.  Not playable in the sense that it runs poorly, but playable in the sense that the control scheme is so bad and so minimally configurable that you are guaranteed to make choices you do not mean to every time you try to do anything.  And let me tell you how amazing it is to have a game made in the 2010s that does not really have mouse support--yes, congratulations, you can scroll like one or two lists and click on the main menu, but not control your movement or fighting or selecting or anything in-game.  Just an astoundingly bad ... port?  Is this even a port? in that sense, wrapped around a relentlessly fun and delightful Halloween adventure otherwise.  Kind of feels like playing some alternate universe G-rated South Park game a lot of the time, which is a good thing tonally.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070884883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1697090659}
review:
I absolutely love this game, I have nostalgia to Costume Quest 1 as I played it as a kid but never played Costume Quest 2 despite it coming out 4 years after the original, Costume Quest 2 is a lot sharper graphically and plays a lot smoother than Costume Quest 1 (Or at least the PC ports anyway) Lets not forget these were originally Xbox 360 Arcade games which were ported to PC, Anyone who loved RPG's, Halloween and Kid games will definitely enjoy Costume Quest 2, I love the continuation of the story from the "Grubbins on Ice" DLC in the first game, Even with the graphical improvements it still keeps the first Game at heart but with improved combat like being able to skip mini cutscenes in a fight to make combat less sluggish, SOMETHING I DON'T LIKE is the art style of the Creepy Treat Cards in the Second Game, The Creepy Treat cards looked really cool in the first one but in this one They look really... Corporate artwork and boring.

I might be blinded by nostalgia as generally its a simple game, But you like what you like I suppose, Perfect for People who liked the first game and the First game is perfect for children and adults alike.

review:

Anyway, you should play Costume Quests every Halloween.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096299973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1667141011}
review:
Link to review: https://backloggd.com/u/RedBackLoggd/review/550558/

Tl;dr - Despite being thematically appropriate, I do not recommend you waste your Halloween indulging in Costume Quest 2. It adds nothing to the original (minus retconning it to have a happier ending for the Grubbins), drains it of its charm, and doesn‚Äôt fix any of its qualms. Play something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046546456', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1686587134}
review:
For the story, you'll get more out of this by playing the last game (but it's not necessary), as a lot of the story bits and callbacks are straight from the first game.

Music is great, nothing to write home about.

Gameplay has slightly more depth, but is still terribly long and drawn-out. You now have options for more combos and a small risk-reward blocking system, but it all ultimately ends up taking way more time than you'd ever want (per battle too). If you just came from the first game and just want more story and less of the pointlessly-long combat, hack yourself to a 1xp away from level 13 and enjoy the game at a better pace.

I know this game is made for kids, so if you're reading this you're probably not a kid (and probably have more value for your time). If you played the last game and wanted more of that Double-Fine humor and story beat, this game is a great continuation. Otherwise this might turn away people who strongly dislike turn-based combat that take *way* too long to finish.

For those who care to know, I played this from start to finish on a Steam Deck. The game runs flawlessly, with the minor gripes being as follows:

- Waking from sleep will sometimes just break controller inputs (binding some keyboard inputs to a few buttons can help you get to a save point)
- Occasionally, waking from sleep will just outright crash the deck into a restart
- Most in-game menus (the first save slot selection, the inventory, Shady's Shop) seem to have a bug where it will always repeatedly be pressing a button. Most of the time it's B, other times it's A. I'm not sure how to fix this other than spamming the button that's bugging the moment the menu opens so it will "cancel out".
- Unrelated to the Deck itself, but this game does NOT support cross-platform saves, even if you try to copy the save file from the deck to a Linux distro to hopefully continue your game on. 

Besides these issues, the game runs great. No visual bugs, no weird audio glitching, all the way from start to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561199076881624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1682803541}
review:
[u] Not nearly as good as the first one. Had fun at some points but would not have bought it outside the bundle. [/u] 
 
In short: 5.5/10. The gameplay is similar to Costume Quest, but the new combat system was awful and borderline annoying. The story is okay but nothing special. Frame drops and technical issues may occur. They didn‚Äôt do anything better except for one or two small things. I loved the first title, so I am a bit disappointed.  
 
[h1] DETAILS [/h1]

(+) The gameplay (outside combat) will be the same: You walk around in adorable new costumes, hit things on your way with your bag to obtain candy, and do quests. You can buy a [b] map for each area [/b] with candy now, which conveniently tells you if you found all chests and costume parts. I found the maps mostly confusing, though (since they look like a kid‚Äôs drawing, and you still have to find your location). My biggest plus is that you can [b] roller skate with every costume to speed walk. [/b]

(+/-) Okayish storyline: An evil dentist wants to destroy Halloween? Not very groundbreaking. Nevertheless, one part of the story got me and improved my opinion.  

(-) Your health bar won‚Äôt heal after each fight anymore: You need to find a fountain (or eat candy) instead, resulting in more unnecessary walking. 

(-) [b] The new battle system made me dislike fighting: [/b] In the first game, you could easily equip ‚Äúbattle stamps‚Äù for specific combat advantages. Now they made a [b] card game [/b] out of it where you first have to select three (chaotically displayed) cards before combat, THEN select one of them during the fight and lose an entire move. You also have to consider their cool-down! Overall, it‚Äôs much more clicking and thinking if the card is worth it. Before, you also had to concentrate a little during the fights to click the correct button (E, Q, Space, or Shift) at the right time to fight/parry. Now you always press the same button (either 1, 2, or 3 depending on the character) and move with A and D to select a specific attack, card, or even run away. As I said: much clicking. [b] Frame drops made it almost impossible to get the timing right, [/b] resulting in less overall damage and longer fights ‚Äì even longer than with the changes they made. Not sure if it was because of all the said above, but the [b] combat music annoyed me. [/b]

(-) One of the worst letdowns was the overall look of the costumes in combat, which was the heart of the game for me. While I found them creative and badass in the first game, they now look 3D-ish and out of place. 
 
(-) More technical issues: My game crashed once and deleted part of my progress. One of my team members decided to randomly leave my group and run into a wall for a couple of seconds, too. Quests containing music acts were tonally out of place (= no sound while playing), thus making them feel unauthentic. 

(-) Even though I enjoyed the first area (and one near the end), everything was too dystopian and/or depressing for me. I get we needed to save Halloween, but still. (This comes from someone who loves cyberpunk vibes).

author: {'steamid': '76561199060909892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1677342920}
review:
Si bien la trama y los villanos del primer Costume Quest me resultaron m√°s atractivos, √©ste sigue siendo un excelente juego, en el que conocer√°s nuevos personajes, disfraces y podr√°s viajar a trav√©s del tiempo para salvar Halloween y reclutar nuevos compa√±eros en tu equipo. Si bien la modalidad de golpear puertas para obtener caramelos puede resultar mon√≥tona a ratos, el juego avanza r√°pido y lo compensa con una serie de misiones secundarias. Por otra parte, aspectos de la jugabilidad mejoran en este t√≠tulo en contraste con su entrega anterior, por ejemplo, respecto al desplazamiento r√°pido y al sistema de combate. Adem√°s algunas habilidades de disfraces del primer juego se reciclan inteligentemente en nuevos trajes. 
En mi opini√≥n, lo mejor de Costume Quest es que es un juego que te permite de alg√∫n modo revivir la infancia y lanzarte a la aventura y explorar el mundo bajo la perspectiva de un ni√±o -con humor y cierta simplicidad de por medio- precisamente porque los adultos de este mundo no son capaces de percibir la amenaza o bien √©stos llevaron al mundo a un desequilibrio o distop√≠a. En este sentido, Costume Quest 2 sigue prometiendo este prisma y esta singular experiencia de juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561199081871345', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1673413331}
review: A great improvement from the original that adds a more interesting story, more dynamic combat, and more varied opponents to create a wonderful short RPG. The charm of the characters and world are still here in full force and the costumes are equally as wacky as the first game, though it is unfortunate that the actual first game costumes were only available to those who pre-ordered the game. The main issue I have with this game is that some of the upgrades one gets throughout the game are not very useful, with the combo system vastly outshining the other upgrades you can unlock. Overall though, if you enjoyed the first, this game is certainly worth playing. The achievements are pretty straightforward but the Hardcorn achievement, which requires you to have the Candy Corn in your party for every battle, made the game much more difficult since the Candy Corn costume can't attack, meaning you're essentially playing with one less party member for the whole game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269399371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1673651213}
review:
I really enjoyed the first Costume Quest and really wanted to hop on the 2nd as soon as I beat the first one; however, some of the changes in the combat system made it frustrating. The concept of the game is fairly the same-- you have to go trick or treating and you bump into enemies but this time, you have to deal with cards and "circle skill checks"to make attacks more effective. First of all, I'm not a fan of the card option and can see why they added it as the first one had the cards purely for cosmetic and collectible reasons. I'm 2 hours into the game and haven't found the battle stamps, which is a little frustrating as that made the game a bit more enjoyable as you can equip and unequip them based on your liking.

I played the first Costume Quest on M&K but feel very forced to play this one on controller due to the new combat system. The beginning of the game is rather slow as you start off with a candy corn costume which doesn't do anything and is just purely a meat shield.. on top of that the candy corn commentary was funny at first but becomes repetitive and is unskippable. 

Hoping to enjoy the game more as I progress but if they're making Costume Quest 3, to revert back to the combat system to the 1st game (without the circle skill checks) and probably implement the cards, stamps and combos.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989268630', 'num_games_owned': 2949, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1667623641}
review:
So, I finally got around to hundo'ing this game...cos my Halloween irl was awful and warranted beating both this game the original Costume Quest so I could get some joy out of the season. Did it work? Yep, my Halloweek was improved! Anyway, here's the review:
Art: Better than the original, but still in the same style. Honestly, it holds up excellently compared to any modern game, because it pulls off its style perfectly. Very good!
Writing: Great! I deliberately tried to find every line of dialog, it is that good.
Audio/Music: There's more music this time (compared to Costume Quest 1), and the music is great!
Gameplay: Yes, it's simple. yes, it's (slightly) different from the original Costume Quest. But that's all fine. I didn't play this game seeking an intense, brain-wracking, RPG grindfest. There's enough mechanics here to put it a step above brain dead though, thankfully. And of course figuring out the puzzles (without hints) is rewarding.
Ending: Still trying to remember to judge games at least partly by how they handle the end of their stories. And this one is a slam dunk, no question. Just about perfect, though maybe it could be slightly improved (but I can't suggest how here because that would be spoilers), but what can't? Miles better than most endings to games, that's for absolutely certain.

In conclusion: Play this game. It's good, especially if your Halloweek irl was bad.

Side Note: Any game where I get to defend the honor of Candy Corn by dragging it into every single fight I get into in a game is a good one. Especially when I get to KO enemies with it. (You don't get that ability right away though. Keep playing, you'll get it eventually.)    (Btw, I think Candy Corn is delicious and is indeed worthy of the MANY, MANY humorous lines displayed when you use it in a fight in game.)  Happy Halloween :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198020012941', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1667273368}
review:
Definitely better than Costume Quest 1, I'd even recommend skipping 1 entirely.
A lighthearted RPG about trick-or-treater kids who transform into giant real versions of what costume they're currently wearing once combat begins.

Combat involves action commands with generous timing windows, special-move meters, and one-use (until cooldown refills) cards you can swap out between battles. It's not too difficult, I'd say it's on the generous/easy side.

Collecting candy (doubles as money and healing-in-a-pinch) loses its luster after a while but collecting new costumes remains exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999917619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1667410533}
review: It's a decent little game. Double Fine's writing is always funny, but as an rpg, it is incredibly shallow. Every fight is the same string of timed hits and the occasional card/item usage. The first game at least offered passive bonuses you could equip to alter your party's capabilities, so lacking that just simplifies things too much. If you're hoping for a paper mario: ttyd level of quality, it ain't here. Even with all that, it's irreverent and the writing really shines through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095857485', 'num_games_owned': 5155, 'num_reviews': 445, 'playtime_forever': 1570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1570, 'last_played': 1634614073}
review:
Just like the first Costume Quest this one is great too.  The story is fun, wacky and cute. The game play improved quite well from the 1st game.  The costumes in this game are just as awesome as they were in the Costume Quest.  

One of my favorite additions to this game was the treat cards which are collectible Halloween trading cards that can be used in battle as abilities (So this adds more strategy to combat).  The story is fun and chill, there is a dentist who wants to destroy Halloween and candy so he goes back in time to take over the world and ban Halloween. You will play as the main twins from the first game, you will pick the boy or girl and whoever you do not pick will be a party member for the rest of the game.  You will travel to the past & future to try to stop the dentist and save Halloween.

The games setting, music and art style are great and if you are a fan of JRPGs then you should def try this game out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025187473', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1665497316}
review:
Great game to play for the Halloween season, not as good as the first in my opinion, but still worth full price and worth playing.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
Like the first game, on some systems this game will launch into a black screen and stop responding.
Wait a couple minutes and it will work as intended with no further issues during playing.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Simplistic JRPG combat like the first, but with some differences.[list]
[*]In CQ1 you press need one of a few buttons at the right moment to do full damage, failing will do reduced damage.
In CQ2 in addition to the above, with even more accuracy you can do extra damage, but instead of a few buttons you only have to press 1 2 or 3 depending on which party member is acting.

[*]In CQ1 you can pick any costume for any situation, surviving combat is dependent on using costume powers.
In CQ2, costumes have weaknesses and strengths, your party will take and deal more or less damage depending on your weaknesses and enemy type.
Defensive costume powers are also much weaker, the focus here is on offensive, for defense you have cards.

[*]In CQ1 you equip your party members with stamps to give them a passive bonus to help in combat.
In CQ2 you don't have stamps, instead you use cards for various effects once per combat, then they need to recharge afterwards by fighting a few battles.

[*]In CQ1 when you finish a battle, you lose any charge on your abilities you had and you are fully healed.
In CQ2 when you finish a battle, you keep any charge on your abilities you had and are not healed, you have to visit a fountain or eat some of your candy to heal.

[*]In CQ1 you had to switch to the robot costume to move faster out of combat.
In CQ2 you have the robot's skates by default.[/list]

[h1]Extras[/h1]
There's some pre-order content baked into the game that you have to edit the game files to obtain, there are steam guides on how to do this.
The costumes are:[list]
[*]Pumpkin from CQ1
[*]Robot from CQ1
[*]Eyeball from CQ1
[*]Unicorn from CQ1
[*]Sackboy from the PS3 game Little Big Planet[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197992807229', 'num_games_owned': 1355, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1656543589}
review:
this game is ok. if you just finished CQ1 and the DLC, and need exactly more of that, this will do, but it's not the bigger and better expansive sequel that it should have been

there's some good ideas here: including maps of areas for trick-or-treating, sprint being bound to a button rather than a costume ability, making battle timings more frame precise (a la Paper Mario) rather than old Xbox 360-era QTE sequences, continuing tradition from the first game of a bad costume having a viable "cheese" strat against the final boss

and some half-baked ones: the strength/weaknesses system, OP Creepy Treat cards, the Superhero costume model (lol), the Candy Corn costume (special ability used literally only in the final fight), older (first game) costumes locked behind a pre-order bonus (i wonder if there's not a way to get them nowadays?), needing to heal in the overworld unlike CQ1

If you thought the CQ1 DLC ended on a cliffhanger and want a conclusion, this game picks right up there. Honestly, atmosphere/setting/story is what's most enjoyable here, with the combat doing it no favors

author: {'steamid': '76561197974627682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1654267618}
review:
Entertaining story, similar problems like the first game - took me forever to finish, I just couldn't bring myself to go play it again. The exploration, the story, characters, everything is nice. But the combat is the most basic, simplistic, primitive turn based combat ever, and on top of that, costumes that you get in like first few hours seemed the strongest and most functional, so there isn't much progression gameplay-wise. Just press the same buttons over and over, the cards are "fine", but it's annoying to constantly shuffle them after each fight.

If the combat was at all engaging, it would be a good game, because everything in the presentation works, it's even endearing at times, but the combat put me to sleep. There is also some frustration with hidden objects or comfusing and overwhelming layouts at times.

It's a shame, the game did deserve better. I say give it a pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048834816', 'num_games_owned': 2648, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1558385760}
review:
RPG de batalla por turnos el cual sirve de secuela directa de su predecesor [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/115100/Costume_Quest/] Costume Quest [/url][/u] y de su [b]DLC final (incluido dentro del juego base)[/b]. En esta nueva aventura viajaremos a trav√©s del tiempo para poner fin al malvado plan del Doctor White, el dentista de nuestro barrio que tras hacerse con el poder sobre el espacio tiempo toma el control de todos los monstruos de Repugia para crear una distop√≠a futurista sin halloween ni golosinas. Nuestra misi√≥n consistir√° en viajar entre el pasado y el futuro para hacer frente a esta nueva amenaza, poner fin a los planes del Doctor White y recuperar de nuevo la normalidad.

El juego, como su antecesor, se sustenta sobre una base RPG de batalla por turnos donde nuestros h√©roes ir√°n desbloqueando diferentes disfraces que les proporcionar√°n habilidades √∫nicas para el combate as√≠ como m√∫ltiples equipamientos para potenciarlas, a su vez deberemos ir avanzando en la trama sirviendonos de estos para sortear obstaculos y resolver puzles. Por la parte gr√°fica nos encontramos con un titulo de est√©tica "Cell-Shading" combinada con "Super-Deformed" donde destaca enormemente la calidad y la simpat√≠a puesta en sus originales dise√±os que denotan gran fluidez de movimientos y calidad de modelaje que a su vez casan a la perfecci√≥n con unos amplios y coloridos escenarios ofreciendo gran nivel de detalle y sorprendiendo por sus fant√°sticos efectos de luces y sombras.  por la parte sonora la OST se presenta correcta, buenos efectos de sonido combinados con una banda sonora inmersiva y de gran calidad nos sumergen totalmente en la acci√≥n gracias a unas composiciones variadas y amenas. Finalmente en el apartado jugable encontramos unos controles sencillos e intuitivos con interacciones claras y r√°pidas que aportan mucho dinamismo a la acci√≥n as√≠ como una interfaz din√°mica con funciones acordes, aunque cabe destacar que la elecci√≥n de mando para jugarlo har√° mas c√≥modas las interacciones, sobretodo de cara a realizar los ataques sincronizados en los combates.

As√≠ pues y como nota final solo cabe remarcar el buen trabajo realizado creando una continuaci√≥n directa de un peque√±o titulo que nos brind√≥ un toque diferente y divertido al ya encasillado mundo del RPG de batalla por turnos y que nuevamente nos ofrece una entra√±able y divertida historia que, a√∫n sin grandes pretensiones se hace eco de su antecesor ofreciendo una grata y desternillante historia que encantar√° a los amantes del g√©nero y que adem√°s podemos adquirir en pack junto con su pimera parte a un precio bastante razonable. Bastante recomendable.

[h1] An√°lisis relacionados de inter√©s: [/h1]
 [u][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/taizo_hori/recommended/115100?snr=1_5_9__402] Costume Quest (GAME)[/url][/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198274487864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1643494176}
review:
Costume Quest 2 tries to fix a lot of what isn't broken: special abilities take longer to charge. You have to heal after every battle now. Costumes have strengths and weaknesses, rock-paper-scissor style, but you can't switch in battle to take advantage. 

Gripes aside, the costumes and humor are still enjoyable. You get to actually use the candy corn costume in battle, and even though it‚Äôs inert, the sheer amount of dialogue they wrote for this piece of candy is impressive. It was honestly my favorite part.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030968107', 'num_games_owned': 1219, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1641936953}
review:
Was a big fan of the first game and this continuation doesn't disappoint.
It's fun to do, combat is slightly repetitive if you stick with the same outfit for longer, but with the pacing of the game (and finding the costumes) it isn't bad.

Hardcorn difficulty is a funny twist (though had to do the final boss twice because of it...) but I'd have preferred a true "hard" mode.

The game is very easy, but amazing to play too!

review:
I really enjoyed Costume Quest 2. 

It felt like the trophies were pretty grindy so I didn't bother with a lot of them. 

Although the environments in Costume Quest 2 were more fun & the secrets were better hidden I enjoyed the fighting style of Costume Quest 1 more. 

I'd still recommend the game as I had a great time with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986697530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1635390322}
review: These simple Double Fine RPGs have done a great job of capturing the Halloween spirit in a way you don't see often in gaming. While I do prefer the original's simpler child viewpoint, the sequel here goes wild with the goofy dystopian time travel elements. Locations are much larger and more fleshed out and the same goes for the combat. As a whole this is an improved game but I think the shorter, more down to earth trick or treat experience of the original is the one I'll return to more often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104755860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 936, 'last_played': 1638214128}
review: The achievements was a real pain to get and to be honest the fighting becomes so repetitive that it feels like a never ending battle, it gets annoying to use all the cards in battles as well. But above all it was still super fun saving halloween, I love how you can upgrade the costumes and how you use every costume to advance in the game by not only fighting with it but using is strategically. Have fun doing some time travelling, collecting candies and collecting those annoying cards!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022113409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1637571751}
review:
I've decided not to recommend this game, although I did enjoy it. I played the first Costume Quest and really loved how it captured the pure whimsy of Halloween and trick-or-treating. Not only did it look cute and have the right Halloween atmosphere, but it was also a simple yet fun game.

Costume Quest 2 is very much the same basic formula, with plenty of humour and silliness throughout. Unfortunately, it's just not as fun. Combat is somehow made into a total chore in this game. There is some satisfaction in figuring out the best way to use the card mechanic and special ability mechanic across battles - for example, charging up during one battle and switching your cards so you are ready for a harder battle. But it becomes very repetitive, and I resent that I actually had to grind battles at the end just to get to the top level and get all the candy I needed to buy everything.

I really struggled to get into the game, trying multiple times to start but always groaning about playing it. Eventually I got a full hour into the game and started to enjoy it more. But after a while, the last few hours started to feel like a chore again. I found myself finishing it just to finish it.

Also, in traditional Double Fine fashion, most things about the game are either painfully easy or obtusely difficult to figure out. Most of the quests and challenges are really just a matter of putting around the map and slogging through the turn-based battles. I don't mind this a lot of the time, since I do enjoy wandering around the environment looking for stuff. And sometimes the dialogue and quests could be very funny. But at the end of the day, you really are just running back and forth without much challenge. Once in a while, a certain battle will be strangely difficult, even though the final boss battle of the game is actually very easy. More frustratingly, though, there are times where I found myself running around because it wasn't exactly clear what I was supposed to do next, and the answer was so specific that I either had to stumble upon it or look up a hint. One time there was actually NO way for me to get through without looking it up because the visual cue I needed to see was hidden from sight. Did they not catch that in play testing? This really took me out of the flow and the atmosphere of the game. I probably would have enjoyed it more if this hadn't happened a few times, cause that's when it started to feel like a chore.

And while I do enjoy the imaginative environments, it was a bit sad that the classic Costume Quest Halloween vibe was only present in certain areas, while a lot of areas were cold and bland because they took place in a dystopian future. It was interesting to explore the first time, but got real old when I was milling around figuring out what I had missed.

It seems like there are certain flaws that Double Fine repeats in all their games, and those flaws made this game less enjoyable than it could have been. It felt slightly unfinished, as if they had reached a certain point and given up on trying to fix the last few things that prevented it from being super fun. All that said, it's not a bad game and it's totally worth playing if you want a cute and fun Halloween-y game to play. If you haven't played the first one, though, that is an even better option.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123801073', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1637448090}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019219529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 743, 'last_played': 1637447148}
review: Played through both the first CQ and this with my young daughter. The story in this one is a bit like Back to the Future but kept us (mostly) entertained. I handled the combat so when it got a little repetitive she wavered but it usually didn't take long to move the story forward and she really enjoyed that. In the end she wished it went longer (we beat it in 12 hours) but fortunately our last save is right before the final battle so we're able to go back to playing some of the things we missed. Not sure how much extra content that gives us but it's still nice. Combat in this one is simplified to pretty much just be about timing and at first I thought that wouldn't be great but honestly it just made the overall experience better; the battles don't really need to be so complicated. Overall this is a great game for the right audience, my only wish is it lasted a bit longer (I feel the first CQ had a bit more).

author: {'steamid': '76561198033086654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1636902028}
review:
I'm not sure if I prefer this or the original but this game has changed some things for better and worse.  The biggest advantage this game has for me is that every costume now has the boost shoes.  Before, I always wore the robot suit mainly for the faster movement speed.  Now, every costume can move faster so I was more willing to try different costumes throughout.  The upgrades are also nice, giving bonuses to your costumes, and the menu system was better designed, making it easier to sort out your bonuses.  
Some things I liked less was the inclusion of enemy types as it didn't seem to impact too much, and the Creepy Cards which I thought were hit and miss.  I also thought the story missed some potential with its time travel element - I was surprised the kids didn't make a remark about Little Bones or had more interaction with Dorsilla considering who they become.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042019439', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1634668005}
review:
I had trouble deciding whether to give this a thumbs up or down rating. It is not a bad game, but it‚Äôs not as good as its predecessor for a few reasons. If you look at the review page for the first game, you‚Äôll see many players praising the nostalgic feel and charming design, calling it a game to play every Halloween. Sadly, this is entirely absent for most of 2. Instead of suburban neighborhoods, malls, and fairs decorated for the season, you spend most of the game in a generic, rainy dystopian city. This is justified with the (admittedly decent) story about a time-travelling candy-hating dentist, but I would have liked to spend the game seeing the Halloween spirit come back to the drab environments.

Regarding gameplay, 2 tries to vary things up for its turn-based combat compared to the first game, but none of the changes really worked for me. Timed button presses are now used for every attack and defense action, but they are represented as a shrinking circle and much harder to get right. You no longer heal automatically after every battle, but it‚Äôs rarely more than a 10 second detour to find a healing/saving water fountain on the overworld. There is a simple damage-type system with each costume being stronger or weaker against monster, magic, or mechanical enemies, but the impact is barely noticeable with the boring but practical strategy of taking out the enemy party one at a time, regardless of their composition. 

Lastly, the stamps from the first game have been replaced by the trading cards in a system which had promise, but fell flat. You pick 3 cards from your collection to keep on hand for battle, can play them for a given effect in place of any party member‚Äôs turn, and must wait a certain number of battles before you can use it again.  Unfortunately, combat is so easy that battles rarely take more than 3 full turns for the whole party, so spending one of your actions to play a card is almost never worth your time. I wound up only using the cards that increased Candy and XP payout to reduce grinding, and still never lost a battle.

If you really enjoy Costume Quest, this might have some novelty for the new costumes, continuity nods to the first game, and a few decently funny moments, but it simply lacks the holiday charm that makes the original such a treat. Throw in a battle system that increases variety but remains as shallow as a puddle, and you‚Äôll ultimately wish you were playing the first game again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198816179817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1634575800}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034666581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1634613932}
review: Okay so first off, I do technically recommend this game, however I'd be lying if I said you're sure to love it if you loved the original game. Long story short it's an okay game, passable as far as standards go. Personally I'm not a huge fan of it since they changed a lot of what I liked about the original, mostly mechanically. It also has a number of visual defects and downright bugs, which is honestly something I can say I never encountered while playing the original Costume Quest even though I replay it every October. In this one I had a rather large bug take place after getting a costume that lets you use the ziplines you see around the game, while I was still on the line my character fell off into the void and all I could do was reset the game via Alt+F4 since I couldn't even open the menu. Normally this games saves often, but since it was a weird spot I had to redo a number of things. This year is only my second time playing this one while having close to 10 replays of the first game under my belt, I almost wasn't going to bother but decided I was in the mood this year.

7/10. "Candy Corn is planning its next move." Lol.

review:
Costume Quest 2 is the sequal to my favourite halloween game (does it count if it's my only?)
How can you not enjoy a RPG about time-traveling to save halloween (and the world I guess) from being ruined by dentists? I enjoyed finding all the costumes and trying them out in battle. Gotta say, the dental drones don't stand a chance when they're fighting against the entire solar system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043135631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2248, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1613995292}
review:
I simply did enjoy the first game quite a lot.
And even that cool free DLC for that game.
The first game was truly fun to experience.
So, I had high hopes for this sequel as well.
But to be honest, I do not like the combat.
It feels like a downgrade of the first game.
The combat in the sequel was just boring.
And that was probably the only negative.
I did enjoy the visuals and even the story.
Most of the gameplay was enjoyable too.
But the combat is truly a big downgrade.
At the end of the day: I did enjoy it, tho.
It's a pretty decent sequel in my opinion.
And I still hope to see a third installment.
Overall, I have to give it a positive review.
This franchise is just worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002506911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 415, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1233, 'last_played': 1612244871}
review:
Costume Quest 2 continues the same concepts that made the original great.  However, this one does not offer much that is new and definitely gets repetitive before then moving the story forward.  I will say though that the game is still fun and enjoyable.

You control a group the main character Wren, Reynolds, and a third kid.  You go around trick or treating to collect candy or parts for more costumes.  Each level offers a variety of secrets where you can discover more costumes.  Each costume also has a special action it can do in the world, when not fighting.  This adds a puzzle element to the game.  When fighting you play a Final Fantasy style fighting game where you costumes become real characters to be reckoned with.  The game offers something like 12 costumes to collect.

The storyline the game follows is about your dentist stealing a talisman from the past which eventually changes the world so that Halloween is no longer celebrated and candy is illegal.  You must follow the dentist into the future and into the past to regain the talisman and make the world happy with candy again.

Overall, the game is just cute.  The graphics are cartoony, the dialogue is fun, the actions are what you would expect in a kids game.  You even have the chance to speed across the game world on your healies, shoes with wheels.  The only downfall is that it gets repetitive and it's very easy.  So in easy in fact that one of the achievements is to beat with game with the Candy Corn costume being on at all times throughout the game.  The Candy Corn costume does not fight.  This means that only 2 out of the 3 characters is fighting at all times.  That's how easy the game is.

If you played the first one, you have to play the second one.  If you missed the first one, to be honest, you should probably play the first one, but you can still play this one without missing anything by not playing the first.  Enjoy the game when you play, I know I did.

review:

Ademas es como una peli de disney, te lo puedes jugar con 25 a√±os y te va a gustar pero vamos si te lo juegas con 12 tambi√©n, dir√≠a de esperar una rebaja pero comprarlo si tienes el m√≠nimo inter√©s el combate aunque empiece con pocas opciones luego aprendes mas t√©cnicas y las cartas dan mucha profundidad al combate haciendo tus combinaciones y t√°cticas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109741813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1076, 'last_played': 1604191748}
review: Enjoyed the first installment of this series and loving the sequel even more.  Double Fine brings their signature brand of game play and graphics to another fantastic game.  For anyone who adores Halloween along with a fun but challenging turn based game, this is for you.  The story is enjoyable and quirky to make any age laugh and gasp.  Played through the game twice for the achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170551349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1609554370}
review: Nope, could not get started on this adventure. They say, not as good as the first and for this it is true. Seemed thrown together and just not on pace as the first quest. Almost like this should of been the part 1 and the first should of followed. Suggest playing the first but no need for the second.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040709134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1609546821}
review: It's a fun cute game with a decent story. If you liked the first, you will surely like this one, although its different enough where I don't feel like I'm just playing the same game. The gameplay is better than the first, adding a little more strategy but can still get pretty repetitive. If your looking for challenging gameplay, this is not your game. But if you want a cute story about halloween with some basic turn-based combat with timed attacks, it won't disappoint.

author: {'steamid': '76561198373591513', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1085, 'last_played': 1607352713}
review:
[quote]C‚Äôest un pur bonheur que de retrouver nos petits h√©ros mignons dans cette suite p√©tillante et pleine d‚Äôhumour ! Votre nouvelle mission : Sauver la f√™te d‚ÄôHalloween gravement menac√©e par l‚Äôaffreux docteur White..[/quote]

[i]Litt√©ralement tomb√©e sous le charme du premier opus, il me tardait de poursuivre l‚Äôaventure dans ce second volet qui ne m‚Äôa pas d√©√ßue ! Contrairement √† certaines sagas dans lesquelles les √©volutions graphiques ou de gameplay sautent aux yeux, rien n‚Äôest ici vraiment d√©paysant. Toujours aussi plaisant √† parcourir ‚ÄúCostume Quest 2‚Äú reste tr√®s similaire au premier except√© peut-√™tre au niveau des combats qui b√©n√©ficient d‚Äôune approche plus riche et plus dynamique √©vitant ainsi les petites longueurs du pr√©c√©dent volet. √Ä titre purement informatif, vous retrouverez ici, de fait, certains √©l√©ments descriptif de mon √©valuation du premier [URL=https://store.steampowered.com/app/115100/Costume_Quest/]Costume Quest[/URL] toujours d‚Äôactualit√©.[/i]

Rest√©s en suspens √† la fin du premier opus, vos petits h√©ros tout mignons doivent √† pr√©sent sauver Halloween gravement menac√© par le vilain docteur White, vouant un culte obsessionnel √† l‚Äôhygi√®ne bucco-dentaire et bien d√©cid√© √† mettre un terme √† cette f√™te traditionnelle ainsi qu‚Äô√† toutes les orgies de sucre qu‚Äôelle repr√©sente.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2305680215
Exploration, r√©colte de bonbons, confection de d√©guisements d√©lirants, qu√™tes en pagaille ou combats rigolos, on retrouve ici toutes les m√©caniques du premier opus. Toutes sauf une qui √©tait pourtant si sympathique.. le jeu des pommes ! Ni lui, ni aucun autre petit jeu. En revanche, une part plus importante est consacr√©e √† l‚Äôexploration et le nombre de lieux √† visiter est plus important, on dira qu‚Äôau final √ßa r√©√©quilibre bien les choses.

[h1]Goules sucr√©es[/h1]
Th√®me d‚ÄôHalloween oblige, la qu√™te de friandise √† s‚Äôen faire p√©ter la panse reste une priorit√© et √† l‚Äôinstar du premier opus tout est bon pour gagner des bonbecs : frapper aux portes (au risque de vous retrouvez nez √† nez avec un gros m√©chant pas beau que vous devrez affronter) ou frapper sur un peu tout ce qui vous passe sous la main, √† vous de chercher !

En plus de l‚Äôimmense satisfaction de voir votre pr√©cieux butin s‚Äô√©toffer, les friandises peuvent √† l‚Äôoccasion vous redonner de l‚Äô√©nergie (si, si !) mais elles sont surtout une pr√©cieuse monnaie d‚Äô√©change pour acheter des plans, des am√©liorations de costumes et des cartes de ¬´¬†bonbons farceurs¬†¬ª utiles lors les combats (elles remplacent les timbres de combats qui n‚Äôexistent plus dans cette suite).

[h1]Des qu√™tes, toujours des qu√™tes..[/h1]
Si vous connaissez d√©j√† le premier Costume Quest vous savez d√©j√† un peu ce qui vous attend. Pour les autres, sachez que la liste des qu√™tes secondaires qui viennent s‚Äôaccumuler au fil de l‚Äôaventure peut effrayer au d√©but, mais en pratique bon nombre d‚Äôentre elles se r√©alisent d‚Äôelles-m√™me au cours de l‚Äôaventure (les autres √©tant facultatives).

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2312031795
Un petit carnet bien pratique et tenu automatiquement √† jour permet d‚Äôacc√©der rapidement √† toutes les informations dont vous avez besoin : que ce soit les qu√™tes restant √† effectuer, les costumes trouv√©s et leurs propri√©t√©s, les plans ou votre collection de cartes de bonbons farceurs.

[h1]√Ä vos aiguilles ![/h1]
Comme dans le premier opus, le plaisir de confectionner et d√©couvrir de nouveaux d√©guisements reste intact ! Plus loufoques les uns que les autres leurs diff√©rentes propri√©t√©s peuvent s‚Äôav√©rer d‚Äôune grande utilit√© lors des phases de combat. Pour obtenir une nouvelle tenue, il vous faudra commencer par en trouver le ¬´¬†patron¬†¬ª indiquant les √©l√©ments qui la composent (et que bien-s√ªr, vous allez vous employer √† chercher f√©brilement). Une fois les diff√©rentes parties r√©cup√©r√©es, la tenue se cr√©√© automatiquement et on a plus qu‚Äôune seule h√¢te : l‚Äôexp√©rimenter lors d‚Äôun combat pour la d√©couvrir en situation !

Certaines ont des propri√©t√©s plus d√©fensives / protectrices et d‚Äôautres sont plus port√©es vers l‚Äôattaque. √Ä vous de choisir celles que vous pr√©f√©rez et d‚Äô√©quiper vos personnages avec les cartes de bonbons farceurs qui vous semblent les mieux appropri√©es (soit dans le but de parer aux lacunes de telle ou telle tenue, soit inversement pour venir amplifier un pouvoir d√©j√† tr√®s fort). Dans cet opus, vous avez √©galement la possibilit√© d‚Äôacheter des am√©liorations permanentes de costumes moyennant [strike]quelques[/strike] beaucoup de friandises.

Une bonne gestion des costumes et des cartes √©quip√©es permet de vaincre tous les ennemis sans aucune difficult√©. Mes chouchous sur ce volume : Le Sorcier, le hot-dog et le clown (m√™me si la cin√©matique de son pouvoir sp√©cial de combat devient vite horriblement aga√ßante √† la longue elle reste super utile !). √Ä noter que plusieurs d√©guisements ont des propri√©t√©s tr√®s utiles durant l‚Äôaventure (m√™me hors des combats).

[h1]Les combats[/h1]
C‚Äôest probablement pour moi ce qui a √©t√© notablement am√©lior√© dans ce second volet. Sur le fond les m√©caniques restent similaires : les combats se jouent au tour par tour avec des phases de QTE durant lesquelles l‚Äôex√©cution des indications doit √™tre r√©alis√©e correctement et dans un temps imparti. Mais √† pr√©sent il ne suffit plus de cliquer ¬´¬†sur le bon bouton au bon moment¬†¬ª : l‚Äôexp√©rience s‚Äôest enrichie d‚Äôune sorte de timing de frappe qui n√©cessite de percuter ou de parer l‚Äôadversaire √† un instant pr√©cis qui apporte de l‚Äôinteractivit√© et une touche de r√©alisme tr√®s gratifiante lors de l‚Äôaction ! De plus, vous aurez plusieurs fois l‚Äôoccasion de travailler avec votre ma√Ætre d‚Äôarmes afin de perfectionner et apprendre tr√®s progressivement les techniques de combats. C‚Äôest particuli√®rement bien pens√©, rapide et intuitif.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2309929123
√Ä chaque ¬´¬†mauvaise¬†¬ª rencontre, le combat est annonc√© par une courte cin√©matique durant laquelle vous voyez votre mignon bambin se m√©tamorphoser en super combattant. La cin√©matique varie en fonction du costume que vous portez √† ce moment l√† et je vous assure que m√™me dans le costume le plus ridicule la transformation est stup√©fiante ! √Ä noter que les cin√©matiques des phases de combats dans le style Manga contrastent avec le style mignon et tr√®s enfantin du reste du jeu.

Sachez que la dur√©e de vie du jeu d√©pend beaucoup de votre fa√ßon de jouer (si vous tracez la route ou si vous avez envie de fouiner partout pour d√©crocher tous les succ√®s) je donnerai donc ici une fourchette plut√¥t large √† titre purement indicatif : comptez entre 10 et 20 heures pour boucler l‚Äôaventure.

üìé Bilan tr√®s positif pour la suite de ce petit RPG qui ne devrait pas d√©cevoir les amateurs du premier opus ! √Ä la fois dr√¥le et enfantin, ‚ÄúCostume Quest 2‚Äú peut sans aucun probl√®me √™tre conseill√© aux adultes comme aux plus jeunes.

review: Costume Quest 2 is an improvement from the first one with a more solid storyline. The continuity of the different environments feels more natural too, which makes the game even more pleasant and engaging than the first one. The fighting mechanic that makes the identity of the game is still present and the costumes are great, being funny both to children and to older players.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993890344', 'num_games_owned': 1194, 'num_reviews': 389, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1604140066}
review: Pretty cool little sequel, different combat system and a few other cool new little things compared to the first game. Only issue is its not much longer and if you don't miss things and you don't try to speedrun through it the game is pretty easy, I don't think I even died once on my second playthrough. My only big issue with this game is the bosses are easier than in the first game and the finale isn't as good so that's the only problem. One thing that could be better is the cards you get in the game which are usable in battles, they're cool but you never really need to use them and there's an achievement for using every one of them however that will take up the whole playthrough trying to use them all so you never get time to pick favorites and use them after you've unlocked them all. So would be good if the game was a little bit longer, overall though pretty good. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198018293698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1603910869}
review:
When you're tired of the spooky games in the spooky month, there's nothing more sweet or seasonably appropriate than Costume Quest, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/crateboxer/recommended/115100/]which I really liked[/url]. Luckily, that goes for the sequel as well!

Costume Quest 2 is a fairly "safe" sequel, operating on basically the exact same formula, structure and even engine as the original game. It's definitely closer to a stand-alone expansion than a true, genre-bending reinvention of the formula. If Costume Quest was decidedly not your thing, even if it's better I still don't think Costume Quest 2 is gonna change your mind.

But if you liked the original, Costume Quest 2 is more of the same candy to gorge yourself on. That's not to say there aren't [i]any[/i] improvements‚Äîfar from it. Indeed, all of the most annoying features of the original have been fixed. There's a teeny bit more depth in the combat with a rock-paper-scissors gimmick and reusable items, and also just "feels" better thanks to timing window changes. The levels are a little more varied and exotic than the suburbia of the original. Best of all, the framerate is an even 60 now, making everything so much smoother. I understand why Costume Quest 1 runs at 30 FPS (timing RPGs are tricky that way) but I'm very glad a fix was a priority for the sequel because the smoother FPS makes the adorable art look so much nicer.

It's also still pretty hilarious. I know "good writing" is usually such a given for Double Fine it's almost not worth mentioning, but good writing is hard! The fact that it always seems so effortless is a huge compliment to the dev team.

The worst thing about Costume Quest 2 is that it feels kinda silly to play it any time other than Halloween. But it's short and sweet, and it's well worth picking both games up to dabble with between trick-or-treaters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146450963', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1572640756}
review:
Following the events of the first game‚Äôs Grubbins on Ice story, the kids of Halloween have returned to a new threat. A crazy dentist has found a way to take over the world and ban Halloween as well. The kids won‚Äôt accept that, and you shouldn‚Äôt either. Get your costumes ready for another adventure to save Halloween in Costume Quest 2.

[h1]The Good[/h1][i]Battle Cards can be used by anyone in battle.[/i]

In the first game, you could acquire stamps that when equipped, can give you another action in battle, whether it‚Äôs a special attack, healing your allies or something else. You could only equip one stamp per character, unfortunately.

In the sequel, you can collect battle cards instead of stamps, and the setup has improved for usage in battle. While you can only equip 5 cards at a time during battles, your entire team can now use the cards at anytime, instead of being limited to having each characters with one card. This makes the battles more manageable and experience less frustrations as a result.

[h1]The Bad[/h1][i]Not a fan of Candy Corn Costume‚Äôs usage.[/i]

One of the first costumes that you will have available will be the Candy Corn costume, which wasn‚Äôt used in the first game, but was worn by the kidnapped sibling. As far as what the costume is useful for... nothing, just nothing.

All of the costumes that you can acquire has their own unique abilities and the Candy Corn‚Äôs ability is simply drawing enemy attacks to it and while wearing it, you can‚Äôt attack, which puts you down one character in battles. There‚Äôs an achievement for completing the game with the costume on from start to finish, but I feel that wasn‚Äôt really necessary.

[h1]The Ugly[/h1][i]Sequel feels shorter than the first game.[/i]

It‚Äôs been a while since I last played Costume Quest 2, so when looking back at the game length, it feels roughly the same as the first game without the extra story, yet in hindsight, the sequel feels shorter compared to the first. When thinking what could be the possible reason for this, I look at how the game puts more focus on having you progress through the story and that there‚Äôs less focus on side activities, like trick-or-treating and mini-games.


While the second game feels shorter, the experience and fun factor is still there and with some improvements, like the battle cards feature, this is another experience that shouldn‚Äôt be ignored.

[h1]Developers (Headquarters)[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Double Fine Productions (San Francisco, CA)
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 603, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1602101099}
review:
The sequel to the awesome Costume Quest, Costume Quest 2 seeks to deliver a similar experience to the first title, trying to improve a few things and, along the way, making some things worse.
For starters, the trick or treating is still present, but somehow feels a bit tacked on. It‚Äôs not the main objective anymore, but a means to reach an end. The story is more convoluted with time travel, and you‚Äôll visit more locations. However, they‚Äôre not as interesting as the ones present in the original game, that had fewer but more memorable places to go. Combat is a bit different with more options and new costumes, and overall feels a bit better, with one big exception. This time you can equip 3 cards with various special effects, and after using one it will be on cooldown for a few battles. You can swap used cards for fresh ones between battles but doing that constantly after every single battle is incredibly annoying, and I just avoided most of them. And, if you‚Äôre going for all achievements, you practically need to play the entire game with only 2 party members, which is totally doable, but a bit annoying as well.
There‚Äôre still lots of things to do and collect, but the way the game tracks things going for 100% is a bit inferior to in the original game. And this time, unfortunately, you‚Äôll need to grind some battles for candy to buy everything and even to reach max level. All costumes have an upgrade now, including the 4 bonus ones from the first title that my copy included, but those are incredibly expensive to buy to give small benefits. Still, one of the best additions to progression.
Now, I‚Äôm not trying to say that this is a bad game. It‚Äôs still a good experience, I just personally enjoyed the original Costume Quest much more. I can see the improvements made (and this one runs at 60 FPS) but there are a lot of design nitpicks that together detracted me a bit from fully enjoying this game. So, my recommendation is to pick the first Costume Quest, and play the second one if you enjoyed it and want more of the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359185', 'num_games_owned': 1329, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1446296894}
review: J'avais vraiment beaucoup aim√© Costume Quest, son univers, son humour et son gameplay basique mais parfaitement adapt√© √† l'aventure. J'esp√©rais n√©anmoins quelque chose de plus consistant pour ce deuxi√®me opus et c'est exactement l'inverse qui s'est produit : le jeu reprend exactement la m√™me architecture mais en moins bien : pouvoirs des costumes sous-exploit√©s lors de la partie exploration, dialogues et humour d√©cevants, aventure encore plus courte et inconsistante (malgr√© quelques vraies bonnes id√©es sur la fin) et un gameplay l√©g√®rement modifi√© mais pas vraiment plus int√©ressant - d'autant que le jeu √©tant devenu tr√®s facile je n'ai m√™me jamais eu besoin d'utiliser la moindre carte lors des combats. Je me suis bien amus√© malgr√© cela mais c'est quand m√™me regrettable d'en arriver √† faire moins bien sur tous les points alors qu'un second √©pisode permet g√©n√©ralement d'am√©liorer la formule.

author: {'steamid': '76561198330055872', 'num_games_owned': 1434, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1600020334}
review:
En Costume Quest 2, saldremos nuevamente durante la noche de Halloween para conseguir los preciados caramelos, pero... ¬°El dentista de la familia quiere destruir la festividad y quedarse con todos los caramelos! ¬øLograr√°s convencer al villano de devolver el az√∫car al pueblo?

[h1]Pro/s:[/h1]
- Se mantiene la est√©tica de la saga: Buena historia, m√∫sica, etc.
- Mejoras en batallas y mayor uso de las habilidades del disfraz para avanzar.
- Funciona perfectamente con mando. [i](Al menos con el Pro Controller)[/i] 

[h1]Contra/s:[/h1]
- Un poco m√°s caro que su predecesor.


Consegu√≠ el juego despu√©s de pasarme por completo [i]Costume Quest[/i] y quedarme con ganas de m√°s. Este me ha costado un poco m√°s pasarlo, quiz√°s porque desde primera hora he ido con el reto del ma√≠z de caramelo y algunos momentos de la historia se volv√≠an poco intuitivos.

Cabe destacar que la historia tiene una duraci√≥n aproximada de siete horas y, aunque incluye un DLC, se trata de los disfraces de la anterior saga [i](H√©roe, Robot, Calabaza y Unicornio)[/i]. Realmente, espero que en el futuro Double Fine nos brinde con una tercera parte de esta apasionante historia... ¬°Juego 100% recomendado!

[h1]Nota: 9/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198095668425', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1598730656}
review:
Apr√®s avoir ferm√© la barri√®re entre notre monde et celui des monstres voleurs de bonbons dans le premier √©pisode, on doit cette fois emp√™cher un dentiste fou de faire dispara√Ætre Halloween.

Le c√¥t√© 'enfantin/ind√©' du premier √©pisode a essay√© d'√™tre rendu trop 'adulte/pro' dans ce second √©pisode √† mon go√ªt (exc√®s de sucreries ?), plus joli mais moins fun :
+ Graphismes plus fins
+ On retrouve ce qui marchait dans le premier √©pisode (structure globale, costumes et qu√™tes, etc.)
- costumes moins "rigolos", ou li√©s √† l'enfance et aux 'vrais costumes'
- Syst√®me de combat moins fun (combo qui ne sert √† rien √† par faire durer les combats, QTE qui sont toujours les m√™mes, qq soit les personnages/costumes et moins sympas, les contres, etc.)
- Level design moins intuitif
- Qu√™tes et histoires parfois peu claires, √ßa m'est arriv√© qq fois de juste ne pas savoir quoi faire pour avancer dans l'histoire (ce qui ne m'√©tait pas arriv√© dans le 1, o√π tout s‚Äôencha√Ænait de fa√ßon fluide)

Donc optionnel si on a fait le un, qui reste pour moi la r√©f√©rence entre ces deux √©pisodes.
Petit pouce bleu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025448088', 'num_games_owned': 1206, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1598358494}
review:
1st try:
I have a xbox controller plugged in, game did not detect that. Navigated to the options with keyboard -> game freezes.
---
2nd try:
Game detected my controller (Press (A) instead of [Space]), but not responding to it. Unplugging controller causes another freeze. It seems that each time plugging/unplugging a controller will cause a freeze.
Game seems to display in the same resolution regardless of setting. If you run it at full screen it's at full screen, otherwise it's at some kind of windowed mode that you can't adjust the window's size or see the top bar of the window. You can only tell it's at windows mode by a very thin line of your wallpaper at the right side of your screen. This "window" still occupies your full screen, again regardless of game resolution settings.
---
3rd try:
Launched the game's DX9 version instead. Freezed immediately.
Let's see how many updates I can make to this review...
I may still try the game using a keyboard but for now this is the worst experience I've had with Double Fine games.
---
Final try:
So I did try to play the game with keyboard. Weirdest thing is: controller rumbles as it should be, it just won't work as an input device. Tried key binding - if I press the keys on the controller, the game seems to have registered them, in fact not. Using controller is a dream and without proper keyboard instructions makes using keyboard a nightmare.
Dialogue is not as witty as the last. Boring house grinding (oh how much I hated that part in the last game) started as soon as you unlocked the third costume.

Man I had so many good memories with Double Fine games and Costume Quest 1...I guess I won't give this game another try any time soon. Might watch some Let's Play instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978369654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1480, 'last_played': 1596998677}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is an easy to play adventure game with a turn based combat system.
The gameplay is similar to Costume Quest 1 and the story is again about saving halloween.
Every costume in the game  has special stats for attack and defense etc.
You accumulate candy by trick and treating and by winning battles agains the villains.
The candy can be traded for special abilities in the form of cards, which can be used in combat.
During the game you find new costumes with special stats which are necessary to progress.

All in all a lighthearted fun to  play game, targeted to players age 10 and up I estimate.
I found it a nice diversion from the other, games that I normally play.
That's it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096297343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1597270735}
review: A fun and charming game using simple turn based combat mechanics, with a fun and comedic story that anyone of any age could enjoy. Easier than the first Costume Quest, but doesn't lack teeth, and makes a great first game to play with the young ones if you're a parent. If you see it on sale, it's absolutely worth the couple bucks and hours to beat. This is also an incredibly easy game for achievement hunters, one short play through can net you everything.
