author: {'steamid': '76561198119374337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1594960609}
review:
As someone who has gone out of their way to play Costume Quest 1 every year for a few years now (simply because it's a personal Halloween tradition of mine), I have enjoyed the first one immensely. Because of this, I was apprehensive to say the least playing the second game.

If you have played the first game and are looking for a similar experience, Costume Quest 2 brings that feeling back with a tad more simplicity, but also some flavor. It still retains combat elements from the first game, combined with the same "battle costumes" concept that allows you to fight monsters. The costumes you choose between in this game are new. While a few costumes are lacking in appeal to me personally, there were some costumes that were immediately my favorites. (The hot-dog costume is adorable.) You also feel rewarded fighting and playing, as you can learn combat techniques that help you and you can tell the difference between your damage output before and after you learn them.

As for the story, it can be a little confusing, simply because it has time-traveling elements, which is confusing in and of itself. Old characters from Costume Quest 1 and Grubbins on Ice show up, so it really feels like you're playing the sequel to this game. The story line is a little ridiculous, but obviously had some thought and care put into it, and I found myself playing just to know exactly what would happen, and how it would happen.

There were some things that deterred me from it, and I'm not sure if I'll play it again. If I do, it will be in place of the first Costume Quest until I get every achievement. And then it's back to the first one.

The first thing I really hated was when you got a "perfect/critical hit" the screen flashes bright purple/white. If you are sensitive to flashing lights, it can be annoying to see that every time you're in a battle and you get at least 1 critical hit. Be prepared if you are.

Another thing was how on-the-nose a LOT of jokes and themes were, but as far as anyone is concerned, this game IS geared toward an audience on the younger side, despite being a game that is open to all ages 10+.

There wasn't much that notably took away from the game, and I must admit it has a lot of love put into it, in terms of really making it feel like a sequel to the first Costume Quest. I would say whatever qualms you have about this series (or this game in particular) put it aside, and try playing, especially for how cheap the 1&2 bundle is.) It's about 6-7 hours of content per-game I'd say, and playing it was a fun experience. It's also really easy to put down and pick back up again after a few days/weeks. I really would genuinely recommend this game to anyone who is curious about trying it, and is looking for a serious review.

Thanks for reading! I hope this helped anyone who is questioning buying it. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198036844151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1561892726}
review:
Well, first off, let me tell you: the game is REPETETIVE. Like, REALLY REPETITIVE.

You do the same battles, watch the same battle animations, do the same quick time events that don‚Äôt really have that much variety within them. Even the bosses themselves don't offer that much variety in comparison with other games.
So let me tell you this..
If you're looking for some rich narratively, deep combat systemy, brain puzzling turn based RPG ‚Äì you might want to shy away from this one.
But if you're looking for a light hearted, Halloween filled adventure that is sure to make you laugh and have a good time..

Give this one a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198418549470', 'num_games_owned': 1157, 'num_reviews': 654, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1591706327}
review:
Big step up from CQ1 with lots of improvements in graphics, music, and especially retooling the combat mechanics. Kind of a slow, plodding game where a lot of time is spent exploring a level, collecting candy-currency, and collecting the required parts to unlock the next area. Lot of NPCs to do a talk-action, and once and a while they have something funny to say. Story was decent, if a bit bland, with typical Doublefine quality.

Played this game on an ubuntu linux desktop computer with radeon mesa graphic drivers and a gamepad controller. The game requires 1,300MBs of diskspace and a fairly fast computer system. Not a game for everyone, as seen by only 45% of steam owners advancing past the first boss fight. The (improved) combat is still a bit slow and repetitive. Still, I would recommend this game for someone looking for a bit of brainless adventure on a cloudy weekend morning. There is a lot of content here, and I think it is worth the full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043984197', 'num_games_owned': 852, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1590737201}
review:
A fun cute little rpg game. If you liked the first game you'll probably like this one too.

Pros:
-Cute
-Not too grindy besides fights required for the main story, there are respawning mobs if you want to grind but you can beat the main story without fighting any of them.
-Retains the core mechanics and world exploration of the first game that made that game fun/interesting
-The story/world was the biggest highlight for me. The world and characters were so fun that I really wanted to go and interact with everything.

Cons:
-The game is short, about a 7-9 hr run time depending on much of a completionist you are
-Not much added in terms of gameplay when compared to the first game. If anything it is less interesting since all of the costumes use the same timing windows/mechanics for attacks and blocking.
-Once again the movement is still very janky as I got stuck on the environment a lot and even had to restart once because my character got trapped in a spot and couldn't get out.

Overall I loved the story and world, but was left wanting in terms of actual gameplay. The game is short so the lack of gameplay mechanics isn't the worst thing in the world, but it is definitely something that I wish they improved more on and had more creativity with; especially considering that this is a sequel. I think that the game is worth playing for the story/world aspects, but I think that I definitely enjoyed the first more as a game, even if I did play it 5 years ago. Enjoyable game but I expected more from a sequel.

Rating: 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197992880692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1572807584}
review:
the sequel to the first game, though it is not necessary to have played the first one to enjoy this installment. That said, I believe the first one is better so only buy this one if you really liked the first.

What I liked about the first game is that it had one foot in reality and one foot in fantasy high-jinks. You trick or treated in a neighborhood, in a mall, at a festival; all while fighting monsters that only the kids seem to know exist, making it feel like just maybe its all made up, which was charming to me. This 2nd game though? Time travel, trick or treating in a dystopian monster city, evil overlords, and this time adults are involved in the adventure... it lost all connection to reality and I just really did not like that aspect.

That said, still charming overall, and can recommend if you enjoyed the first. But really, play the first one first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198264305879', 'num_games_owned': 93, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 916, 'last_played': 1587852990}
review:
I received this game as a gift from my brother who basically trained me to love games like this since I was young.  So when I got the gift [set] of Costume Quest 1 & 2 I was excited.  I started playing this game pretty shortly after I completed Costume Quest, and the main difference for me was that instead of using a keyboard to play, I used a playstation controller.  Any issue from there on out was a transitional one for me.  I would have to say though that I did like the controller better than the keyboard - which is one's own preference.  Anyway, a couple changes that I'm sure many reviews have covered is the way that you attack the monsters. Instead of a leveled bar with the specified "go" space, it was like a narrowing target which initially appeared to be impossible to successfully attack with.  I am not great at explaining this, so would encourage anyone to see if you can find a youtube video to visually show the differences.  The three main adjectives used to measure your success is AMAZING (which is the best), NICE (which is good, but could've been better), and WHOOPS, which means that you totally mistimed the hit. Not to mention that throughout the game Corvus will provide different attack strategies and teach you them throughout the game, which I'd honestly prefer to learn right from the start. My only other complaint is the Candy Corn, which other than for defensive purposes was utterly useless.  And the constant commentary whenever it was the Candy Corn's turn was annoying as well. One thing that really irritated me though was that one of the achievements for the game (which is the ONLY one I didn't get) was that you had to play all battles throughout the entire game with the Candy Corn present. Which, as I noted earlier, would be frustrating when trying to beat a particularly difficult opponent, but also annoying. However, that didn't mean that I didn't intend to do it.  The problem with that is, on occasion there are a handful (or less) of monsters that kind of pop out of nowhere to battle you, and throughout the game you're switching costumes to utilize the different in-game talents. I had intended on battling every monster with Candy Corn, but got caught unawares by one of those monsters, which totally messed up my chances of actually getting that achievement. Maybe the next play through I will aim for that. 

Other than that, the game is basically the same in terms of game play.  The story is fun, about a dentist whose mother basically tortured him by not letting him go trick or treating or eat candy or anything like that, so as an adult he basically goes overboard with that same expectation and does away with Halloween and acts as an overlord to all, which is kind of hilarious. 

I liked the costumes with this game, as I did with the first costume quest, although I would have to say that I felt that getting the Space costume was a bit anticlimactic because of course it was a pain to get, and I wasn't overly impressed with the costume's general moves or its specials, even when you had the ability to upgrade it. As much as I did love the Egyptian costume, the Wizard costume, and others, I would have to say that I preferred the costumes from Costume Quest [1] . The clown costume with the horn was absolutely obnoxious whenever a battle was won. I saw that if one had bought or pre-ordered costume quest 2 when it initially came out, that the costumes from Costume Quest would be available. I don't know if that's true or not, but I was disappointed that there was no way to get the costumes from the first game. 

I do genuinely hope that a 3rd Costume Quest will come out because I really enjoy this game series!

review:
Costume Quest 2 reprends le sc√©nario l√† o√π s'est arr√™t√© le premier opus.
Le principe est le m√™me : sauver Halloween.

Je l'ai trouv√© un peu moins envo√ªtant que le premier. D'ailleurs je vous conseille de ne pas faire le second opus √† la suite du premier mais de laisser un laps de temps. Les 2 jeux sont assez similaire.

Les nouveaux costumes sont cool, toujours un plaisir de les d√©bloquer.

Le syst√®me de combat a √©t√© revu, on d√©bloque des "comp√©tences" avec les niveaux, utilisation de cartes bonbons farceurs en combat mais tout cela reste assez simple.

Bref, j'ai pris du plaisir √† y jouer et si vous avez aimez le premier opus...Celui-ci vous plaira aussi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198831126223', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1664662388}
review: This game was interesting with some parts feeling like they were too slow and other sections feeling like they went by far too quickly but one thing that is steady about this game is the art work. Nearly every level or location was beautifully created to make me feel immersed while playing through, the sound design was amazing too. All around this game really made me feel like i was playing a Double Fine game, this oozed originality. I really enjoyed the few easter eggs as well, like a call back to costumes of the previous game in one of the levels. The rest of this review will be in comparison to the first Costume Quest: I finished the first CQ and immediately played this one and the switch was very noticeable, mainly the artwork, the characters looked sharper. The fight mechanics changed significantly and, at first, i was against it. I hated the limitations it felt like the game put on me but by halfway through I realized that in comparison to CQ, CQ2 just felt more engaging in the fighting mechanics. The costumes all looked incredible and the addition of types made the gameplay that much more fun, it added a layer of strategy. The opponents felt less cookie cutter this time around and the script felt more imaginative. When i first started this game I didn't think I would like it, it felt very different to the original game, it felt like an adult Double Fine game that played on a cute subject but as I played I saw every little npc and all the interactive work put into this gem and i fell in love with costume quest all over again. Enjoyable game for sure and highly recommended especially if you enjoyed Costume Quest

author: {'steamid': '76561198019270397', 'num_games_owned': 4165, 'num_reviews': 732, 'playtime_forever': 1307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1307, 'last_played': 1584290293}
review:
[h1] Points positifs: [/h1]

- Les graphismes r√©ussis dans le style dessins anim√©s
- L'ambiance sonore parfois l√©g√®re et fluide, parfois rythm√©e et percutante
- Le sc√©nario original et la magie de l'histoire dans l'ensemble
- Les personnages attachants
- Le syst√®me de combats
- La progression des h√©ros
- Les diff√©rents sets d'√©quipements
- Dur√©e de vie acceptable (environ 20h en prenant son temps !)
- Le syst√®me de combats efficace...

[h1] Points n√©gatifs: [/h1]

- ... Mais trop simpliste !
- Un peu r√©p√©titif √† la longue notamment dans le d√©roulement des combats
- Une fin plus longue aurait √©t√© appr√©ci√©e

[h1] En conclusion... [/h1]

Au final, on retiendra surtout de ce Costume Quest 2, un jeu l√©ger et sympathique, qui se laisse jouer en un peu moins d‚Äôune vingtaine d‚Äôheures. Le concept des costumes est vraiment original mais le syst√®me de combat, tr√®s simpliste, ne fournira aucune difficult√© au joueur. Gr√¢ce √† son aspect graphique tourn√© vers la bande dessin√©e occidentale, et √† son ambiance musicale travaill√©e, Costume Quest 2 peut se vanter de s‚Äô√™tre cr√©√© une r√©elle identit√© qui marquera le joueur. Si vous voulez passer quelques heures devant un petit jeu humoristique, qui ne vous prend pas la t√™te, Costume Quest 2 fera parfaitement l‚Äôaffaire.

Costume Quest 2 est une v√©ritable petite douceur. Pris comme tel, il arrive sans mal √† embarquer le joueur dans son univers bon enfant d√©bordant d‚Äôhumour et de p√©rip√©ties gentiment monstrueuses. Loin d‚Äô√™tre un grand jeu exempt de d√©faut, on oublie sans mal ses errances durant les quelques heures qu‚Äôil nous offre. Repus de ses farces, on c√®de volontiers une partie de nos friandises √† Wren et Reynold et on laisse en toute confiance les enfants de 7 √† 12 ans (et les plus grands √©galement !), filles ou gar√ßons, partir avec eux pour l‚Äôaventure d√©guis√©e d‚Äôun soir d‚ÄôHalloween ! Je conseille tout de m√™me d'avoir jou√© au premier Costume Quest pour mieux comprendre cette suite ! >> 16/20

review:
One of the better JRPG turn based combat games in the past decade. If you haven't played both entries in this IP you're seriously missing out.

On another note Costume Quest 2 is much weaker than the original entry. The Halloween themes just aren't as strong, combat doesn't quite feel as tightly balanced, and there is some 3rd act fatigue. That said it's still a great game and worth playing. As it boasts much better exploration, more diverse environments, and world building with a lot more depth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198966848709', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1575069791}
review:
[i]* In this review I'll assume you have played Costume Quest 1 first *[/i]

[h1] Description [/h1]

Costume Quest 2 is a short RPG  that follows the gameplay of the first game : You trick or treat, defeat monsters, gather candy, buy stamps, collect costumes and save the day.  Dr. Orel is the bad guy in this sequence and wants to create a future without costumes and candies by messing with magic and time.

[h1] Review [/h1]

It's a bit more challenging than the first one because you have to eat candy or find a fountain to recover HP and the fights are also more difficult and interesting, but it's basically the same as the Costume Quest 1. So I'm sure that if you've enjoyed the first game, you'll enjoy this one.

If I had to choose one favourite I would definitely choose Costume Quest 1 because it was more related to Halloween than this one and also because everything was new. With Costume Quest 2 there are no more surprises, except for the story line that it's really well written.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994799155', 'num_games_owned': 1534, 'num_reviews': 307, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1575716676}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is not a bad game, but it is a worse game than the original. It takes the 'more' approach to sequels far too literally, by not innovating on the original gameplay loop and just giving you... 'more'.

If my memory serves me, the original game had a fixed number of enemies and no respawning. This has been removed, so now any kind of exploration will result in a number of battles, particularly if you do any backtracking or grinding for XP. The combat system is bare-bones simple to the point of boredom, but you can't just mash though it like a JRPG, because every attack and defence requires a QTE to be effective, requiring you to pay attention at all times. You also no longer get passive buffs from the candy cards, requiring you to sacrifice your turn for an effect, and with one of the game's achievements requiring one of your characters to wear a non-combative costume, you will often find yourself at a disadvantage with optimal gameplay.

The story is fine; I suppose it was a logical progression to the concept, and the world and writing is as charming as ever, but they just HAD to fill it with fluff to pad the time, and that's to its detriment. Go play Costume Quest 1; it's shorter, cleaner, and a more rewarding experience. But if you already have and want more, this is certainly that.

review:
I'm torn on this one.
While I've enyojed the game and I recommend playing it during Halloween season, I feel it failed to capture the charm of the first Costume Quest. The plot doesn't really feel like a Halloween story and the handful of new characters is forgettable.
Sound, graphics and general style are comparable to the previous instalment. The combat is a bit more involved, and I consider it a plus since combat in the first Costume Quest probably was the weakest element.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061442437', 'num_games_owned': 1044, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1574592307}
review:
A super artistic game, albeit quite repetitive in design.

Still worth a buy though, especially since it's one of the rare "Halloween games that aren't horror" out there.

Honestly, kind of want a 3rd Costume Quest at some point, but it probably doesn't sell well enough for Microsoft to justify.

Anyway the costumes are cool and each have a weakness and strength against a certain type of enemy, the wizard is pretty damn amazing. Overall a fun game that you might get bored of the repetition of, but you'll probably enjoy still.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985424862', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1574044311}
review: The game have some combat changes, some fixing the issues I had with Costume Quest 1, but now a new problem have risen which is irritating me - the new stamps. I liked the idea of the old stamps working outside of battle like set buffs or passives, but leaving that aside the game is as good as the first one. I can give the game without a doubt a clean 9/10. I have to say that the new costumes are a bit meh compared to the epic costumes from the first game, but I guess there were some hits and some misses there, depending on people's preferences. Also the game does one of the riskiest things in gaming - playing with time. Even in movies the time travel concept is risky because its soo easy to mess it up or make it boring. I'm glad that the developers took that gamble. This gamble payed off with a great story. I only wonder... will we see costume quest 3 now when the story is all finished?

author: {'steamid': '76561198379244916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1572571324}
review:
So Costume Quest 2 is a game about halloween, costume and. . . .wait what's halloween? I know about how to keep your teeth healthy! 

So basically Costume Quest 2 is a time travel game where halloween is a stake because of Dr. Orel White, a guy who everyones teeth to be healthy. . . 

Story:
So the game has a good, easy and well-devoloped story so that other players can follow along with it! so I'd probably rate the story of the game 8.75 / 10

Art/Design:
The Artwork for this game is also quite good! I'm not artist or expert at art but I'd say the shadings good and the characters moods fit the image for the loading screens. So I'd rate the loading screen artwork and the rest in general about 8.5/10

Graphics:
I'd like to say that they are good but I don't know if it's just to have that cartoon effect or not but I've noticed all the kids have the same face thrown onto each others model. Same for adults (ones related to the story) npc adults that are in the background just look like a potato with a cotton ball on it. although Dr. White seems to have lots of more work put into his face than any other characters face in the entire game. So I'd rate the graphics a 5.85

So It's time for me to give the game my FINAL rating. . .

So i'd rate Costume Quest 2 a 7.7 out of 10 (7.7 / 10)

author: {'steamid': '76561198264274375', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1667950876}
review:
[h1]Here's what you do:[/h1]
Costume Quest 2 is an adventure RPG with turn based combat. This is a direct sequel to Costume Quest (1) and the story this time involves traveling through time to stop an evil dentist who wants to get rid of both Halloween and candy. The 2 main characters are the same twin brother and sister from before who are joined by a couple new characters along the way. The costumes you find along the way are what determine your abilities both in and out of battle. The costumes sort of act as RPG classes and they can be switched freely among your party members when outside of battle. In the field, your player character is able to use the unique field skill of the costume they are wearing, such as the wizard's ability to light up dark places or the clown's horn which is used for various interactions throughout the game. 

[h1]What I like:[/h1]
+ All costumes are unique to this game (no repeats from the first game)
(Well, a few costumes from the first game do exist in this game, but they were a preorder bonus, which I didn't get).
+ The button timing for attacks is more focused on timing and less on reaction by using consistent buttons per party member.
+ The roller skates (faster movement speed) are no longer tied to a costume, so you can use them all the time. 
+ Same as the first game, you can choose to play as the boy or the girl as your lead character at the start of the game. 
+ Same funny sense of humor in the dialog as the first game. 
+ While you don't use the all same party members from the first game, they do play a part in the story.

[h1]What I don't like:[/h1]
- Not all costumes have an ability which can be used outside of battle. 
- While the first location is a spooky Halloween type place, the other locations of the future have less of a Halloween feel to them (for story reasons, of course).
- The first game let you go back for extras at the end of the game, this game saves at a point of no return at the very end of the game where you can't go back.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
I'm not sure if I like the first game more than the second. Costume Quest 2 has a superior battle system. CQ1 has a better connection to Halloween through it's level environments. Both games are about the same in difficulty. The first game is easier to get all the achievements. I still enjoyed this game, so I recommend playing the first game first. If you like that, this game can give you some more of the same and continue the story. If you want to go for all of the achievements, look them up first, one takes the entire game to do and you can mess it up very early (Candy Corn).

[h1]Want a more detailed look? Watch the video review:[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1904318535

author: {'steamid': '76561198090099765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1572684431}
review:
I want to like the game, but the way they changed the combat from the first really dampens the experience.

The reason the first game was good despite being repetitive is that almost every fight takes a minute, 2-4 turns if you know what you are doing and cool super attacks were going off all the time. You could run really any costumes you wanted and the only real skill you needed to make the combat not suck was the timed presses and that was simple

The way they changed it makes the same amount of fights take 3 min, animations are longer, stamps were removed and were replaced with really bad cards that charge per 2 or more battles, it feels like you do less damage in general, supers charge slowly and you almost don't want to use them in case you fight a boss next, and to top it off after every fight you have to go heal at a fountain or go into the next fight with low hp

It works as a system and I bet there are a lot of people that would appreciate the added depth more than I could but all and all its just a more limiting system that doesn't feel as satisfying in the slightest

author: {'steamid': '76561198023490380', 'num_games_owned': 1021, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 840, 'last_played': 1571631639}
review: If you've played the first one you pretty much know what you're getting into. The combat system has changed a bit, going for a more simple, timing-based mechanic, and the creepy treat cards from the first game replacing the battle stamps, but everything else is what you expect from Costume Quest. Same fun, cute story, same lovable characters, same fun in acquiring and using new costumes, same door-to-door trick-or-treating. The environments don't feel as intimate toward Halloween as the original, but they're still a blast to traverse and experience. Overall, you'll most definitely enjoy this game as well if you did the first, and there's still no game that captures Halloween quite like this and the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000722022', 'num_games_owned': 4291, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1566829120}
review: If you played the first one you'll know whether or not you'll like this since it's mostly the same game with a little more depth and better graphics. If you haven't played the first one and for some reason want to play this one first, it's basically a simple turned based RPG, similar to classic Final Fantasy JRPGs but simplified, probably for a younger audience, but as an adult I still enjoyed the game overall. It has good writing and it's nice to play a simple RPG once in a while instead of a 100 hour monster. The better graphics seem to have made this a poorly optimized game though, I only had to reduce the SSAA from 4x to 2x to eliminate the horrible framerate in sections but I don't see how my 1080 TI couldn't run this game at 4K without such horrible slowdown on any level with water. I also HATED the menu system they used for this game, it should have just been a simple menu instead of walking into portals. Well, now I have to replay the damn thing since they had to put an achievement to play with a candy corn the whole game, thanks a lot Double Fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051443870', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1565025081}
review:
More costumes, more questing, same holiday which is somewhat unfortunate. A couple of the issues that bogged down the first game are present yet are not as bad in the repetition department. There are a few new fetch quests for you to do that oddly breaks up the monotony of fighting and collecting candy that made up the first game.

If you liked the first game, you will definitely love this as it improves a lot on story and combat, especially the combat which makes fights feel more balanced and that skill plays a significant role more so once you get the ability to counter. As well as that, each costume provides some tactical play though that's stretching it a bit since you have to guess who you're going up against for the Bonus / Weakness setups that you could only figure out after the battle.

The world is a little blander and bleaker than the previous title, but overall it feels much better to look at while you're going about trick-or-treating. Music is the same with no real changes that I can tell immediately yet the battle arenas are so much better to fight in. Alongside that, each punch just feels SOOO rewarding when you get an Amazing and even a double Amazing. There is a lot of power in each turn that sends a shiver down your spine.

Overall, I had much more fun with this and with a little more polish this would definitely be a Game of the Year for me since it's fun, colorful, and still retains its uniqueness in focusing around the most beloved Holiday.

author: {'steamid': '76561198410169156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 485, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555, 'last_played': 1564345288}
review: Just like the first game the fights will get kinda repetitive but there are some improvements too like the starting menu which is awesome and the graphics and the story it self. Overall if you enjoyed the first game you will enjoy this one too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025753757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1430005085}
review: A worthwhile sequel. If you liked the original game then you should play this one too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025754276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1562138035}
review:
Pros:
- Colorful art style. With very Doublefine esc environments. Definitely a step up from the first game.
- Different costumes offer many team builds. 
- The way the costumes interact with the world kinda makes this a metroidvania-ish game.
- Doublefine humor
- Interactive combat. (For a JRPGish experience)

Cons:
- They made the game more difficult than the first, however i feel that they changed too much. It is rather annoying after every 2 battles running back to the fountain to heal up. 
- Each costume has only 1 skill and a auto attack, so not much customization inside of  combat
- Game is only 6 Hrs long. Can be beaten in a single sitting.
-As with the first game, it is mostly a rinse/repeat from town to town. Get the quest, knock on the door, turn in the quest.

Summary:
 I did enjoy my time playing this game, limited as it was. I would definitely recommend this game to people,especially if you enjoyed the first game, and you can find it on sale for like 5 bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093213295', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 1070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1562101092}
review: Right off the bat, I want to say this is not an improvement from the first game. It has its moments, but everything feels stretched: the combat was made more complex, but duller; there are more and bigger maps, but they aren't interesting enough; quests are longer and depend on missable, never again repeated, dialogues. I'm sure people can still like it for the concept, something that I did on my first playthrough, but after playing both games back-to-back, I'm disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113941532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 888, 'last_played': 1667007726}
review: A fun game that has been an enjoyable time with witty writing and fun combat I bought it during the steam summer sale for only 3 dollars with it bundled with the first game and its totally worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048080618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1562504049}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is in the same-but-different sequel category.  The combat has become more involved, with blocks and counters introduced, and the whole feel of it is a touch less halloween like thought the story is still "save Halloween".

All that said, I still find it a fun, quick casual game to play.  It's fun to see what the costume powers are, and the Creepy Treat cards are more important than the last game, so there's more incentive to collect them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335543681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1514544484}

author: {'steamid': '76561198171033130', 'num_games_owned': 456, 'num_reviews': 375, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1559081203}
review:
Little from the original formula has been improved, and a lot has actually devolved. In the end, not very compelling to play considering there's no challenge and every fight is a boring grind.



The original combat system has remained mostly unchanged, with a few tweaks or new features. But nothing that fundamentally changes it in any degree. The combat is still void of difficulty however. Playing the first game, by the end it started to get boring when the novelty wore off and it became obvious there's zero challenge or risk of failure. So going into this game with that knowledge, there's virtually no sense of purpose to keep playing when the novelty of the combat has long worn off and it's clear every fight is just you pushing buttons. You couldn't lose unless you literally tried. It is understandable to keep the game easy for the sake of making it accessible to children, who at this point don't actually need to be pandered too with easy games; but not even having a high difficulty option at all is just shallow design.

Yet the amount of fights in the game has seemingly only increased, while the amount of environmental exploration has decreased. So it's even more grind based then the previous one. The whole thing of using costume abilities to traverse certain obstacles in the environment, still a really generic and uninteresting gameplay mechanic. All it does, is just force the player to change their costume to push one button so they can get past an obstacle. It's not gameplay at all.

The new card system is generally worse then the previous stamp system. The new cards use up a turn and thus it's often simpler to just hit enemies instead of wasting cards on them, since the game isn't difficult enough to justify using the cards to improve your chances of winning. Meanwhile, having the cards on a battle based cooldown just discourages the player from using them at all unless absolutely necessary; and switching cards out when they go on cooldown is just tedious inventory management.

The new costumes feel uninspired. Clowns, dinosaurs, some old american guy with a wig. Not very Halloween spirited outfits and they just make it feel like the developers ran out of ideas. Having the Candy Corn costume unable to actually perform actions is boring and makes the early game extremely slow until you unlock a new costume to replace it with; a costume that actually can perform actions.

The new storyline is an overly wacky, un-Halloween themed time travel thing that just feels like a really bad attempt to artificially make the story more interesting. The story isn't very compelling especially because it's just a generic cartoon whatever type of plot; and while the writing is sometimes funny it's not usually entertaining to read. The new areas are similarly uninspired and don't really feel like very Halloween themed place to be or in general, they don't feel like logical or cozy places to be Trick-or-Treating.

The only distinct improvement in this whole game, is the speed boost shoes are no longer costume specific.


The novelty of the original game was a huge part of what made in enjoyable. The combat wasn't especially interesting but at least it was neat for awhile, the sometimes funny writing and classic Halloween cartoon plot made it feel a lot like an old school Halloween special turned into a game. This feels exactly like a bad sequel to an old school Halloween special, where all the new ideas just aren't very interesting and a lot of the original charm has worn off or been replaced by something less charming.

To a degree it highlights how fragile the quality of the original game was, as a novelty. Trying to sell that novelty a second time would of been questionable enough without clearly losing inspiration in the process. 

As a whole it's a shallowly designed game with a very shallowly written story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026462055', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1558922972}
review: Excellent sequel - it may actually be an improvement over the original on the story, but the default controls for keyboard are pretty awkward (in particular, they ask a lot of your left pinky).  Either remap the controls ASAP or use a controller - it definitely feels like this game was built for a controller.  The combat system is a little smoother than the original - every costume has the same controls rather than different patterns - but it has something of a learning curve, and unlike the first game, health and specials don't reset after every battle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981001186', 'num_games_owned': 2078, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1554647305}
review:
A fun linear and rather short RPG with turn-based combat about kids saving Halloween. If you've played the first one, you essentially know what's coming at you. You'll visit a few hubs, fulfilling quests and acquiring new costumes that offer new ways to reach certain points in the game world as well as new combat abilities. 
Combat is fun, but never really difficult and the story is nothing spectacular, but charming and'll occasionally get a smile out of you - unless you're dead inside of course.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022824643', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1553421437}
review:
gioco molto divertente, estremamente consigliato.

a differenza del primo ci hanno provato a rendere i combattimenti meno noiosi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031718366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1552802665}
review: Fun Halloween styled RPG with a cute story and characters. Has a variety of "classes" so things don't get too boring. They switched up the battle system quite a bit from the first game which i was not a fan of. This battle system seemed to be repetitive as opposed to the original, where switching suits meant new style of play. Aside from that really enjoyed the game. Solid game and worth the money, would recommend. Can't wait for the TV Series!

author: {'steamid': '76561198126921407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1553018119}
review: Still super cute and halloweeny and this time ,we see why things happened but still fun as heck totally collect everything and good luck on the bosses oof!

author: {'steamid': '76561198928685566', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1572629845}
review:
Just like the original gem, this game had true heart and soul put into it. The combat style was different to the original and I wasn't a big fan of it but it did not ruin anyhting for me. I've seen reviews saying this is a repeat of the first game, while the gameplay style is the same, it's a totally new story with old places, yes, but also some new places. The time travelling is weird and all but you'll get used to it. Honestly this game was enjoyable and it was a great sequel and did a lot well.
This game ended the series quite well and made things come to a close although weird things with timelines, so I'm okay with the end. However if a Costume Quest 3 were to come and be a final game I would not complain as Iove this and the original.
Much love <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198162381766', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 547, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1550182576}
review: Questo seguito riparte da dove si era fermato il dlc del primo che il dlc a sua volta partiva dopo aver terminato il titolo principale. Le migliorie di questo seguito si possono notare nella grafica specialmente l'acqua che riflette i protagonisti, nel combattimento ora piu dinamico con un solo pulsante che fa tutto sia attacco che difesa per singolo membro del gruppo. Y per il primo X per il secondo e infine A per il terzo membro del party. Lievemente pi√π complesso riguardo il completamento delle missioni, ma per il resto, la formula non cambia con il fare dolcetto e scherzetto nelle case andando a zonzo nel tempo tra passato, presente e futuro per evitare che halloween venga cancellato. Lo consiglio a chi si √® divertito con il primo capitolo e vuole vedere nuove trasformazioni. Vale sia a prezzo pieno che scontato. Non lo consiglio per chi si affaccia subito a questo titolo anziche fare il primo, per via di spoiler dei vari personaggi che si incontrano in questo seguito a tutti i sensi del primo gioco. Un'ultima cosa, qui il salvataggio avviene solo ogni volta che bevete dalla fontana o che finite una missione. Non ci sono opzioni di salvataggio.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043451094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1435031467}

author: {'steamid': '76561198247279800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1544019308}
review:
I was absolutely crazy about the first game and have definitely labeled it one of my permanent favorites (just check my review for that one, if you think I'm exaggerating). That makes the review I'm about to give this one....well, a whole lot harder. <:{

While I would still recommend people try this game, Costume Quest 2 took away or changed some of the key features that made Costume Quest 1 so enjoyable. Firstly, Costume Quest 1 had these epic battle animations and camera angles that made combat super satisfying and interesting. Battle stamps equipped to your characters granted a whole slew of different passive effects or usable/triggerable abilities. In this one, the diversity of combat camera angles is almost completely gone, and the combat animations are all toned down in general epicness and have far more muted colors. Combine this with a change in how customizable abilities work (which I'll talk about in a second), and you've got a new combat system that both feels and looks boring. I found myself actively avoiding the enemies because the new combat system felt like a chore, whereas in the first game I didn't skip a single battle and actively combed and re-combed over each map in search of any baddies that I might have missed, because it was just so fun to destroy them in satisfying action-packed combat.

Now the customizable combat abilities. The change in how these work between the first game and this one is a majorly contributing culprit to why the combat is no longer fun. Battle Stamps from the first game have been replaced by reusable Creepy Treat Cards. In the first Costume Quest, you would equip one unique Battle Stamp on each of your characters to grant them various abilities, passive or otherwise; maybe one to make a character's attacks do lingering poison damage, or maybe one that grants them an additional special ability that will stun an enemy for one turn, etc. In this one, you just equip a total of three cards that any of your characters can use. The catch is that once a card is used, you can't use it again for a set number of BATTLES. That's right, entire BATTLES. In Costume Quest 1, stamps that granted passive abilities worked their magic every single turn and ones that granted additional abilities were USABLE every turn (or for special charge-up abilities, they were usable every time your special meter filled). This new system SEVERELY limits your combat versatility and customization, and largely forces you to just use your costumes regular abilities (which, combined with tedious, disinteresting combat, makes it even harder to enjoy.) To make matters worse, I am SICK TOO LITERAL DEATH of [spoiler] super hero stuff [/spoiler]. So the fact that [spoiler] that's your first costume in the game [/spoiler] was disheartening for me personally.

Not all is bad, though. Some of the maps still hold all of the magical enchanting lighting and childhood nostalgic feel that the maps from the first game did (there's a reason not all of the maps do; the lacking ones are that way intentionally, but I can't say why without spoilers). The minion dialogue I've encountered thus far (I've made it to Auburn Pines) is flat and disinteresting, but the dialogue for the Candy Corn costume FAAAAR makes up for it. You'll quickly see what I mean if you play, lol.

CQ2 is peppered with other little things that fall flat in comparison to the first game (and sometimes just in general), but it's just fun enough that I'm going to keep playing it and recommend it to others. And also because it's riding the high of fun and wonderful excitement I got from literally just finishing Costume Quest 1 (which I highly, highly encourage you to play before even touching this one, one because you'll need its inspiration to get through this second game and also because this game won't make any sense without having played the first one).

author: {'steamid': '76561198084561752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1540922641}
review: The combat system is definitively worse than before and it doesn't show to many changes from the previous chapter, but hey, I like the story and the costumes, you have to play it during Halloween period!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025393549', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1604293880}
review: A perfect sequel. It expands on the original in gameplay, story, and overall look and polish. Battles are more substantial now and animations make the attacks feel great to use. It has the same charm and funny dialogue from the first game that keeps you playing. Definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977850703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1541049300}
review: This has Double Fine's brand of humor all over it. Cute and stylized, it's a fun way to throw 6 hours into a game. Combat and encounters are repetitive but that's not really the point here. Loved the story development around candy as a resource, blessing and curse. Makes me remember Halloween as a kid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047962206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1477610302}

review:
N√£o est√° entre os meus rpgs favoritos, mas n√£o deixa de ser um jogo decente, por√©m:
- Quando acaba a batalha, o hp n√£o √© restaurado e como voc√™ geralmente perde muita energia, √© preciso procurar uma fonte para restaurar o grupo e isso √© repetido exaustivemente durante o jogo, ou seja, batalha, fonte, batalha, fonte, batalha, fonte ....... e isso √© chato pra kacete sendo o pior defeito do jogo.
- A ideia dos cartas √© legal, mas n√£o deveriam ter cooldown porque demora tanto tempo para recarregar que voc√™ acaba nem usando (usei basicamente apenas 1 vez cada para pegar uma das conquistas).
- Deveria ser possivel trocar de costume durante as batalhas porque como elas tamb√©m s√£o usadas para executar a√ß√µes nas fases, muitas vezes voc√™ entra em batalha com alguma que n√£o √© indicada para aquela situa√ß√£o.
Resumindo, serve para passar o tempo, mas recomendo apenas na promo√ß√£o porque √© bem curtinho e f√°cil, d√° para platinar tranquilo em 10 hrs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047524156', 'num_games_owned': 672, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 1058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1058, 'last_played': 1540115445}
review: Perfect sequel. Lots of improvements on the original game while keeping the same style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034797533', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1540022692}
review: You just need Costume Quest 1 + DLC and you're good to go. I don't like the setting of 3/4 of the second one. The game is not a bad game. It made the gameplay a bit more interesting (still not challenging) but bottom line is not as interesting as the first game. So is a no, I don't recommend it even if you like the franchise. I recommend replaying the first game instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058706108', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1539566116}
review: A nice, straightforward turn based RPG for the spooky season. Never too challenging, fun art style, and "blow air out of your nose" kind of funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205074691', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1525586542}
review: Great follow for the Costume Quest saga, play the original before CQ2 because it sets up the story and characters for this game. The first was a bit better but not in a huge way, this game was still funny, cute and a great overall experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 9876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7170, 'last_played': 1539794280}
review: Costume Quest 2 managed to be even more ridiculous as well as cute as its predecessor. The humour isn't always the greatest, but it is a very well designed RPG game about halloween. Aimed at a younger audience. Think South Park without any expletives and without any mature content whatsoever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079602090', 'num_games_owned': 1934, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1476139157}
review: It's short and very casual turn-based combat with some exploration and puzzles. Good for people not looking for a challenge who would enjoy a cute and comedic halloween-themed adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965215862', 'num_games_owned': 4215, 'num_reviews': 523, 'playtime_forever': 918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1539219672}
review:
[h1]üéÆ [u]Costume Quest 2[/u] üéÆ[/h1]

Das Sequel des erfolgreichen [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/115100/Costume_Quest/?curator_clanid=32139821]ersten Teils[/url] von [url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/doublefine?snr=1_5_9__creator-home-product-page]Double Fine[/url]. Nicht unbedingt besser, sondern anders. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Wer ist der gr√∂√üte Feind von S√º√üigkeiten? Genau: Der Zahnarzt! So ist dieser im zweiten Teil unser Gegner. Die Protagonisten des ersten Teils sind auch dieses Mal wieder am Start und es gibt einige √Ñnderungen im Vergleich zum Vorg√§nger. Die lustigen und humorvollen Dialoge blieben hingegen, ganz wie man es vom Entwickler gewohnt ist, erhalten. 

Als wesentliche Ver√§nderung erachte ich das Kampfsystem. Im ersten Teil simpel und einfach gehalten, erscheint es mir nun unn√∂tig kompliziert. Jeder Charakter hat eine Zahl von 1-3, die Spezialf√§higkeiten oder andere Auswahlm√∂glichkeiten sowie der Fokus welcher Gegner attackiert wird, sind per WASD zu bestimmen. 

Der ausgeteilte Schaden scheint in Relation auch gesunken zu sein, sodass K√§mpfe jetzt gef√ºhlt l√§nger dauern. Erlittener Schaden bleibt im Anschluss an K√§mpfe erhalten und man muss sich heilen. Daf√ºr kann man jetzt quasi auch Gegner "farmen". Das raubt dem Ganzen den Charme des Vorg√§ngers. 

S√º√üigkeiten k√∂nnen nach wie vor f√ºr Karten ausgegeben werden, deren Verwendung ist jedoch jetzt leicht ver√§ndert. Ansonsten k√∂nnen die Kost√ºme aufgewertet werden. Hier ist es √§u√üerst positiv, dass die Kost√ºme im zweiten Teil weitestgehend andere als aus dem ersten Teil sind. Die F√§higkeiten hat man nat√ºrlich angepasst und passen entsprechend.

[b]Grafik & Sound[/b]

Grafisch hat man am Altbew√§hrten festgehalten, genauso bei der musikalischen Umrahmung. Es bleibt niedlich und knuffig, mit typischem Setting w√§hrend Halloween. Die Kameraperspektive bleibt nach wie vor ab und an hinderlich. Gef√ºhlt eher h√§ufiger als in Teil 1. Musikalisch passt das Ganze, wie schon erw√§hnt, auch weiterhin. F√ºr die Errungenschaften sollte man sich vorab informieren, denn ich musste das Spiel einmal komplett neu starten. 

[b]Fazit[/b]

Das Spiel ist in meinen Augen nicht mehr so charmant und auch die Nutzerreviews best√§tigen meinen Eindruck. W√§hrend Costume Quest 1 noch 94% positive Bewertungen aufweist, sind es hier "nur" 85%. Ich empfehle den Kauf von Teil 2 daher mit Vorbehalt und empfehle einen Sale (z.B. zu Halloween) oder gleich den Griff zum [url=https://store.steampowered.com/sub/53813/]Bundle[/url]. Es ist jedoch ein gutes Spiel, k√∂nnte allerdings f√ºr Spieler von Teil 1 zu Entt√§uschungen f√ºhren!
[i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198095905694', 'num_games_owned': 1380, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1532726454}

author: {'steamid': '76561198346930703', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1532291378}
review: I did enjoy this game, and I did like a lot of the new features, such as the upgradeable costumes and creepy treat cards for battles  - HOWEVER I just didn't enjoy playing it as much as the original, no matter how much I tried.  That being said I would still definately recommend it, and it works out incredibly cheap if you buy both games in the bundle on sale like I did - more money to spend on candy that way! :) :hardcandy

author: {'steamid': '76561198825010795', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1532359238}
review:
At first it seems like a cool game and all those positive reviews makes it even more interesting. But I've been playing the first episode for almost 2 hours and nothing is happening! I think they tried to create something like Money Island series but apparently it's not going to happen.

- It's childish, I mean it's REALLY childish I'm speaking as a cartoon type PG7 games fan.
- Combats are way too repetetive, nothing strategical here
- I'm literally sick of those pre-combat scenes
- Soundtracks are soooo boring

This game is not for people who are looking for some challenge, some hard puzzles etc. But you can easily let your kid play this game without worrying. Still, I think it's neither entertaining nor educational. It's just a "safe" game for those 10 year olds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137667602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1531890184}
review:
To preface: I love the first Costume Quest. I play it every fall. It's just one of those feel good Halloween season games for me, and it never gets old.

This one? Eh, I'm sad to say, I was looking forward to it being over. It borrows a lot from the original game, including maps, quests, and character models. In fact, there is very little that's actually original in this game, and the things that are original are pretty uninspired, tbh. The music was pretty boring and lackluster too, and I found myself longing for the old battle theme a lot. Or at least for something with a little more oomph, you know? 

They changed up some of the core game mechanics and I can't really say it was for the better. You liked being auto-healed after every fight in the first game? Well, too bad! Now you have to backtrack to a heart fountain to heal after just about every battle! It's every bit as annoying as it sounds. Battle stamps are no more, replaced with creepy cards that are a one-use kind of thing and can't be used again until their cooldown (which is usually anywhere from 1-3 battles). It's not too horrible, so long as you use them wisely. There are some pretty awesome cards in the mix, and they can come in quite handy in a pinch. A lot of the costumes were kind of lame and left me disappointing, but that's just my opinion. 

All-in-all, it just felt like a half-assed rehash of the first game, and that's a huge bummer! I really wanted to love this game, but it really just kinda... lacked the charm and fun of the first game. It's an easy 100% if you're into achievements, and that's about it.

Graphiquement c'est tr√®s agr√©able, et le gameplay est sympa : fouiner les recoins de la map pour terminer les qu√™tes, compl√©ter les costumes et d√©couvrir les sp√©cificit√©s de chaque costume lors des combats. author: {'steamid': '76561197978926591', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1529132662}
review:
Now I was a fan of the first Costume Quest so when I saw the second one was on sale I jumped at the chance of getting back into the fun universe of costumed kids kicking butt. Sadly, much like adults growing up and not being able to trick or treat this game did not get better.

While the writing is decent it felt surprisingly derivative of the first. I think a large issue of that may be due to the fact that the second game is a lot more linear than the first. While the second one really had you choosing to go out of your way and explore the world for secret costumes, this one hands you every costume along the storyline. I get that these games are short but this one made me finish the game going "wait, thats it?" It really felt more like a small DLC of the first and calling it a second game really feels false. Much like getting crummy fast food, this game is over in a couple of bites and really makes you crave something with more sustenance.

7.0/10.0

author: {'steamid': '76561198262626587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 373, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1576870010}
review:
What is Costume Quest 2 ?

Costume quest 2 is a cute adventure game set during halloween, its fun and full of personality, perfect for fans of turn-based combat, here the main characters are kids and they transform into the costumes they are wearing, you can control up to 3 kids in your party and theres different costumes to use, I never expected a sequel to the first one and while I think the first one is better and this one is shorter than it should have been (It isn't one of those sequels who goes big but instead play safe) It was still a surprise to me to know that a game I loved received a sequel I never expected, but while I prefer the first, having more of the same of something I really liked is not a bad thing, so I recommend both this game and the first one for everyone, especially fans of the adventure genre mixed with turn-based combat, those two are really good games.

review: You're probably not looking at this unless you played the original Costume Quest and if you liked the original, you'll probably like this one too. The story is great. The combat is turn based and, well, it works. There's not much to it, it's very basic. Overall, the game is a pretty cute run through a kid's Halloween story. If you enjoyed the first one, give this one a go. It really feels like more of the same with a different story so that should be pretty telling if you should even look at this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086666257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1523154431}
review:
Lovely new settings and music with a few npc's that were charming. Overall it was about as addicting as the first as far as story line went. However when it came to enemies and costumes... it was lacking in the creativity department. I'd so wished to see a brand new set of enemies but... it was very much just more of the same. There were roughly four new enemies. All of which were very plain or simplistic. Two of which made no sense whatsoever as to why they even existed... namely the random moles and snails scattered about. Why are they so big... and why are they on the enemy's side? They even look innocent at first glance.

Then there were the costumes... I was excited at the concept of a few of them but... when they were finally put together? Another batch of disappointment. I think I liked only one of the outfits on the avatars, but when it came to combat..? They were all so unintimidating. In the first game they would always turn out to be so epic, especially with their special moves but... all of these just felt purely like jokes. I understand wanting to be comedic but... I also always thought that part of the game was to give a visual representitive of how children can be strong too. That they can be whatever they want to be. Such is one of the reasons for Halloween after all. (It's even mentioned in game several times if I recall correctly.) I feel more could have been done to show this. If needed be you could have made less costumes but put more thought and time into them. That would be my personal preference though.

All in all, I would say the original Costume Quest game is preferable to this. If you loved the original... you'll probably be as saddened as I am by the content of this game. However if you have too much extra time on your hands and need a game that you don't have to put much thought into this is your game. (Aside from the acquisition of the last costume... which is more effort than it is worth. So much so I would toss it into a black hole at risk of being sucked in myself.)

review:

But i wasnt feeling the battle system and the battles are tougher now so u have to pull your restraints into bold furious
good caption and timing that drips into satisfaction and to beat any boss from piling achievements!

I think maybe someday ill be able to finish this monstrosity and see what lays in this creative world what we call costume quest!

But i liked costume quest the first one alot more,even though it was shorter and well defined to be growls of spirited gameplay that is both multiawarding and hopeful for any tale of heart to not abandon what a game is for entertainment,and not a whacky hit pulse test of timing buttons and being so frusturating!

For what i played so far! I give this game a 7.6/10 for trying to be like the first Costume Quest

author: {'steamid': '76561198310540345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1516546521}
review:
It's Final Fantasy for kids!!! 

REALLY cute turn based RPG - perfect for beginners and young gamers. Definately going to introduce my 8yr old niece to this game series!

Search for and create costumes that give the wearer different abilities, then utilise them to make a team appropriately skilled for the sub quest/monsters at hand.

The developers have ironed out the little issues with the first game (e.g. introduced autosaving) which has improved game play.

At my age I should probably be ashamed at how much I enjoyed this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063507166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1516476000}
review:
Costume Quest 2 came as a bit of a let-down for me, sadly. It's a good game, don't get me wrong. But after playing the first game, I had VERY high hopes. Some changes made to the game made perfect sense, whereas some others were very... Odd. The story was a big weakness in my opinion. I'd rather get attached to a group of characters than keep switching out in an already short game. I wanted to like some of them, but for example; the first companion to join your party feels like a random kid that would give you a stamp. Yet he's important to the story, and he joins you for a while.

I fel like the first game had a better idea; where you gradually get party members, and you have a cute interaction as you get them; already making them a bit more endearing. And then you keep them. Meaning there's even more interactions. I just think that recipe was better executed.

The combat -is- mostly better in the second game. The combos add another layer of "intensity", even though it also feels superfluous. The counters are a much better touch. However, making it so every single attack is the exact same "attack meter" was a big turn off for me. I liked having different ones in the first game, it made it less repetitive.

The removal of battle stamps felt like a huge waste to me. It removed a BIG deal of depth from the game, and I feel it was felt in the difficulty of the game. In fact; there's an achievement to beat the game having the Candy Corn costume in your party the entire time; it doesn't do any damage. That alone would be unbelievably hard if not impossible in the first game. Mostly because of the last boss, but still.

Allowing you to use rollerskates the entire time was a definite plus. You don't feel restricted to the robot if you want to be faster, unlike in the first game.

The costumes were also all perfectly fine, same for the sidequests. It felt like there was a lot more back-and-forth in this game than in the first one, which isn't super fun but eh... Not a deal-breaker.

I was kinda put off by how short the game was. The first one was short but this one was even shorter, which came as a shock to me.

Making some costumes better against certain types of enemies and whatnot... I... I didn't like that. It's like... A layer of depth this game doesn't need. I honestly ignored that part of the game completely and I did perfectly fine. It's just not necessary, and kind of an eyesore when you start seeing 2 numbers instead of just your damage while fighting. On top of the combos it kinda just looks like screen clutter to me.

I definitely prefered the "random button" aspect of the combat in the first game, on top of having a different attack gauge. All of it made it for a much more fun and interesting combat in my opinion.

All in all, when I think of the good things this game has done compared to the bad ones, I'd say... This is a 7/10. If there's a 3rd game and we can expect things like... 10hrs of gameplay, actually interesting characters, maybe more costumes, more puzzley areas, more interesting combat, and a more engaging story, I could see myself somehow loving it more than the first game, which I promise you is no easy feat.

This is still worth playing. But I do feel it was a downgrade from the first game. I don't think Costume Quest needs to be flashy. Or epic. It just needs to feel like a Halloween night gone wrong and you and your friends do everything in your power to fix it. This just felt like it tried too hard to be an epic adventure. Just make it a fun one. I'd say keep the charm the first game delivered. You can tell the graphics were improved in this game and I honestly didn't like the art better, because the atmosphere felt so much colder. Less full of life; vibrant. I would LOVE for a 3rd game to make the 2nd game the odd one out by making it the only "good" game in a series of great games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114686861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1516232552}

review:

Les recuerdo es un genero RPG de rol por turnos en primera este tiene un publico peque√±o porque muchos se aburren de tantas batallas segundo por los graficos caricaturezcos piensan que va dirigido a ni√±os de 10-13 a√±os pero no, este juego es tan complejo como para entretener al adulto y fresco y tan sencillo para mantener al ni√±o atrapado queriendo saber que sucede en la historia asi que lo que ocurre es que juegan el costume quest 1 y les gusta pero al jugar el 2 sienten mas de lo mismo pues obvio son RPG siempre seran lo mismo lo bueno que este juego agrega varias cosas nuevas,misiones,logros,enemigos etc para mantenerlo fresco durante sus casi 12 horas de duracion el juego mejora en todo aspecto imaginable y le mete un poco mas de dificultad a la cosa y un sistema de batallas aun mas complejo con counter,evasion,guardia etc el juego es lo que merecia el 1 un buen sucesor pero si no te gustan los RPG mejor ignoralo y juega otro he llegado a ver gente diciendo que final fantasy 9 era basura solo porque no era fan de los RPG por turnos solo eso una nota merecida por mejorar muchas cosas respecto al 1 le doy 8.8/10 jamas imagine que un juego que jamas habia jugado me hubiese terminado enganchando

author: {'steamid': '76561197996241018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1514314265}
review:
I really loved the first Costume Quest because it was simple yet fun. It had a lot of atmosphere, a cute humor and was just generally loveable. 

Costume Quest 2 kept some of those aspects, like the free roaming in small areas, where you can do some fun side quests and the tongue-in-cheek dialogues. However, that's pretty much it.

The best way to describe this sequel is "frustrating and dull". The game loves to play with the players patience. That starts with the fact that everytime you want to access the main menu, you'll have to go through credits and an animation and continues when you can't skip a cutscene. 
The worst offender however is the new fighting system. First of all, all the costumes play the same (and you need much longer to acquire new ones). Even the small variation when it comes to how to execute an attack was taken out of the game. That makes the fights pretty stale, you ALWAYS press the same buttons. Apart from that, the new technique in which you initate your attacks feels weird - it's hard to understand how to actually execute "amazing" attacks.

The Halloween-card system was changed aswell. Instead of giving each of your character either an additonal attack or a cool passive, you can only use those cards once. That brings some more variation to the fights, but makes the cards less reliable aswell. 

Then, there is this stupid new well-system, which forces you to refill your health after each fight. If you don't do that, your characters will have decreased health the next time you get into a fight - UNLESS they died in the last battle. So you're pretty much punished for surviving fights. This can be super frustrating when you enter a bossfight with a big disadvantage, lose and then have to watch the whole cutscene again (cause you can't skip it). 

The level-design isn't very exciting aswell. Thinking of the great Grubbins On Ice DLC for CQ1, that brought some variation to the areas, Costume Quest 2 feels like a rehash of the first game with muddy textures. The side-quest are pretty much the same ones aswell.

in conclusion, the sequel does not do justice to the first game and comes across pretty lackluster. Neither the story nor the gameplay are actually engaging and most of the "improvements" feel gimmick-y.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041636869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 1741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1741, 'last_played': 1512583379}
review:
A fun RPG set during Halloween in three different time periods. If you‚Äôve played the first one, you know what to expect here. If you haven‚Äôt played the first one, you can grab both of them in a set for a really low price. 

The combat is more complicated with cards that need to be switched out every time they are used, as well as timed attacks and blocks. You can heal between fights by eating candy, but that means you won‚Äôt have enough to buy what you want when they are first available. To save candy, you have to run back to the fountain after every fight, which is the most annoying part of the game. That said, it is a minor annoyance.
