author: {'steamid': '76561198052983021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 492, 'last_played': 1510453465}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is more Halloween JRPG goodness from the fine folks at Double Fine.  The turn based battles are fun if a bit shallow.  The timed based attacks and blocks keep you on your toes and the super attacks and ability cards add a bit of strategy to the battle.  There are plenty of costumes that allow you to change character class and each costume makes the battle a little different, mostly due to the unique super attack for that class.  Plus they look cool in an 80ies cartoon sort of way.  The neighborhood is just as much fun to explore as last time, and some of the costumes open up new avenues of exploration with their abilities.  For example if that alley is too dark to see then light the way with your wizard wand and find that missing costume piece or rare creepy treat card.  

There are only a few settings to explore this time thru but each one is chock full of atmosphere with plenty of quirky characters to talk to and lots of candy to find.  The lack of enemy variety hurts Costume Quest 2 but there are a few interesting boss battles and the story, atmosphere and exploration is really the calling card of the series anyway.  Costume Quest 2 is not the evolution of the series that I hoped for, but it‚Äôs still a blast to play on a crisp fall night with some hot cider and a bowl of candy corn.  

Costume Quest 2, like the original, works best as a light JRPG and an ode to Halloween for the kid in all of us.  It‚Äôs still more treat than trick, but with mini fun sized candy bars instead of the full size ones.  Happy Trick or Treating and don‚Äôt forget to floss afterwards!

author: {'steamid': '76561198212553021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1508991275}
review:
If you enjoyed the first, you'll enjoy this one as well! I will say that I somewhat preferred the original, but mainly because it stuck more steadfastly to the "Halloween" theme. Don't get me wrong; this is a delightful sequel and every bit as creative as the first, and perhaps even more unique. Whichever you prefer will likely come down to whether you prefer the original's spooky/Halloween vibe or this one's time-traveling theme.

I would definitely play a Costume Quest 3. For what it is worth though, I much preferred Costume Quest 1's battle stamps to 2's creepy treat cards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052125808', 'num_games_owned': 1125, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1509805494}
review:
Wren und Reynold haben gedacht, dass sie nach ihrem ersten Intermezzo mit den Grubbins ein wenig Ruhe reinbekommen, aber damit haben sie komplett falsch gelegen: Der Zahnarzt Dr. med. dent. Orel White setzt seinen Plan um, alle S√ºssigkeiten zu verbannen, um eine Welt der perfekten Zahnhygiene zu erschaffen, der aufgrund eines MacGuffins und eines Zeitzauberers Erfolg zu haben scheint. Nun liegt es am Geschwisterpaar, die althergebrachte Ordnung wiederherzustellen und den Karies zur√ºck zu bringen.

So viel zur Handlung. Costume Quest 2 ist eine direkte Fortsetzung zum Erstling und setzt direkt da an, wo der erste Teil sein Ende gefunden hat. Es ist nicht zwingend notwendig, den Vorg√§nger gespielt zu haben, aber empfehlenswert ist es alle Male, da man sonst mit einigen Figuren √ºberhaupt nichts anfangen kann.

Im Mittelpunkt stehen erneut die Kost√ºme und das simple, aber √ºberaus charmante Kampfsystem, das im Vergleich zum ersten Teil ein wenig angepasst wurde: So hat jetzt jeder Charakter eine festgelegte Taste, die sowohl f√ºr die Verteidigung, als auch f√ºr den Angriff verwendet wird, was einiges an Frust erspart und den Schwerpunkt auf den Rhythmus legt, den man braucht, um m√∂glichst effektiv anzugreifen oder zu verteidigen.

Die Kampfmarken des Erstlings ist ebenfalls der Schere zum Opfer gefallen und wurde durch ein Kartensystem ersetzt. Dieses Mal sammelt man Karten und nutzt die teilweise sinnlosen oder √ºbertrieben Effekte in den K√§mpfen, um sich einen Vorteil zu verschaffen (Oder einen Nachteil - warum man einen Kampf in doppelter Geschwindigkeit spielen will, erschlie√üt sich mir einfach nicht.). Mir pers√∂nlich hat das Markensystem besser gefallen, auch wenn es nur passive Effekte waren, denn durch die Karten kommt nicht gerade frischer Wind ins Geschehen. Daf√ºr sind die Abklingzeiten einiger Karten viel zu lang und manchmal steuert man einige K√§mpfe ohne brauchbare Karten durch die Gegend.

Die Selbstheilungsmechanik des ersten Teils wurde ebenfalls ver√§ndert: Dieses Mal wird man am Ende des Kampfes nicht wieder auf 100% Leben hochgeheilt, sondern muss einen Brunnen suchen oder S√ºssigkeiten naschen, um die eigene Gesundheit wiederherzustellen. Das ist - in meinen Augen - komplett √ºberfl√ºssig. S√ºssigkeiten hat man immer in H√ºlle und F√ºlle und es gibt keinen Grund, einen Brunnen anzusteuern. Da h√§tte Double Fine es auch dabei belassen k√∂nnen, dass man am Ende jedes Kampfes geheilt wird, anstatt damit Tiefe vorzugaukeln, die nicht gegeben ist.

Grafisch hat sich nicht sonderlich viel getan. Nat√ºrlich, die Grafik schaut etwas runder aus als im ersten Teil, aber da Costume Quest kein grafisch anspruchsvoller Titel ist, lassen sich die Unterschiede nur mit der Lupe erkennen. Das ist aber nichts Schlechtes, denn das Spiel lebt von seinem Cartoonstil und dem charmanten Figurendesign.

Im Gro√üen und Ganzen hat Double Fine mit diesem Titel viel richtig gemacht: Die meisten √Ñnderungen sind Quality of Life-Anpassungen, so kann man z.B. jetzt den Dash benutzen, ohne das Roboterkost√ºm zu tragen, und das Kampfsystem geht deutlich besser von der Hand, aber trotzdem gibts Dinge, die mir √ºbel aufsto√üen: Durch das dystopische Weltbild geht sehr, sehr viel Charme verloren. Im ersten Teil kam ich mir vor, als w√ºrde ich eine Gruppe Kinder durch die Nachbarschaft begleiten und S√º√ües oder Saures spielen, wobei die Fantasie der Kinder aus den Kost√ºmen Superhelden uswpp geformt hat. Das ist im zweiten Teil nur noch im Startgebiet der Fall. Danach verliert sich das Spiel ein wenig zu sehr in seiner dystopischen Fantasie und der Zeitreiseproblematik und nimmt den ganzen Quark, der um die Kinder herum passiert, viel zu ernst. Dadurch ist die Welt nur mit wenigen Charakteren bev√∂lkert, was ich sehr schade finde, da mir im ersten Teil die Interaktionen zwischen den Kindern die gr√∂√üte Freude bereitet haben. Die Verspieltheit ist irgendwo fl√∂ten gegangen und jetzt stehen die Kleinen zwischen zu vielen Erwachsenen herum, die sie von A nach B schicken. Schade!

Trotzdem: Costume Quest 2 ist ein starkes Spiel und hat mich w√§hrend meiner gesamten Spielzeit sehr gut unterhalten. Im Direktvergleich w√ºrde ich den Erstling eher empfehlen als den zweiten Teil, aber das w√§re Korinthenkackerei. Beide Spiele sind gut und man kann sie sorglos einpacken, um ein paar Stunden in eine einfachere Zeit abtauchen, als man zum Fasching mit seinen Freunden um die H√§user gezogen ist, um alte Leute um S√ºssigkeiten anzubetteln.

Euh, je voudrais savoir quel est l'int√©r√™t de devoir courir apr√®s les fontaines pour refaire le plein de vie apr√®s chaque combat, exemple parfait de nouvelle m√©canique aussi inutile que stupide. author: {'steamid': '76561198076061891', 'num_games_owned': 3109, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1506361470}
review:
I like the idea of Costume Quest and the first game. It took the idea from that Buffy episode (and Treehouse of Horror, and probably a lot of other examples) where the characters turn into their costumes and use it as the combat mechanics of an rpg staring kids battling candy stealing goblins. It's was a cute idea, that had charm and was pretty funny in a silly Double Fine way. A pretty good if simple game. Along comes Costume Quest 2 and brings in time travel and a insane dentist and it's just not as good as the first game. 

It's not as funny this time. The costumes are not as creative, and the novelty of the game has worn off after 1 game and a DLC expansion. The combat is somewhat more involved this time, bit it adds a really anoying mechanics with the removal of post battle healing, forcing you to backtrack to a fountain (or to eat some candy). It doesn't add anything, it doesn't make the game any harder and it just makes the battles anoying. 

Overall it's still pretty much the same rpg-lite for kids, but the combat mechanics is still kind of uninteresting and too simple and the storyline is weak, even when you take "it's for kids" into concideration. The first game had charm that made it a pretty good game. This is not bad, but I can't recommend it unless you desperatly need more after playing the first one, and can accept a game that's slightly worse on everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064005074', 'num_games_owned': 1665, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1504389901}
review:
Giocato un sacco di tempo fa il primo capitolo sull'allora PS3 ho finalmente avuto il tempo di provarlo e finirlo.
COMPRALO PERCHE:
-La Storia, seppur risulti molto fanciullesca, pu√≤ appassionare ed incuriosire il giocatore sino a spingerlo quantomeno al compimento dell'avventura non risulta minimamente prolissa puntando molto sul sodo seppur con larga presenza di cliche e davvero ben pochi colpi di scena. Caratterizzazioni dei personaggi divertenti e che non infastidicono per la loro idiozia (piaceranno sicuramente ad un pubblico pi√π giovane)

LASCIALO A STEAM:
-Graficamente il titolo non brilla di certo sotto il lato puramente tecnico regalando un cell-shading molto abbozzato e con davvero poco carisma (decisamente meno del predecessore seppur il balzo di poligoni lo si nota in maniera decisa). Un titolo che da il meglio di se nel lato artistico che risulta sicuramente divertente e caricaturale ma meno geniale del predecessore. Gira anche su un Tostapane quindi lato ottimizzazione e fruibilit√† generale non si pu√≤ che lodarlo purtroppo in generale non risulta essere un comparto cos√¨ SUFFICIENTE da meritare il pollice in su (soprattuto per non aver raggiunto il livello del predecessore)
-Il comparto Sonoro non brilla ne per originalit√† (qualche track presa dal predecessore) ne per variet√† (per tutta l'avventura le tracce saranno quelle 3/4 ripetute all'infinito). Una totale assenza di doppiaggio ed una realizzazione molto abbozzata dei rumori ambientali regalano un comparto sicuramente insufficiente
-Ludicamente parlando il titolo si ispira in maniera molto semplicistica agli RPG con un sistema di crescit√† dei personaggi dovuta all'esperienza post battaglia o missione principale o secondaria che sia. Punto focale del comparto rimangono, cos√¨ come il primo capitolo e cos√¨ come fa intuire il titolo dell'opera, i costumi (circa una decina, ognuno diverso ed ognuno con abilit√† uniche, seppur un paio si somigliano in tutto e per tutto). I nemici risultano a schermo quindi si pu√≤ sempre e comunque decidere se ingaggiare o meno una battaglia seppur il grinding ed il farming siano totalmente assenti visto il level cap decisamente basso dei protagonista e delle battaglie che puntano pi√π sul tempismo nel premere un tasto durante il colpo che sulla strategia di malus/bonus o sull'essere decisamente pi√π forte a stat rispetto al nemico (molto in tal senso la fa la scelta del costume, non possibile da switchare in battaglia). In generale, per tutta la durata del titolo un comparto che diverte ma ampiamente difettoso soprattuto per una difficolt√† quasi assente, un sistema di missioni decisamente caotico e che risultano poi nel compimento delle solite azione e nella ricerca spasmodica del Costume successivo per sbloccare i paletti delle varie aree che il gioco impone e se a questo aggiungiamo una non perfetta navigazione del personaggio nella world map, un sistema di controllo non del tutto calibrato ed in parte buggato (colpi o parate perfetti non calcolati, e viceversa) ed uno svolgimento delle battaglie davvero semplicistiche seppur con qualche buona idea (il ragionamento tipico dei giochi con battaglie a turni risultano in toto inutile) non pu√≤ che farmi bocciare anche questo comparto.
-Anche a longevit√† siamo messi piuttosto maluccio, terminato il primo capitolo con il doppio delle ore (e mi sembrava gi√† una durata molto striminzita) anche la rigiocabilit√†, visto le parole spese, non risulta poi cos√¨ eccelsa (una volta terminato sicuramente non vi verr√† voglia di riprenderlo ne nel breve ne nel lungo periodo)

Che dire se non...Delusione?!
Mi aspettavo un titolo dai toni fanciulleschi ma non cos√¨ tanto ed avendo giocato il capitolo precedente (non mi era neanche dispiaciuto) mi sarei aspettato passi avanti pi√π decisi e marcati invece mi son ritrovato un prodotto insipido e che non porta nulla al panorama indie se non la classica storia di Bambini che salvano Halloween. Peccato.

VOTO
30/100
Sicuramente un pubblico decisamente pi√π giovane potr√† apprezzare di pi√π un titolo di questo stampo ma, il mio consiglio, √® di far ingegnare i ragazzi nei videogiochi e non dargli in pasto un titolo dove la loro testa pu√≤ andare tranquillamente in vacanza data la sua "stupidit√†"

author: {'steamid': '76561198148334833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1504560333}
review:
Este Costume Quest es la continuaci√≥n de las aventuras de nuestros recolectores de caramelos preferidos en Halloween, los cuales ya nos hab√≠an brindado numerosas escenas que robaban m√°s de una sonrisa y una historia que se dejaba jugar como los buenos juegos cortos mandan: manejo, quests y gr√°ficos sencillos donde los reyes son las grandes dosis de simpat√≠a y humor.

En esta entrega, la esencia divertida se mantiene pero el sistema de combate var√≠a un poco, ya que incorporan cartas jugables en vez de sellos para los stats de los disfraces, lo cual aumenta bastante el estilo de lucha a algo m√°s elaborado.

PROS
-Las conversaciones y la trama en general es graciosa, se pasa un buen rato. Adem√°s, es el broche final a la historia (o lo parece) de forma bastante digna
-El sistema de juego por turnos junto con los disfraces y sus golpes especiales son divertidos

CONS
En este punto.... El juego ya no me ha entusiasmado tanto. Hay errores t√©cnicos que ensombrecen la jugabilidad en alg√∫n punto. En mi caso sufr√≠ tres:
-En un momento dado, al comienzo de una batalla, las cartas jugables se ve√≠an delante sin poder ver el cursor ni a d√≥nde clicaba; s√≥lo se solucion√≥ atinando "a lo que fuera" unos segundos, despu√©s de varios intentos fallidos en el que terminaba d√°ndole a huir sin querer xD

EDITO: En cons mencionaba unos supuestos fallos relacionados con llevar el disfraz de robot, porque era pon√©rmelo y que los enemigos me ignorasen. Tambi√©n me quejaba de que en la batalla final no pod√≠a pon√©rmelo para luchar y verlo en acci√≥n. Pues... estos "fallos" no eran tales, sino que el disfraz en cuesti√≥n, su utilidad especial es la del SUBTERFUGIO, o sea, pasar desapercibido....... Por eso no me interactuaba y en la batalla final desaparec√≠a y la m√°quina me endi√±aba el ma√≠z dulce por defecto >,< xD (no caig√°is en errores tontos como el m√≠o, leed bien las descripciones de los disfraces xDDDD)

As√≠ que bueno, s√≥lo me queda rectificar y a√±adir que joer, ya podr√≠an poner alguna pista de ello, que los pjs comentaran algo antes y as√≠ el tema no pillara de improviso justo adem√°s en el final, con las prisas del boss :S xDDDD

7,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198158185766', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1514671216}
review:
Double Fine nos vuelve a encandilar con la continuaci√≥n de Costume Quest, como si no hubi√©semos dejado de jugar. Hilando la historia original, meti√©ndonos de lleno en otra, y endulzando la semana de Halloween. ¬øQu√© m√°s pod√≠amos pedir? Quiz√°s un poco m√°s de jugabilidad, y menos repetici√≥n o mayor profundidad, aunque por lo dem√°s sigue la estela de una decente aventura RPG, en la que el g√©nero de aventura, de investigaci√≥n, de hacer clic aqu√≠ y all√°, de buscar las claves de la trama, se mezclan con el combate por turnos caracter√≠stico del rol cl√°sico. Eso s√≠, donde el humor y la belleza visual abundan por todos los recovecos del juego. 

Con un alma infantil, Costume Quest 2 nos pone en los ojos de los gemelos Reynold y Wren, que a trav√©s de agujeros en el tiempo, disfraces que emulan los cl√°sicos en Halloween, y la incesante b√∫squeda de caramelos y pegatinas de poder, han de evitar que un malvado dentista deje al mundo sin caramelos. 
 
 JUGABILIDAD 
Costume Quest 2 basa su sistema de juego en el ir y venir de los dos protagonistas disfrazados en un d√≠a de Halloween mientras intentamos detener al malvado dentista. Y estos disfraces no solo otorgan un m√©todo pintoresco de moverse por el escenario, sino que cada disfraz otorga en el combate un rol determinado. De este modo, podremos ir disfrazados de ‚ÄúSuperh√©roes‚Äù, que nos conceder√°n capacidad de da√±o directo; de ‚ÄúPayaso‚Äù, con habilidades de curaci√≥n; de ‚ÄúMalvavisco‚Äù, el cual no hace m√°s que recibir da√±o (pero es muy gracioso), o si necesitamos apoyo siempre podremos recurrir a un disfraz de ‚ÄúPerisod√°ctilo‚Äù. Vamos, los cuatro cl√°sicos roles en un mundo de fantas√≠a. 

CONCLUSIONES 
Aquellos que hayan disfrutado de la primera parte, no encontrar√°n muchas novedades en este, y aunque s√≠ se corrigen determinados problemas como la velocidad de los personajes a la hora de recorrer el mapa, los mismos problemas del original siguen en esta nueva entrega. A los apasionados de Double Fine nos encontraremos ante un estilo similar, y cierta cercan√≠a en la forma de jugar. Y aquellos que llegan nuevos, no necesitar√°n conocer el Costume Quest original, ya que este es en s√≠ mismo una entrega √∫nica. 

Los gr√°ficos cumplen perfectamente su funci√≥n, y nos meten de lleno en una historia colorida, donde las explosiones, los gestos extravagantes y las animaciones un poco anime har√°n las delicias de los fans de Double Fine. Escoge a Reynold o escoge a Wren, y emb√°rcate en la aventura de evitar que el se√±or White, malvado dentista, intente dejar al mundo sin caramelos. D√©jate llevar por una aventura de caramelos de sabores, llena de colores y de disfraces. Y disfruta de una tarde de peleas roleras, mientras de forma virtual pides ‚Äútruco o trato‚Äù, una vez al a√±o, mientras el humor y la belleza del mundo de Costume Quest 2 te maravilla. 

LO MEJOR: 

La ambientaci√≥n, el mundo colorido y detallista.

El humor ,que nos hace sonre√≠r en muchas ocasiones.

Aunque no sea habitual, la duraci√≥n. El tiempo de juego es suficiente para disfrutar del t√≠tulo. 


LO PEOR: 

Sistema de combate muy, muy repetitivo.

No mejora mucho el t√≠tulo original, es una continuaci√≥n de la historia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198200519807', 'num_games_owned': 857, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1501003055}
review:
This is the sequel from the game that consist from two main element: the costume, and the quest. So the title is... Costume Quest 2. 

+Battle system improvement: combo, counter, new ability system, and other,
+Story improvement, involved the past and the future,
+Setting improvement, ex: you can boost your movement without specific costume,
+And of course with the new costume and new quest.

Still recommended: 8/10

P.S. : Better play the prequel so you can know the basic of the game and the story.

review:
Costume Quest 2 prosegue subito dopo il finale del primo, un dentista malvagio ha cambiato il presente dal futuro e toccher√† a noi saltare avanti e indietro nel tempo per salvare ancora una volta l' Halloween!
Lo stile del gioco rimane pressoch√® uguale al precedente, busseremo alle porte per le caramelle, combatteremo i cattivi e lo faremo indossando i nostri costumi preferiti, (alcuni meno in tema Halloween del precedente capitolo, ma ugualmente divertenti) in un sistema di combattimento sempre a turni ma stavolta pi√π dinamico e meno noioso.
Consiglio a tutti di partire dal primo capitolo per godere di tutti i riferimenti presenti nel gioco e ovviamente li consiglio entrambi a tutti!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038880470', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1492948245}
review:
[h1][b]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ[/b][/h1]
After playing through Costume Quest 1, I took a break by playing something else, because honestly, that game is not great. It has the charm, but the combat was too simplistic and repetitive. Some players also had problems with the fast-scrolling, automated texts. Though I still think this sequel is somewhat too easy, I do think that this game can be considered as one of the best video game sequels in recent years.

It's improves everything from the first game. The combat this time is more intriguing with the slight rock-paper-scissors mechanic and the significance of the cards. Graphically they also added a lot of great looking effects, lots of original assests and generally more detail to the world. I thought the first game had a great style to it, but the sequel just made the style prettier in overall. Perhaps the best improvement is the writing. The story has a lot more going on, the humor pretty much always hits and the cutscenes (including those in combat) have been treated with care.

I've one would ask me, I'd say this game is one of Double Fines best, next to Iron Brigade.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140136036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1492795156}
review:
Denn ersten Teil hab ich geliebt ! Es wurde mit so viel Liebe und Hingabe die Levels design, das game war einfach klasse.Die Story , Die Aufgaben, das Prinzip und die Steuerung Einfach genial. Doch der zweite Teil hat nichts mehr mit Costume Quest zu tun. Die Steuerung ist Grauenhaft. Das Kapfsystem ist nicht viel besser. Das alte Kampfystem im ersten Teil war zwar simpel aber toll. Ich hatte es schnell drauf und habe mich auch wie ein kleines Kind bei siegen gefreut. Jetzt im zweten Teil versuch ich k√§mpfe zu vermeiden ... es macht mir keinen Spa√ü mehr.
Es ist schade das sowas aus Costume Quest geworden ist ...
Aber das ist nur meine Meinung ihr solltet euch trotzdem eine eigene Bilden :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028648236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1451705556}
review: Costume quest 2 is allot like buying candy after Halloween. It's cheap and plentiful but it doesn't quite have the same feeling as buying full priced candy before the date and stuffing your craw.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026565056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 603, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1491704919}
review: Costume Quest 2 is a casual indie game made by Double Fine Productions. It's a sequel to their first Costume Quest game. This time around the kids', Wren and Reynold, dentist goes back in time to steal the talisman that summons the monsters from the first game. It's up to Wren and Reynold to save Halloween, agian. The plot is kind of random, in the first game the main characters had a confict that ended up make the situation they were in, this time random evil dentist that can time travel out of nowhere. So, insted of having your third child, Everett, from the first game, you get a new party member every level you go to, because of that I never got into the new characters at all. The gameplay is basical the same, but insted of the passive power-up stamps, you use battle cards in battles. It got rid of after battle healing, making you go to the healing water, or eat some of your candy for health. Combat is still boring after awhile. The beginning of the game is kind of hard, cause you give you a joke candy corn costume that does attack. Overall, I think it's not as good as the first game and it's dlc, but it's not bad. And I give this a 6.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036868741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1673765453}
review: Outside of story, OST and atmosphere, it is worse than the first one and dlc in every other way. Controls are more complex in the worst ways possible, removal of post battle healing and new buff system all made the experience worse. The useless candy corn costume is a joke that got stale quick. Maybe worth it for the story if anything, I would wait for a sale to buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046561928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1490734106}
review:
Come seguito di Costume Quest ha fatto ci√≤ che doveva fare, migliorare i comandi dei combattimenti.
Ora ogni personaggio ha il suo tasto dedicato e i combattimenti sono migliorati, forse diventando ancora pi√π semplici da portare a termine.

Dura forse un paio di ore in pi√π del primo capitolo ed √® pi√π difficile da completare al 100%. Migliorata anche la componente RPG con l'aggiunta dei potenziamenti ai costumi e l'uso delle carte, e non pi√π dei francobolli, direttamente in combattimento.

Una storia veramente belle e decisamente ben scritta. Il che, visto le tematiche di questo capitolo, non era cosa scontata. Bellissimo lo story telling con un finale che ha quel giusto tocco di profondit√† che pu√≤ piacere anche ai pi√π grandi.

Come per il primo, vi regala quella 5/6 ore di relax e divertimento che ogni tanto servono. Per pi√π ci sono ottime novit√† nel gameplay che di certo nom gustano.

ATTENZIONE: per capire appieno la storia dovrete giocare il DLC del primo capitolo.

review: Dobr√Ω n√°stupce prvn√≠ho d√≠lu. Vylep≈°en√° grafika, nov√Ω p≈ô√≠bƒõh, lep≈°√≠ technika boje.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129501715', 'num_games_owned': 1155, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1488668854}
review:
[h1]¬øQuieres un juego simple para divertirte y relajarte un rato? Entonces este juego es lo que buscas.[/h1]

La primera entrega me encant√≥ y esta no se ha quedado atr√°s. Costume Quest 2 es un juego en el que tienes que ir haciendo misiones por diferentes localizaciones hasta conseguir llegar a la batalla final con el enemigo principal del juego (un dentista). La ambientaci√≥n de esta segunda entrega es sublime, adem√°s podemos explorar las zonas que vayamos desbloqueando. La historia en s√≠ es muy graciosa y divertida, aunque no es nada del otro mundo tampoco. Podemos seguir la historia principal y a su vez ir realizando misiones secundarias y recogiendo caramelos (ya sea en casas, batallas u objetos que encontremos) los cuales nos servir√°n para comprar mejoras de disfraces y cartas.

El dise√±o art√≠stico es muy bueno, personalmente me enamoran los juegos as√≠. El sistema de combate se hace algo repetitivo a la larga debido a lo simple que es. Se basa en combates por turnos, donde podremos lanzar dos tipos de ataques (uno normal y otro especial), tambi√©n se pueden lanzar dos en el mismo turno, defenderse y contraatacar. Tambi√©n se pueden utilizar cartas en el combate, las cuales vamos recogiendo en batallas, cofres o compr√°ndolas.

Tenemos 11 personajes diferentes (que en realidad son disfraces de Halloween: hombre lobo, superh√©roe, payaso, perrito caliente, mago... ), cada uno con su ataque normal y especial, como nombr√© anteriormente. Algunos de ellos tambi√©n tienes habilidades fuera de combate, √∫tiles para realizar misiones secundarias y acceder a zonas secretas. Un disfraz a destacar es el de "Ma√≠z de caramelo", un personaje que NO ataca y que se dedica a decir frases graciosas cada vez que es su turno. Existe un logro, en el cual tienes que pasarte el juego luchando con √©l en todas las batallas, un plus de dificultad para el que acabe el juego y quiera volver a rejugarlo.

La duraci√≥n es algo mayor con respecto a la primera entrega, sobre las 9-10 horas se pueden conseguir todos los logros. En rebajas este juego se puede conseguir tirado de precio (yo lo compr√© por 3‚Ç¨), al igual que la primera entrega (que ha llegado a estar a 0,99‚Ç¨). As√≠ que si buscas un juego para divertirte, pasar el rato y probar algo diferente, no dudes en comprarlo. Eso s√≠, recomiendo antes jugar la primera entrega para as√≠ enterarte mejor de todo.

Nota: otro gran punto a destacar es que el juego est√° completamente en espa√±ol, se agredece que se haya traducido a nuestro idioma.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006563527', 'num_games_owned': 3471, 'num_reviews': 909, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1487675587}
review:
Costum Quest 2 ist ein 3D-RPG das zwischen zwei Ansichten wechselt, dem eigentlichen Spielmodus wo wir mit einem kleinen Trupp Kinder herumwuseln und Quests erf√ºllen und dem Kampfmodus der rundenbasiert √§hnlich wie bei den fr√ºhen Final Fantasy Titeln abl√§uft. W√§hrend die Spielmodus-Ansicht und die Story doch eher an ein j√ºngeres Publikum gerichtet ist, ich kann ohnehin mit dem amerikanischen Halloween nichts anfangen, ist der Kampfmodus recht witzig gemacht. Vor allem gef√§llt mir das die Kinder, je nach dem welches Kost√ºm sie tragen (wir finden/bekommen st√§ndig neue Kost√ºme und k√∂nnen gezielt wechseln) sich verwandeln. Also aus dem Jungen/M√§dchen in einem Pappkarton-Roboterkost√ºm wird im Kampfmodus ein Kampfroboter der Raketen verschie√üt. Sch√∂nes Spiel das nach anf√§nglicher Verwirrung schnell in den Bann ziehen kann.

review: You remember costume Quest one? This game EXPANDS on the original with more costumes and more story with a new story and new characters. I LOVE this game i give this game 5 stars. IT IS THAT GOOD The attacks and new moves are also a joy to use. the candy corn quoates are downright HILLARIOIUS! The Combat was improved from the first game... though i wish the battle stamp system was still a thing... and being able to EAT candy to heal rather than having to walk all the way to a save point was a nice change of pace. And the NEW super abilities are Quirky Funny and awesome all at the same time. the funniest was Jefferson's Decloration of Destruction Especially when i dental drone starts munching on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054216330', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1487010866}
review:
[b]Costume Quest 2[/b] ist ein kleines, Geradliniges RPG mit kindgerechtem Setting f√ºr junge Spieler und jungebliebene √§ltere Spieler

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Das Gameplay von Costume Quest 2 hat sich im vergleich zum Vorg√§nger nicht gro√üartig ver√§ndert, hat aber einige entscheidende Neuerungen.
Das [b]Kampfsystem[/b] ist im Gro√üen und Ganzen das gleiche wie im Vorg√§nger. Man bek√§mpft im Rundenkampf die Gegner. Bei Angriffen und Verteidigungsaktionen wird ein Quicktime-Event gestartet, das bei bestehen den ausgeteilten Schaden erh√∂ht oder erlittenen verringert. Die drei Klassenelemente im Spiel bringen je nach resistenz Boni oder Abz√ºge im Kampf. Charaktere, die beispielsweise gegen magische Monster stark sind, erleiden durch sie weniger Schaden und verursachen ihnen mehr Schaden. Auf der anderen Weise erleiden Charaktere von Gegnern gegen deren Typ sie schwach sind mehr Schaden und f√ºgen ihnen auch weniger zu. 

Anders als im Vorg√§nger hat man keine Kampfmarken mehr, die permanente Boni bieten sondern [b]Sammelkarten[/b], die man einmalig im Kampf einsetzen kann und bei bedachtem Einsatz gro√üe Auswirkung auf das Kampfgeschehen haben.

Das war es dann mit den Neuerungen auch schon. Wie im Vorg√§nger l√§uft man in den einzelnen levels herum, geht von Haus zu Haus und sammelt dabei S√º√üigkeiten. Ziel ist es oftmals unter anderem, alle H√§user abzuklappern. Dabei wird man hin und wieder von Gegnern angegriffen. 
In den Levels sind oftmals zahlreiche optionale Secrets und Kost√ºmteile versteckt, aus denen man sich ein Kost√ºm basteln kann, das ben√∂tigt wird, um im Spiel weiter zu kommen, denn wie im Vorg√§nger haben Kost√ºme auch hier oftmals besondere Eigenschaften und F√§higkeiten, die einem neue Wege ebnen, so kann der Pterodactylkost√ºm beispielsweise Laufhaufen hinwegblasen, die im Weg sind.

[h1]Grafik/Soundtrack[/h1]
Die Grafik hat den selben minimalistischen, kindlichen Stil wie im Vorg√§nger und passt damit gut zum Thema des Spiels. Der Soundtrack ist recht h√∂renswert.

[h1]Zusammenfassung[/h1]

[b]Positiv:[/b]
[list]
    [*]einfach zu erlernendes, eing√§ngiges Kampfsystem
    [*]Hier und da Humor
[/list]

[b]Negativ:[/b]
[list]
    [*]immer noch zu leicht f√ºr √§ltere Spieler. Taktische Ans√§tze gehen unter. Mehrere Schwierigkeitsgrade w√§hren gut.
    [*]Hauptmen√º unn√∂tig langsam in der Bedienung
    [*]gro√üteils repetatives Gameplay
[/list]

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Costume Quest 2 kn√ºpft an der Konzept des Vorg√§ngers an, wenn auch nicht komplett. Wer den Vorg√§nger gut fand und wem nach weiteren S√º√üigkeitensammelstreifz√ºgen durch die verschiedenen Levels ist, der kann hier zugreifen.
Wer ein ernsthaftes Spiel mit spielerischem wie erz√§hlerischem Tiefgang sucht, sucht besser weiter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081294899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1484502957}
review:
"Costume Quest 2" is a direct sequel to "Costume Quest" and also plays like. Well, most of the time.
In the sequel a grumpy Halloween-hating Dentist threatens to destroy the beloved holiday in order to build a new society where candy and Halloween are illegal. The heroes from the last game - the twin siblings Wren and Reynold - again fight baddies, collect costumes, candy and trading cards but this time also have to use time travel where they take a glance into a bleak future with even North-Korean, communist tendencies (no joke, there are two or three or even more references).

So the story's a bit bigger than last time, although I admit that I prefer the first game also because of the story. It felt like something a child would completely fantasize about (some bullies stealing candy and fighting you, the own mother being the evil witch boss) while the sequel provides a story that's almost nowhere just out of a child's mind. It's a matter of taste but it's still enjoyable. But the first game just spreads that Halloween feeling much better.

The gameplay is almost the same and not hard to learn after a while. However, fighting and handling the menues and trading cards are different. Generally it's not bad but if you played the first game and liked the controls there, you might need time to get used to the new controls. When it comes to fighting, there's a character teaching you moves in tutorials.

The new costumes are sweet for the most part and in some way or others replace the old ones (like the clown replaces the Statue of Liberty...I never thought I would actually say this or write this down...).

The graphics are a little bit better and the music is okay, though, not very memorable.

The puzzles throughout should be easy to solve, yet there are also challenging ones (like getting access to a place or finding necessary items in a city with easy missable corners). And also you can collect achievements for a couple of optional actions (like pimping your costumes which you can but don't have to do).

Overall it still is fun but I like the first "Costume Quest" more. If you haven't played the first game, you might not totally get into the characters or their references to the first story. I generally recommend to play both if you love RPGs and/or Halloween.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049183091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1455991279}

author: {'steamid': '76561198117687346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 706, 'last_played': 1667323739}
review:
I like this game, but not quite as much as the first one. 
But that's mostly personal taste - I preferred the fantasy-themed monsters and plotlines of the first game over the scifi of the second, and the increased complexity of the battles did nothing for me. The costumes didn't make much of an impression overall, and the constant costume-switching for advancement got annoying, but the hotdog cerberus is my absolute favorite.
It's still a good game, with many of the same mechanics and characters as the first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104392527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1483937709}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is a sequel to the extremely fun and interesting kids' adventure embodied in the original Costume Quest. While the story of Costume Quest 2 is meant to continue on from the first game, and is meant to embody the same style, I would say that this sequel is not quite as strong as the original.

I am an extreme fan for the first game and still really enjoyed this game, but it definitely has some big weaknesses. Note that I played both of the games back-to-back, so certain details stood out even more than they might have for years apart.

An adventure RPG is here for you again, as you continue with the brother and sister from the first game, stuck in a bad world suddenly being taken over by a dentist of all people. You must fight your way through some returning monsters from the first game as well as robots created by the dentist to keep his world in check.

Many of the mechanics of the first game still exist, such as using costume abilities to explore the map, the same player stats, the turn-based RPG battles... However, there are some tweaks here and there. In the first game, the only way to sprint across maps was to use the robot ability, which was a slight grievance to keep changing costumes. This game fixes that with its own designated button, thankfully. Further, in the previous game, most battles were triggered at specific points, with only a few sections having enemies walking along the map. This game now has many sections where enemies will run around on the map and you need to avoid them unless you want battle - and many of them respawn. That change is good for giving the maps more life, but bad in the sense that the game adds in some grinding.

Other bigger changes are to the battle style. In the previous game, you mainly performed normal attacks and used the special powers when available. This game adds in a few changes to that: First, you can now run away from battles if you do not want to have them. Second, the developers removed Battle Stamps and you now find Treat Cards which allow for special attacks or powers in battle. You can equip 3 cards at a time and any character can use them. They can only be used once per battle, and each card has a different time limit before it can be reused (i.e., you must complete X number of battles). Third, when you perform attacks, you must now hit the attack button at an exact timing to perform more damage, which is much tougher than in the original game.

Some of those battle changes make the game stronger, some make it weaker. One thing I particularly noticed is that the majority of battles take a lot longer than they did in the first game. The developers seemed to make enemies a lot stronger and you a lot weaker. (As a note, I did have one of my characters being the Candy Corn costume the whole game!)

Besides the above, the rest of the game is pretty much the same, but this time not as fun. You explore the maps, use costumes to get around, and perform trick-or-treating a lot while also solving some side quests... While the first game was quite nice to do that exploration, it now became somewhat of a chore. The story of the game is not as well-done as the first, for many of the main characters only show up occasionally, and the game has a significantly smaller amount of conversations and funny dialog. Further, while the places of exploration are still nice in style, that lack of characters and events makes some of them particularly boring.

If you enjoyed the first Costume Quest, you might still enjoy Costume Quest 2 to some ends, as I still did. But I definitely think that the developers fell behind on keeping the game consistent. The feeling of heart and charm that I had for the first game only happens sporadically for this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026486730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1463468937}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069108534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1467495679}
review:
Enjoyed this game very much, just a little less than the first one. 
The card system they implemented is pretty awesome, adds a lot to battle and you can choose which ever ones you prefer.
I don't know why but I enjoyed the story and costumes in the prequel, Costume Quest, so much more.
If you're debating whether or not to buy this one or the other one, I'd recommend the first one. (This one was shorter and felt a little easier as well)
However they're both super cheap when on sale, so you should obviously get them both if you can, still a very cute game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010395257', 'num_games_owned': 3313, 'num_reviews': 469, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1530250063}
review:
The original Costume Quest was a great game and the sequel doesn't disappoint either.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pvl3TkzUcHw

Costume Quest 2 is, plainly, an RPG about kids trick or treating.  On the surface, that's all it is.  However, it's Tim Schafer at the helm with all his inherent crazyness making it absolutely hilarious.  The battle system is quite nice and nods to classics such as Super Mario RPG with its timing mechanisms and job system (well, costume system in this case) of Final Fantasy 5, but put in a very light way so people of all ages can enjoy it.

So yes, it's a turn-based RPG with timing mechanics based on trick-or-treating that is absolutely hilarious and charming...just like the last one...except this one revolves around a time travelling plot.  Pretty fun stuff overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061535297', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1483444450}
review:
Absolutely adore this game. 
My only advice is to make good use of the card system - they recharge...and make the game a lot easier! 
Beautiful game, and although initally jarringly different to the combat system of the first game, it becomes very quickly a challenging and fun experience. 
Creating a squad with your 3 favourite costumes is a real treat (pun unintended...). So is upgrading the costumes - wish you could do it more than once...definitely will be drawing fanart for this game at some point. LOVE it. Sequel, Double Fine? Please? <3

review:
Das Spiel ist √§hnlich wie der Vorg√§nger, wieder Pl√§ne und die ben√∂tigten Materialien f√ºr die Kost√ºme finden.
Du musst Halloween retten, du musst die Menschen vor einem ungruseligen und langweiligen Halloween bewahren.
Man reist hin und her in die Zukunft und wieder zur√ºck. Du erlernst neue Kampftechniken, lernst neue Gegner kennen.
Einen Unterschied hat das Spiel zum Vorg√§nger aber auch noch, man muss sich n√§mlich nach jedem Kampf an einem Brunnen heilen oder ihr esst ganz einfach S√º√üigkeiten, falls denn nicht schon alles vorher drauf gegangen ist. ;)
Auf jeden Fall ist das Spiel wie der Vorg√§nger interessant und lustig programmiert worden. Also kauft es euch und schnappt euch so viele S√º√üigkeiten wie ihr essen k√∂nnt!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1955, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482713754}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Costume Quest 2 is an adventure game developed by the wonderful people behind Stacking, Brutal Legend and Grim Fandango: Remastered; Double Fine Productions and published by Majesco Entertainment and Midnight City. Double Fine Producitons once again hits the nail yet again with their cleverly designed and well thought out game

Costume Quest 2 continues right after the ending of Costume Quest which I won't spoil here. Across the game's worlds you have to go and knock doors to ask for candy. Sometimes you will get regular human beings who give you candy, sometimes its the nasty Grubbins which it will send you into an RPG button prompt combat system. The combat system is sort of fun but can get very repetitive and boring

This game, the same with Stacking, is meant for people unlike me who are known as completionists. Completionists will have a ball playing Costume Quest 2 and leveling up. The game's graphics are really cute and well designed, the music is nothing special but it is good nevertheless

Costume Quest 2 is the same as Costume Quest, it is very repetitive. Expect to enter the boring combat system multiple times and doing the same thing which is trick or treating can get boring and repetitive too. The game is okay at first but it can be impossible to finish if you are not leveled up properly

Costume Quest 2 has some improvements from the first game but also has some new or the same issues that Costume Quest suffered with that made me not enjoy it. Costume Quest 2 however is certainly more enjoyable and entertaining yet somewhat repetitive at certain points and is certainly better than Costume Quest

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198089374202', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 865, 'last_played': 1480622023}
review:
A group of youngsters face a future without Halloween after an evil dentist steals a relic which allows him to drastically alter the future by allowing monsters into the human world. These monsters live off the currency of candy, something that is now illegal for humans to consume. Desperate to save Halloween and prevent the dentists version of a utopia coming to fruition, the crew goes back in time (and then to the future, and then back again?? and then the future once more... and then... kinda jump between the two a couple more times trying to unlock that freaking solar system costume) and save Halloween using the only logical method of attack... turn based combat!

Double Fine have a habit of making charming games that I love. They aren't perfect (except Psychonauts which literally is perfect and when I die I hope to be buried with it) but what they lack in one area they will more than make up for in story telling, character development and humour. I found that I take more screenshots playing Costume Quest games and DLC than any other game. Everything just looks gorgeous, not like a new AAA game where you can see every speck of dirt on the lead characters face, as he walks in a rain, with a lightning storm in the background and great lighting effects - no, not that. It's gorgeous because it's colourful and engaging. The world, be it cartoony, feels real. 

Honestly, I enjoyed the original more than the sequel but it's still worth playing if you're a fan of their work and want to support the developers. If you are not a fan or know nothing about Double Fine or their games, I would recommend starting with the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982180153', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1482701830}
review:
Non ricordo perfettamente il primo, visto che ci ho giocato ormai 2 anni fa, ma di una cosa sono sicuro: ho solo bei ricordi.
E' proprio per questo che questo nuovo capitolo non mi √® andato molto gi√π.

Sebbene sembra sia stato fatto per i giocatori pi√π piccoli (molto piccoli), il primo era divertente anche per i pi√π grandi, con dialoghi di certo infantili ma non scritti proprio da poppanti per poppanti, ed un gameplay che comunque fa passare piacevolmente qualche ora (poche a dire il vero) in completo relax, fatto molto gradito da gente pi√π grande (come me), perch√® non sempre si ha voglia di azione o spremimeningi dopo una brutta giornata.

Ecco, nonostante ci√≤, questo gioco non lo vedo adatto ad un bambino piccolo, a meno che non sia assistito da un adulto. Per altri motivi, non lo vedo adatto ad un adulto, visto che non sempre √® puro relax.

Lo svolgimento del gioco √® spesso confusionario: ci sono luoghi nei quali √® difficile capire cosa dobbiamo fare perch√® le nostre azioni non hanno nessuna logica, e gli obiettivi di missione sono generici e poco comprensibili. Ci√≤ non accade troppo spesso, per fortuna, ma comunque accade, e la struttura confusa degli ambienti di gioco, e quella praticamente inutile della mappa del territorio, di certo non aiutano.

Poi non aiuta nemmeno il sistema di combattimento, che per fortuna almeno non √® random. Questo secondo capitolo implementa un nuovo sistema che richiede la pressione di un tasto al momento giusto, sia per l'attacco che per la difesa, se vorrete riuscire a vincere. Sebbene sembra buono su carta, nella pratica non funziona cos√¨ bene, visto che, per qualche motivo, ho trovato che il momento giusto per premere il tasto √® rilevato un po a casaccio. Non so se dipenda da un bug mai risolto, ma ho ottimi riflessi e nonostante ci√≤, il gioco spesso rileva la mia pressione al momento sbagliato, rendendo difficile fare danno (e difesa) massimi. Anche qui, comunque, niente di impossibile o complicato, visto che i combattimenti non sono molto difficili.
E' poi molto noioso il dover andare a bere da una fontanella dopo ogni combattimento, ma almeno ora si pu√≤ anche mangiare qualche caramella raccolta per ottenere lo stesso effetto. Sarebbe bastato che i personaggi si ricaricassero automaticamente dopo ogni combattimento per rendere il gioco molto pi√π godibile.

L'esplorazione viene promossa mediante la solita caccia ai segreti, ma anche qui c'√® qualcosa che non va: le mappe sono piene zeppe di ostacoli invisibili che rendono anche questa operazione pi√π noiosa che divertente.

Per il resto non c'√® molto altro da dire. La grafica √® buona ma forse ha qualche problema di stabilit√† di framerate di troppo; inspiegabile, tra l'altro. Mentre il sonoro √® allo stesso livello del precedente capitolo, da quanto ricordo.
Buona la selezione di personaggi anche se, alla fine, non ne vedo molto il senso, visto che potrete vincere con praticamente qualsiasi combinazione di essi. Avrei preferito che fossero utilizzati meglio.

Insomma, un gioco che non √® all'altezza del primo, che non va bene n√© per i bambini n√© per gli adulti, e che consiglio solo con un buon sconto o in un bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076093453', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1436191892}
review:
Got it completed with achivements and everything in 15 hours! 
This game and Costume Quest 1 were bought in a bundle, so you can often find them on sale!
(Even now as I write, they're ¬£1.49 for both of them).

They're both super great games, but this one expands on the storyline of the first, and is a bit difficult than the other. 
The play mechanics are also different when it comes to collecting cards /stamps.
It doesn't make it a bad game though! Just because something is changed doesn't mean it is a bad change.
Battles are similar to the first game, and a bit easier in my opinion!

If you like to collect like I do, then go for it!

review:
To be honest it is definitly not as good as Costume Quest 1 - but the narrative and character design is as cute as ever.
Gave me some awesome flashbacks to the first game and for me it has replayvalue for gathering all achievements since I missed some things in my first playthrough.

For you guys who have problems with the key-responding in fights considering blocking and dealing critical hits -> just put down your resolution and check if the game is in full window mode - this solved that problem for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063643963', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1478865828}
review:
Starting this game I was immediately skeptical. The first Costume Quest held a special place in my heart. It's sequel had a lot to live up to. 

From the get-go I was not impressed. The game's storyline seemed loaded, time-travel - really? Despite the graphics retaining their similarity with the original there was a lot of added 'detail', it felt cluttered. To top it all off the fighting mechanics had changed. From playing the original to this in a short span of time, the altered fighting style was jarring and uncomfortable. 

But the costumed kids had provided me such joy in the past, I gave the game the benefit of the doubt and stuck with it.

After some groaning and grousing. Some frowning and some grumbling. The storyline began to unfold. Familiar faces resurfaced and a smile was gracing my lips. The world you explored had deepened, the hidden bonuses for exploring were genuinely rewarding. The battle system, especially as it expanded became just as enjoyable, if not more enjoyable than the original. 

By the end I was thoroughly satisfied! The antagonist was a great blend of bizarre and entertaining and entirely appropriate for the game's Halloween-themed setting and the cotumes were, as always, fantastic to see in battle-form. (Of particular note was Jefferson's 'Declaration of Destruction.') The strengths and weaknesses mechanic was also a nice detail and the ability to upgrade your costumes, which in turn, changed their appearance, was kind of awesome. 

Unfortunately, the game felt much easier this time around. Much more forgiving, especially later on in the game. The water fountains were never an issue, as you could eat candy on-the-go to keep your health in check. I didn't use the cards a single time, only after I had finished the game to farm the achievement. The only tedium I found was exploring the little overworld's your character's traverse, as the maps were almost entirely useless and a few secrets and a hiding kid or two drove my patience to it's limit. 

Nevertheless, I would highly suggest this game for it's charm, maybe not at full price, mine was bought at a discount, but for the original I shelled out the full price, here and on my old ps3. It provided me with quite a few hours of enjoyment, it is an exceptional sequel and I would definitely buy another installment. I've always had a soft spot for Halloween. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198047460864', 'num_games_owned': 3167, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1558723954}
review:
Double Fine Productions is back with this amazing sequel of Costume Quest and I HAD to play it after finishing the first game in a row. A little confused and doubtful at the beginning, mainly because of the combat system that didn't feel right, I realized it was just about adjusting ; once you're "in", this game is just as good as the first one.

One of the highlights of Costume Quest was the story and I wasn't disappointed with this new storyline - saving Halloween traveling through time, fighting the evilish Dr. White and his dental army. A lot of fun, new costumes and abilities, various new cards to use in combat and of course, new characters. The gameplay and the quests remain identical, but it doesn't get boring for all that (you can even skip combat animations if it starts bothering you after a while). Let's not forget to mention that they (finally !) added maps.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=793942473

Costume Quest 2 is truly worth playing if you've finished the first game. Join Reynold and Wren one more time in a second epic adventure, in this cute and amusing RPG - and, hopefully, there will be a third adventure...

author: {'steamid': '76561198090084538', 'num_games_owned': 1320, 'num_reviews': 265, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1478274962}
review:
This is a decent follow up to the first Costume Quest that I would recommend to anyone who loved the first one, although it doesn't add a [i]ton[/i] to the game. So I would play this game with the "Hardcorn Mode" achievement in mind, because the last game did somewhat better at not just favoring the player in most battles.

Pros:
Graphics are slightly better. "Hardcorn Mode" achievement is a genuine challenge. Level depth seems better. Power up attacks and counter attacks (learned later in game) are welcome additions.  Variety among costumes, their abilities, focuses, and purchaseable upgrades. Candy wasn't so plentiful like the first game that I naturally had enough candy by the end to buy all creepy treats - A welcome challenge.  Maps are nice, and their counters for costume pieces & secrets are very helpful tips.

Cons:
New additions to the game make it way easier outside of Hardcorn Mode. Time travel story is a little more convoluted than the story from the first game.  Creepy treats are now special attacks, and they're either consumables or attacks you can reuse after a certain number of battles (can't spell "Con" without convoluted).  Maps cost way less than creepy treats.  A faint dark translucent horizontal line appeared on most levels throughout the game when navigating on foot - Does not appear in any other game of mine.  Battles almost always feel in favor of player unless playing "hardcorn mode" but that feels like forced balancing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998105505', 'num_games_owned': 5215, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1477410082}
review:
Costume quest 1 was a charming and funny JRPG with some tedious elements and very easy battles. Costume Quest 2 is exactly the same thing, but slightly worse.  
  
[b]Graphics & sound[/b]
Not much has happened in the graphics department since Costume Quest 1. If you play the games back to back, you might notice some differences, but to me, who played them a few years apart., the two games look very similar. 
The game has an intentionally simple graphics style, with cartoonish looking characters. It works quite well, considering the game is a lighthearted game about a bunch of kids who have to save the world on Halloween, and it helps set the tone for the game.  
Outside of combat, most animations are very simple, but they get the job done. The simple animations never actually clash with the game, nor do they look out of place. In combat animations are more intricate, while still keeping with the overall simple tone of the game. In particular the main character animations look quite good. The models are also more detailed in combat and despite how different the models look, the art style still always feel consistent.  
  As far as sound goes, the game fares a bit worse. None of the music is particularly memorable, and the sound effects range from alright to downright annoying. I ended up not using certain costumes due to their annoying sound effects (the clown costume in particular was bad in this regard).

[b]Story & setting[/b]
It's Halloween and an evil time-traveling dentist has ruined everything by banning costumes & candy. It's up to two kids to save Halloween and by extension the world from being boring. Or at least a specific city from being boring on Halloween, the game is not entirely clear on the details. With such an outlandish plot it's surprising to see how little they actually do with it. There are some funny moments, but mostly of the game seems to focus on tedious busywork rather than on the story itself. You visit some different time periods, but while they have a different coat of paint, not much seem to change. Had the game focused on actually telling the story of how Halloween was ruined rather than focusing on having you collect candy from houses no matter when or where you are, the game would have been a lot more interesting. Basically, it feels like Double Fine were unwilling to commit to the story they had created, and they just padded it with things that ended up feeling only loosely related.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
If you've played the first game, you'll know how this game works. It's nigh identical. You move around and talk to people with WASD, and solve some simple puzzles, like many other games, and when you enter combat, it switches to a different perspective. Combat is turnbased and works very similar to Super Mario RPG, where you select what kind of attack you want to make, and if you time your button presses right, you deal additional damage. Each costume has a basic attack and a special attack that requires some buildup before it can be used.
Combat is tedious though. The combat animations are very long, which makes combat take far more time than it should, and there's no way of skipping regular attack animations, due to how you need to time your button presses. Combat is also very easy, which just makes fighting a chore. You're not going to lose, as long as you're paying a bit of attention to the game, it's just not going to happen. 
And while combat is easy, you'll also take a lot of unavoidable damage, so you're expected to go back and heal after every second battle or so, which just makes the game even more tedious. Luckily there are no random encounters, and as long as you stay within an area and don't reload the game, dead enemies stay dead.

[b]Final thoughts[/b]
Costume Quest 2 is a step back from the original Costume Quest. It keeps all of the flaws that the first game had, and introduces a few new ones. Tedious is the best word I can find to describe this game. It's also very bad at actually committing to its strange story, which makes it a lot less memorable than it should have been. Costume Quest 2 is by no means a terrible game, but it's not very good either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056350187', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 429, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1474796192}
review:
Costume Quest was a decent RPG that was a good introduction for young RPG player. Now we go to the sequel and see what‚Äôs new.

Story:
After the events of ‚ÄúGrubbin's on Ice‚Äù, our heros made it home on Halloween even though it was winter. While walking around, the twin's Wren and Reynold, find their dentist is up to something and with the help of a time wizard, gets a talisman that lets him unleash the monsters and gets Halloween. Confused, a time traveller finds them and tells the twins that the dentist has taken over and now you must go on an adventure to save future and Halloween.
This is a time travel story but you only go to two time periods(Bayou Past and Dystopia Future) but the time travel isn't that complicated. I don't much to about about the characters except for the villain, Orel White. This guy is such a delight when he's on screen and is properly one of the funniest villains I've seen in a while. 
I also like the dental theme empire that your explore. It's nice to have a fun take on a dystopia setting every now and then.

Gameplay:
The combat in the first game was repetitive as every fight was the same thing, over and over again. Here, the combat has improved greatly as now you can keep you special bars but you health doesn't refill after a fight. While most of the costumes you get are simply reskins of the ones from the last game, they now have different strengths and weakness to fight enemies which are: monster, magic and tech, and now the costume select shows what stats you'll get for each costume, AND the dash move can be used by everyone. While the all this make deciding costumes more flexible I must saw that Thomas Jefferson is almost essential to a party as he's one of the few costumes that's strong against tech.
Also, the cards you get in the last game gave been promoted to card you use in battle like one that gives you two moves, one that stuns all enemies or one that gives more exp. While I didn't use them much myself, they can be useful depending on what kind of party or stragey you want, although some take longer to recharge than others. I also noticed that every enemy was different as some can do special buffs or debuffs and some attack faster. A trowbog was a lot faster hitting me than a gubbin.
As for the stuff outside of battles, it's mainly the same as the first game, with similar side quest and similar trick or treating with a few minor differences, mainly in the second area.  Not much else to say.

Presentation:
Most of the character models are copy pasted from the last game along with new ones for the new monster types and they replaced the adult model with the one for the twin's parents and Dorsilla. I still think the fat people are adorable in this game. While the music isn't that memorable, the theme for the French Quarter is really catchy. There isn't that much great music so it really stands out.

Verdict:
Like every good squeal, it improves and expands on what didn't work or this case was tedious and made it a bit more challenging.
8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198073841664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1475429924}
review:
Costume Quest 2 picks up right where the first after the DLC left off. It follows the events of your crew consisting of brother, sister duo Reynold and Wren. However unlike the first, this one is beset with bugs, lag and lack the memorable aspects and charm of the prior game.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Cartoon aesthetic is still lovely and evokes a nice Saturday morning cartoon vibe.
+ Audio matches much like the first.
+ Story is good overall but I preferred the events of the first.
+ Battle system is improved a bit, now there are single turn double attack and defensive counter-attacks which reflect some damage to the enemy attacker.
+ Funny at times.
+ Combat requires you to master it otherwise combat will feel tedious at time.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Combat QTE feel like it has some lag as there was numerous times where I hit the QTE correctly but for some reason it failed to respond correctly. There's a fair chance you'll not make it out of the tutorial introducing the QTE combat mechanics.
- The new Creepy Cards system is disappointing, unneeded and can be ignored completely when compared to the Battle Stamps of the first. You can take 3 Cards into battle whereby you can spend a turn to use any one of your cards like consumables. Cards have various effects but the downside is that unlike your special meter it takes 3 battles until you can use that card again. Who thought this was a good idea; all it does is make me not want to you the system entirely.
- Certain Creepy Cards will work 100% of the time on normal enemies but will not on bosses whatsoever. Again, who thought this was a good idea. If you were to compare the Stamps from the first I could augment my costume build without any restrictions and it would work all the time but this just adds insult to injury to those who like the initial system.
- As like many games these days, bugs exist. There's this one bug where the QTE buttons failed to show up against certain enemies forcing me to eat a lot of damage as I couldn't mitigate the damage using the blocking system.
- A map exists but it doesn't indicate your position, lovely.
- Main menu is the most unintuitive menu I've ever had to use. Normally it's hit the Start Game button but here you've got to watch an intro scene which displays options controls or start game controls every time you wish to play. 
- You can't quit the game easily. Normally it's a simple process of hitting the quit button to either quit to the main menu or desktop. With this however, when you quit you're taken back to the unintuitive intro scene, before being presented with the main menu. So the only way to quit easily is to save your game and ALT + F4 out of the game. What nonsense is this?

[h1]Irritations[/h1]
+/- Reuses a lot of assets of the first.
+/- Doesn't really add anything new to the game. Most additions feel like it could've been DLC for the first.
+/- Quest are generally unchanged in their execution but feels really repetitive early on in your adventures. It's essentially the same talk to quest giver and go Trick or Treat on doors but it feels ways more repetitive as there's nothing else to do. 
+/- AI is dumb. I remember dying quite a few times in the CQ1, but with this one, unless I made a mistake or the game failed to register a QTE I'll not die but that could also be attributed to me knowing the system now.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
For some reason this game feels like a cash grab which saw to cash in on the popularity of the first one without really addressing its flaws. Instead of issues being resolved from the first we're met with those same issues and new ones to boot. At 3+ hours I got bored of the tedium and constant repetition and unlike the first this one feels like it has little to no charm and loses my attention quite early. 

I really enjoyed the first game it had charm, endearing story, simplicity in its systems which still had a certain level of depth. This on the other hand feels like the complete opposite. It doesn't improve on any of the original's ideas, it adds new but buggy systems, restricts prior systems and to me that's the worst kind of sequel but it's not terrible. So even though I'm recommending this do note that it has problems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059965676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 672, 'last_played': 1698632354}
review:
After finishing the first Costume Quest I was chomping at the bit for more Halloween goodness, and was so glad a 2 was available! Same wonderful charm as the first game, with the added benefit of slightly more gameplay and storyline. 
I recommend 1 & 2 to pretty much anyone that will listen to me rave about these games. 
Only negative: there's not a Costume Quest 3 (yet!)

I really like the story, so making character decisions would have been more fun I think.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094083996', 'num_games_owned': 2470, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1473107501}
review:
Costume Quest 1 was a cute, simple and very tedious game.  Costume Quest 2 seemed to double-down on the tedium while losing some of the charm, as I couldn't even finish the first area before uninstalling.  Fights are simple but very long and feature timed button presses against HP-sponge enemies.  They are all long and boring and samey in the worst way.  

It's hard to believe someone at Double Fine didn't see the problem here, but I'm guessing they knew it was a bad design choice but were more afraid of being accused of releasing a short game than a tedious one since people that play games would rather slog through garbage for dozen of hours than have fun for a few.

Even the writing in the bit I played didn't seem as fun as the original, and even exiting the game is strangely tedious if you don't force quit out of it.  Costume Quest 2 is a really disappointing game that apparently learned nothing from the flaws of its predecessor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023218150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1471821193}

review:
A very good sequel to a very good game. This one follows some similar mechanics, with some differences in the battle style. There are also new characters and costumes to play as/with.

The art and style of this game stay true to the original, while still adding plenty of new environments, and the story is a great continuation to the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970702836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1468822962}
review:
so far it's similar to costume quest 1 except they took what made the original memorable and made it better
sorry i have to be a jokester about it i really cannot take anything about this seriously
the combat's been simplified so you no longer have to look at the randomized "hit this button for damage/no damage" button since it's no longer randomized
now you have to save after every fight instead of after clearing every level
the timing has been slightly improved so now you can go for a super crit or regular crit which you'll hit anyway
but really, if you're looking at costume quest 2 chances are you played the first one
this game is the same, save for more doublefine "writing"

author: {'steamid': '76561198023049557', 'num_games_owned': 764, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1468464254}
review:
[h1]Und wieder ist Halloween...[/h1]

Ich muss wirklich sagen, als gro√üer Fan des ersten Teils waren meine Erwartungen an die Fortsetzung hoch. Leider wurden diese sehr entt√§uscht. Generell ist Costume Quest 2 kein schlechtes Spiel und einiger der neuen Elemente finde ich sogar ganz gut, (das gliden funktioniert jetzt auch ohne Roboterkost√ºm) nur kann ich √ºber die schlechten Dinge nicht hinwegsehen (man muss sich nach K√§mpfen an Brunnen wieder heilen).

Wenn man wie ich den ersten Teil gespielt und liebgewonnen hat, findet man das neue Kampfsystem in dem Punkt gut, das es nicht mehr wie ein Quicktime Event wirkt, sondern jetzt jeder Charakter einen festgelegten Button zur Benutzung hat. Dadurch wirken die Attacken jetzt fl√ºssiger und man verbockt nicht hin und wieder das Blocken der gegnerischen Attacken. Was mich allerdings am neuen Kampfsystem st√∂rt ist die Tatsache das ich im richtigen Moment die Taste dr√ºcken muss damit etwas Wumms reinkommt. Man kann im weitern Spielverlauf noch etwas dazulernen (Kombo & Gegenangriff ), das t√§uscht aber nicht √ºber die M√§ngel des neuen Kampfsystems hinweg.

Bleiben wir noch ein wenig beim Kampfsystem. Die Kampfmarken aus dem ersten Teil sind auch wieder dabei, nur leider wurde das auch neu umgesetzt. Man r√ºstet √ºber das Men√º vor dem Kampf seine Karten wieder aus. Neu umgesetzt ist allerdings das es keinen "passiven" Boni mehr gibt, sondern die Karten im Kampf gespielt werden m√ºssen. Das Ergebniss sieht dann so aus das Karten dann f√ºr einige Runden wieder aufgeladen werden m√ºssen und somit ihren Zweck f√ºr mich verlieren. 

Die Grafik sieht gegen√ºber seinem Vorg√§nger aufpoliert aus, nur leider verliert es dadurch ein wenig an seinem Comic Charme. Costume Quest 2 kommt wie der Vorg√§nger auch wieder ohne Sprachausgabe daher, was einem mal wieder dazu bringt Gespr√§che mitzulesen (als RPG Spieler ist man das ja gew√∂hnt). Der Sound und die Musik passen sich dem Setting in dem wir unterwegs sind, und da gibt es auch f√ºr mich nichts zu meckern.

Ich w√ºrde dem Spiel gerne einen Daumen rauf geben, nur kann ich das nicht weil die Neuerungen einfach das Spiel runterziehen.

review:
Ooof were do I start

The Good
-60fps
-interesting premise
-Skating without robo suit
~old costumes reappear (granted pre order only game)

thats it for The Good..... no I'm serious

The Bad  (OOH THERE IS ALOT)
-(IMO most of new costumes)
-battle system turned into crappy Mario and luigi style gameplay
-enemies are even more generic
-the cool stamp system is replaced with a (pardon my french) F***ING S**TTY A**  card system
-now you have to heal outside of battles too (not too bad)

The Ugly
-lacks the charm of the first game
-Some of the UI looks terrible (IF IT AIN'T BROKE DON'T FIX IT)


If you really want it then buy it, BUT..... if you want to truly see why people like the series so much buy the first one instead if you haven't already

review:
Globalement d√©cevant, ce second opus est largement inf√©rieur au 1er. Malgr√© une √©criture toujours aussi sympathique, et un ou deux twists sc√©naristiques sympatoches, le reste se r√©v√®le bien inf√©rieur. L'aventure est bien moins longue et beaucoup moins vari√©e (j'ai mis 5h √† le finir, contre une dizaine sur le 1er opus), le syst√®me de combat est moins int√©ressant et devient encore plus r√©p√©titif, et les nouveaux costumes sont sympas sans plus.
On dirait plus un gros DLC qu'autre chose et pourtant... m√™me le DLC du 1, "Larbins sur Glace", √©tait beaucoup plus int√©ressant que ce nouvel opus! Mieux vaut vous procurer ce dernier si vous avez appr√©ci√© Costume Quest 1!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026325298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1465078460}
review:
[h1]Score: 7/10[/h1]

[u][b]Similar Games[/b][/u]
Costume Quest

[u][b]Summary[/b][/u]
The gang is out collecting candy again, but with a twist. Time travel and an evil dentist has cause the end of halloween as we know it. You now must time travel to prevent it.

[u][b]The Good[/b][/u]
Same adorable style of graphics and humor as the original. The level designs are much more interesting this time around. The objectives are a bit more interesting along with use of costume powers to traverse the level or solve small puzzle situations. The use of cards that give combat advantages.

[u][b]The Bad[/b][/u]
Even though the combat should be more interesting with timed button presses forcing you to stay involved it ends up just being annoying. The cards are great, but the actual abilities don't seem as interesting or balanced as the original.

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]
It's a great game if you loved the original. If you didn't like the first one you won't like this one. It doesn't really evolve enough to be called anything beyond an extension of the original.

[u][b]Value[/b][/u]
If you play and like the original I'd suggest playing this, but get it on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010082736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1464530177}
