author: {'steamid': '76561197972142968', 'num_games_owned': 1921, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1446687400}
review:
This is a very good continuation of the series. If you liked the 1st CQ, you'll like this one.

***Below is my review of CQ1. It holds true to CQ2 as well. There are very few changes other then the story.***

This game is all about the charm. The story isn't the same ol' derivative RPG story. The characters & setting are very enjoyable. I especially enjoyed playing this during Halloween, It put me in the holiday spirit.

As an RPG there's nothing truely ground breaking here. The combat is ok, It's a class based system. Classes are selected through a series of costumes. Some costumes have healing abilities, some are damage/crowd control & others are defensive. It may sound unique & interesting, but the battles generally all go the same way due to the fact that your abilities are not able to be activated till the 3rd round. Damage for 3 rounds, if the enemy is still up, stun heal & damage battle over.

I'm a fan of Tim Schafer's work, but I'm going to rate his work on it's own merits. This game is fun & charming & I would recommend it, but I would say wishlist it & wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040904595', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1459155084}
review:
Direct sequel to Costume Quest with few gameplay improvements, new story and new costumes. Mind you that the core gameplay and structure are exactly the same. You will once again travel around in a team of three, utilizing costumes with different abilities to fight monsters in very basic RPG battles and solve simple puzzles. Only thing that is really new are 45 Creepy Treat Cards, that can be used in battles with various effects ranging from healing, disabling enemies, buffing allies and so on. CQ2 took me 7 hours to complete while getting all achievements in the process.

Pick it up if you need closure after Grubbins on Ice or just want more of the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071193512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1456269619}
review:
I really enjoyed the first costume quest.  Cute graphics, good gameplay, great setting, very funny.  Plus the Grubbins On Ice content essentially doubled the length of the game.

Costume Quest 2 is at first just as enjoyable.  The graphics are just as cute, the gameplay is just as good, the setting is if anything even betterm as is the humour.

It's just that... it's really short.  Like, really short.  Without spoiling anything the end credits sequence is a neighbourhood you can wander around in, and I kept trying to work out how I made the next bit of the game start because I couldn't believe the story would be this short.

I really really enjoyed it while playing, so I'm giving it a thumbs up.  I just wanted more.

review:
Nachdem ich den ersten Teil angefangen hatte zu spielen,
war ich positiv √ºberrascht. Es war also keine schwere Entscheidung sich noch den zweiten Teil zuzulegen.
Wer noch am gr√ºbeln ist, ob er sich Teil 2 zulegen soll, oder nicht, der soll gar nicht lange nachdenken
und das Ding hier in seinen Warenkorb schieben :)
Es kn√ºpft sehr sch√∂n an die Geschichte von Teil 1 an und der Flair ist unver√§ndert.

Dicker Pluspunkt: 
‚Ä¢   Man kann mittlerweile S√º√üigkeiten "quasi" farmen, dadruch das immer wieder neue Monster in der Gegend spawnen.
‚Ä¢   Candy Corn ist sehr unterhaltsam.


Kritikpunkte g√§be es, mag aber Geschmackssache sein:
‚Ä¢    Das Kampfsystem hat mir in diesem Teil nicht so gut zugesagt, in Teil 1 war das besser gel√∂st.
‚Ä¢    Au√üerdem hat man, sinnfreierer Weise, noch zus√§tzlich Heilbrunnen aufgestellt. Sehr nervig wenn man jedesmal
einen Brunnen suchen muss um die HP zu regenerieren. 
In Teil 1 war das gar nicht n√∂tig, da nach jedem Kampf die HP automatisch regeneriert wurde.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126615821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1453719821}
review: In eerste instantie lijkt het lichtjaren dieper uitgewerkt dan de oorspronkelijke game: meer mogelijkheden om verschillende tactieken te gebruiken, meer combo's, meer puzzels waar je echt moeite voor moet doen om eruit te komen, meer verschillende type enemies met eigen krachten en zwakheden, meer sfeervolle settings in verschillende tijdsperiodes. Toch ontkomt ook dit vervolgdeel er niet aan dat de gameplay repetitief wordt. Net iets teveel tijd gaat zitten in herhalende stukken spelplezier als zoeken naar verstopte kinderen, of op de automatische piloot grubbins en aanverwanten stukslaan. Dan gaat het ook steken als bossfights nauwelijks uitdagend zijn en het kaartsysteem niet voldoende uitgewerkt is om dat te gebruiken in plaats van de standaard-aanvallen. Wat deze stukken beter doet is dat het qua sfeer en humor consequent een prettig koddige toon vast weet te houden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042838346', 'num_games_owned': 5512, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1452873801}
review:
[i]Pour contenter ses fans les plus fervents, Double Fine Productions a d√©cid√© de donner une suite √† son RPG bourr√© d'humour et d'inventivit√©, j'ai nomm√© Costume Quest. Ce jeu est-il √† la hauteur des attentes des aficionados du premier volet ?[/i]

La f√™te d'Halloween est en danger car le mal√©fique dentiste Dr. Orel White a pactis√© avec un magicien du temps pour retourner dans le pass√© et supprimer tous les bonbons ! Les enfants sont bien d√©cid√©s √† ne pas se laisser faire et ayant √©chou√© √† stopper le dentiste dans le pass√©, ils sautent dans un portail temporel qui les am√®ne vers un futur dystopique o√π les bonbons sont interdits et o√π les robots dentaires patrouillent les rues. Avec l'aide de Lucy et Everett, leurs amis d√©sormais adultes, ils devront trouver un moyen de repartir dans le pass√© pour arr√™ter le petit Orel White avant qu'il ne soit trop tard ! http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=600359663 Costume Quest 2 est la suite directe du DLC Larvins sur Glace qui √©tait fourni gratuitement avec le premier opus. Si vous avez appr√©ci√© le d√©but des aventures de Wren, Reynold et leurs amis, vous devriez retrouver votre compte avec cette suite mais certains changement et ajouts pourraient vous d√©concerter, voire vous d√©cevoir. Et cela commence par le syst√®me de combat.

La question est : pourquoi changer une recette qui marche ? Dans le premier opus de la s√©rie, les combats fonctionnaient avec des QTE et c'est toujours le cas, mais ici nous n'avons droit qu'√† des QTE tim√©s. Oui il y en avait dans Costume Quest premier du nom mais c'√©tait plus diversifi√©, parfois on devait appuyer sur un bouton au bon moment, d'autres fois faire preuve de dext√©rit√© avec des boutons √† marteler, tout d√©pendait du costume port√© par notre personnage. Bien qu'ils aient gagn√© en dynamisme, √† pr√©sent les combats sont encore plus r√©p√©titifs qu'ils ne l'√©taient d√©j√† et cela enl√®ve de la "personnalit√©" √† chaque costume. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=599334448 Si on r√©ussit l'attaque on peut r√©-attaquer une seconde fois mais attention, le timing change et il faudra s'y habituer pour r√©ussir. Il y a toujours les attaques sp√©ciales pour couper √† la monotonie des combats et elles gardent quant √† elles un c√¥t√© humoristique bienvenu. 
Pour bloquer les attaques des ennemis, m√™me recette que pour le reste du combat : appuyer sur la touche correspondante au personnage en danger au bon moment. La seule nouveaut√© vient du fait que l'on peut d√©sormais contrer les attaques en maintenant la touche d'un des trois personnages, au hasard, en esp√©rant qu'on ait opt√© pour le bon, et rel√¢cher la touche au bon moment. C'est donc le jeu de hasard √† chaque fois.
La double-attaque, l'esquive et le contre sont des atouts qui ne nous seront pas donn√©s d√®s le d√©part, il faudra passer par quelques s√©ances d'entrainement au cours de l'aventure. Il est tout de m√™me dommage d'obtenir un "booster" de jauge d'attaque sp√©ciale uniquement vers la toute fin du jeu.

M√™me constat pour les timbres de combat. Mais si souvenez-vous c'√©taient de petits timbres que l'on attribuait √† nos personnages et qui conf√©raient un bonus en combat (plus de PV, r√©surrection, d√©g√¢ts sur les ennemis environnants...etc). Eh bien ces petits atouts qui permettaient aussi de personnaliser nos petits amis (quand on me dit "RPG" je m'attends √† un minimum de personnalisation) ont tout bonnement √©t√© remplac√©s par des cartes √† collectionner. Il est impossible de les attribuer directement √† un personnage, non, elles s'utilisent en plein combat et font par la m√™me occasion perdre un tour. Grrrr...

Aussi, les d√©veloppeurs ont cru bon d'ajouter un aspect dont on se serait pass√©s. En effet, apr√®s chaque combat on ne gu√©rit pas automatiquement et on [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=599827554]devra se diriger vers une fontaine pour boire de l'eau et rebooster ses PV[/url]. Je ne comprends pas ce choix qui plut√¥t que d'ajouter de la difficult√©, ce qui √©tait peut-√™tre l'intention des d√©veloppeurs, ajoute surtout de la lourdeur au vu des allers-retours √† effectuer. 

Concernant les fameux costumes, on a droit √† une nouvelle panoplie qui redouble d'inventivit√© pour apporter du neuf par rapport √† ce qui avait d√©j√† √©t√© fait. On obtient entre autres le costume d'un clown qui permettra de redonner de la vie √† tous les alli√©s gr√¢ce √† son attaque sp√©ciale, le pharaon qui peut ressusciter un alli√© mort au combat, le magicien et son attaque foudroyante ou encore le loup-garou et son attaque griffue. Il n'y a rien √† redire √† ce niveau-l√† car on retrouve cette originalit√© et cet humour bon enfant qu'on avait appr√©ci√© avec Costume Quest 1. C'est toujours un plaisir d'obtenir un nouveau costume et de visualiser la transformation et les attaques qu'il permet d‚Äôex√©cuter. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=600902955 Petite nouveaut√© : on peut am√©liorer nos costumes en achetant un objet aupr√®s d'un marchand chez qui on retrouve aussi les-dites cartes √† collectionner. L√† aussi, il n'y a qu'un objet par costume et il aurait peut-√™tre √©t√© sympathique de donner le choix entre plusieurs items qui apporteraient un bonus diff√©rent √† chaque fois histoire d'accentuer un peu le c√¥t√© RPG du titre. J'ai quand m√™me une petite r√©serve √† √©mettre sur les costumes car on en re√ßoit beaucoup sur la fin du jeu et on n'aura donc que peu de temps pour en profiter. Il aurait fallu mieux les r√©partir dans l'aventure car c'est quand m√™me l'atout majeur du jeu.

A nouveau le jeu est irr√©prochable au niveau de ses graphismes et de sa bande-son, je dirai m√™me que c'est le gage de qualit√© d'un jeu estampill√© "Double Fine Productions" car sur tous les jeux test√©s je n'ai jamais rien eu √† redire sur ces points-l√†. Les nouveaux d√©cors que nous allons visiter sont jolis, originaux et invitent toujours autant √† l'exploration pour r√©colter des bonbons et trouver des pi√®ces de costume. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=600903119]La petite carte est bien pratique pour s'y retrouver et distinguer aupr√®s de quelles maisons il faut encore aller r√©clamer des bonbons tout comme pour savoir si on a d√©got√© tous les secrets du niveau[/url]. La bande-son emprunte quelques th√®mes au premier jeu mais loin d'√™tre un d√©faut, c'est un plaisir de les r√©entendre au vu de leur qualit√©. Petit b√©mol, car oui il y a toujours un b√©mol qui vient tout g√¢cher, j'ai fait l'exp√©rience, comme beaucoup d'autres joueurs de baisses de framerates fr√©quentes alors m√™me que la configuration n'est pas en cause. Tout va bien du c√¥t√© artistique mais il faudrait un peu revoir ses bases au niveau technique pour mieux optimiser ses jeux √† l'avenir, n'est-ce pas Double Fine ?

Au final, j'ai malgr√© tout beaucoup appr√©ci√© cette suite de Costume Quest et je ne la juge pas tellement plus mauvaise que le premier jeu. Il y a juste au niveau du gameplay que quelques choix hasardeux ont √©t√© op√©r√©s, probablement pour renouveler l'exp√©rience parce qu'il faut l'avouer c'est tout de m√™me tr√®s r√©p√©titif et si on a jou√© le premier il y a peu mieux vaut s'accorder une pause de plusieurs mois avant d'enchainer. Mis √† part ces quelques d√©fauts les fans y trouveront leur compte avec un nouveau sc√©nario bien ficel√©, des environnements soign√©s regorgeant de cachettes, une bande-son toujours au top et surtout de super costumes !

[quote]Lisez d'autres avis sur ma page de curation : [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9002662/]Kitsune's Guide[/url][/b][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198066711942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1453084919}
review: Simple game and very nice for casual players like myself. Both this game and the first were good in my opinion, but I would recomend the first more than the second. Standard RPG style and I'm not sure why people are complaining about the graphics and small quirks, at least they fixed the bug where you couldn't clip through your team mates and get stuck at the end of the game. I only found one bug in the game and overall I would say that's pretty good. Takes about 5 hours to complete and 7 to get all the little hidden secrets. Add an extra 10 min to get some achievements and you're golden. 9/10, perfect for your run of the mill casual.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049701098', 'num_games_owned': 3699, 'num_reviews': 832, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1452591809}
review:
Where do I even begin? The Costume Quest games are unique little adventure titles that are sprinkled with RPG elements. Both games center around Halloween and, of course, the act of Trick-or-Treating. Costume Quest 2 picks up where its predecessor left off in terms of story, and it expands on all of the elements that players will be familiar with from the first game.

Without spoiling the main plot, I can say that you will take on the role of the brother/sister duo, Reynold and Wren. You will be tasked with regaining a talisman in order to save the world from a most disturbing fate of a candy-less future. Throughout the course of the game, you will have a few friends to accompany you on your journey; effectively turning your party from a duo to a trio. Having three party members comes in extremely handy across the numerous main and side quests that you will encounter. From knocking on doors to Trick-or-Treat and possibly running into enemies, to free roaming enemies, to helping find lost Hide n' Seek kids, the quests are enjoyably easy.

Each character is able to equip the various costumes that you will unlock whilst playing the game; from a wizard to a pharaoh, a clown and a werewolf, and many more. Each costume comes with its own unique attack, special ability, strength and weakness; all of which makes it essential that the player equips their party with the appropriate costume from area to area. You will earn experience points and candy (which is used as currency) after each battle. Candy can be spent on purchasing costume upgrades and special cards, which brings me to my next point.

The cards in this game act as battle stamps did in the original Costume Quest. If you never played that game, it's simply an extra element that introduces more factors into combat. Where one card can revive a player at 50% health, another card can cause a character to attack twice per turn. There are 45 in total, and you can equip 3 at a time; using them can often move a seemingly hopeless battle into your favor. There are some massively overpowered cards, such as one that will kill all minions, which cause the game to become rather easy at a certain point. However, the cards also have cool downs that expire after a set number of battles.

The soundtrack to this game is fantastic, and given that you rarely go back to previous areas the tunes just do not get old. The game mechanics are also extremely smooth, and the game itself runs at a stable 60 frames with no hitches. The graphics themselves are cute, fun and simple, and it's always exciting to see what your costume will look like in battle once you've unlocked a new one or have spent your candy on an upgrade for it.

Costume Quest 2 is an outstanding follow up to its debut title, in every way imaginable. Double Fine even put a few new elements into the combat system to give it a slightly fresher feel. The story is satisfying from start to finish, and it definitely doesn't let down its audience at the end. I highly recommend this game to fans of the original Costume Quest, or for anyone who is looking for a fresh, fun little adventure game that will last around 8-9 hours. Although I do suggest if you have not played Costume Quest 1, you pick that game up first so that you have more of an understanding of the story.

[h1]Rating: [b]4.0/5.0[/b] - Excellent, highly worth playing.[/h1]
The Horror Network [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28221963/]Curator[/url] | [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thehorrornetwork]Group[/url] Click for Gore

author: {'steamid': '76561197983684753', 'num_games_owned': 2444, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1416537097}
review:
Costume Quest 2 takes its predecessor and blows everything up by several orders of magnitude. More costumes, more characters, more and bigger areas, and new abilities make the second Costume Quest huge, but not -too- huge.

Wren and Reynold return, but both their friends from the original Costume Quest are... otherwise occupied shortly after the start of the game. For some reason, the monsters from the first game return to wreak havoc, and it's up to the twins to find help from whomever they can to fix what's gone wrong. Time travel plays a large part in Costume Quest 2, as Reynold & Wren jump from period to period of their little town's history (and future), encountering new friends in each period that fill a rotating third party slot.

A few of the original game's costumes return, but only as a reward if you've finished the first Costume Quest (which, by the way, you should). Most everything you can wear this time around is new, save for the previously unusable Candy Corn. Yes, you can be Candy Corn. Yes, it's basically hard mode if you do so, as you're not going to get much more than life advice and inspiration from whomever wears it.

As mentioned before, the regions in Costume Quest 2 feel a bit more expansive than those in the first game, and are often sectioned off by ability or interaction sequence requirements. This occasionally leads to feeling a bit lost or concerns you may have missed something, but it's rare that you can't backtrack to pick up something you passed up earlier. In fact, there are several things in each time period that require traveling back to them toward the game's end to retrieve with new costume abilities you've retrieved.

Despite the increased cast size, the story in Costume Quest 2 is just as well told as that of its predecessor, if not more so. The stakes feel adequately raised along with the game's other improvements without feeling like a ridiculous leap, and nothing is left dangling once all is said and done. The combat has been streamlined even further, with a few new features added for variety, and the stamps from last time have been replaced by a more useful and inviting collectable card system for buffs.

Basically, it's Costume Quest 2, but better. Which is a good thing. Get this. Play this. Candy Corn for lyfe.

Granted, they also referenced Blazing Saddles at one point, which may have introduced some bias on my part: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0zjCi_JH7dA

author: {'steamid': '76561198108183039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1452197576}
review:
Eh

Costume Quest 2 is the sequel to costume quest and it is pretty apparent as the game is pretty much a reskin of the first game with some gameplay changes

Story
The game continues off of the DLC (I think) of the previous game where you have to go and free the future from an oppressive dentist while going through the past. It's a bit weird (But then again, so was the story of the first game). However, I think the first game had more charm. It was about halloween and monsters rather than time traveling dentist dystopias. Not bad but not really good either

Gameplay
It's been gutted and changed. You still only have one basic attack and one special attack. However, now it involves timing and your damage depends on how close you hit it to the indicator. You can also block and counter although they have their own disadvantages. The one thing that I really didn't like is that the status cards are no longer applied to characters. Instead, you have to play them in game (which wastes a turn). This turns down the amount of customization each characters has (which is already pretty low) and I wish they really didn't change it.

Graphics/Performance
The game ran at a smooth 60 with a 4790K, GTX 970, and 16GB of ram. It looks much better than the previous game (Especially the water reflections). When you zoom into a character, it looks a bit.. cartoony but that's just the play style.

Final thoughts.
Overall, it's basically part 2 of a game with a different combat engine. It wasn't bad but there is just so much freaking combat and it gets old really fast. I was just rushing through to finish it and didn't want to do the side quests like the first game. Play it if you really want to

author: {'steamid': '76561198055553431', 'num_games_owned': 7573, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1452558277}
review:
[h1]E‚Äô di nuovo Halloween: tornano i gemelli Reynold e Wren a renderci pi√π leggera una festivit√† notoriamente Horror[/h1]

Il primo titolo era carico d‚Äôatmosfera. Una ventata d‚Äôaria fresca nel mercato, grazie alla messa a schermo di un mondo governato dai problemi dei pi√π piccini, ma affrontato con intelligenza e con quella spensieratezza avulsa ormai alle grosse produzioni videoludiche. Le meccaniche d‚Äôispirazione jRpg‚Äî seppur non ricche di profondit√† ‚Äî facevano del titolo Double Fine un piacevole intrattenimento. 
Costume Quest 2 ci propone stavolta una storia che trae spunto da un elemento tipicamente sci-fi: il viaggio temporale, mantenendo sempre l‚Äôambientazione tipica della festivit√† anglosassone del 31 ottobre. Inoltre il titolo viene confezionato con un occhio di riguardo alla parte tecnica e grafica, ora pi√π curata.    

[b]Storia:[/b] ambientata subito dopo l‚Äôespansione, del primo capitolo, Grubbins on Ice. Vaghiamo nei meandri di un limbo ricco di portali, raggiunto in seguito al combattimento con Axaria. Il nemico stavolta √® meno ‚Äúspaventoso‚Äù, e veste i panni del Dott. White. Un dentista ‚Äî decisamente diverso dal Dott. Stu di una Notte da Leoni ‚Äî col pallino dell‚Äôigiene orale. Orel ha deciso di cancellare la Carie abolendo il rito del bottino dei dolciumi, e mandare in ginocchio l‚Äôindustria dolciaria. 
A noi l‚Äôarduo compito di ricalcare le orme di Marty McFly per impedire il disastro‚Ä¶

[b]Gameplay:[/b] 2 novit√†. La prima √® rappresentata dalle Figurine che sostituiscono i francobolli. Quindi niente Perk ma consumabili da lanciare in-game durante le battaglie. Ci sono comunque delle carte speciali da acquisire per potenziare le Skills base dei costumi, ma non sono dotate di potenziamenti trasferibili come nella prima interazione. 
La seconda novit√† √® costituita da mosse e contromosse da imparare nel corso dell‚Äôavventura presso il nostro maestro di combattimento.
Ritroviamo alcune missioni secondarie identiche, come il gioco del nascondino.
I combattimenti sono sempre a turni su un campo di battaglia idealmente suddiviso in 2. I nostri protagonisti contano ancora su meccaniche rette da semplici Q.T.E: un attacco base, una contromossa, e un contatore (legato al bimbo e non al costume) che va alimentandosi di turno in turno fino a rendere disponibile una mossa speciale (d‚Äôoffesa o di ripristino della salute). 
Ad accompagnarci ci sar√† anche un costume non in grado d‚Äôattaccare ma di sciorinare battute ironiche, che vi strapperanno in pi√π d‚Äôuna occasione una risata. Forse per√≤ sarebbe stato gradito un campionario pi√π robusto di frasi ‚Äî soprattutto in considerazione dell‚Äôachievement da sbloccare qualora decidiate di mantenere sempre nel vostro party Candy ‚Äî che si ripeteranno, ma √® un peccato veniale.
Anche stavolta: saremo chiamati al rischioso trick-or-treat; recupero dei pezzi per creare gli abiti (pi√π semplici da trovare); usare le importanti abilit√† di alcuni costumi durante la fase esplorativa ‚Äî con un concept tipico degli action-gdr isometrici ‚Äî per rendere accessibili alcuni passaggi della mappa, e irretire gli npc.

[b]I.A:[/b] le maggiori possibilit√† offerte al giocatore (carte, mosse, e contromosse) non sono stimolate da una tattica nemica ricalibrata sulle novit√†. Nel primo capitolo forse c‚Äôerano un paio di Boss Fight in cui imbastire una lieve strategia, tenendo conto delle abilit√† dei costumi per sfruttare il modo di combinare i vari perk: qui invece il livello degli scontri √® decisamente sbilanciato in nostro favore, basti pensare che si pu√≤ fare tranquillamente a meno dei nuovi power-up.
Certo, stavolta, non c‚Äô√® il recupero automatico della barra vitale, ma basta abbeverarsi presso le numerose fontane (o addentare qualche caramella) per ripristinare subito la salute della compagnia. 
L‚Äôunico modo per renderci la vita un po' complicata ‚Äî ma non migliora certo la scarsit√† di base dei pattern d‚Äôattacco nemici ‚Äî √® portarsi dietro Candy (che non attacca), riducendo il party offensivo a 2 elementi‚Ä¶ Ma comunque alla lunga i combattimenti risulteranno ripetitivi.

[b]Comparto grafico:[/b] sempre molto belle le animazioni dei costumi, sia quando prendono vita all‚Äôinizio dello scontro, sia durante l‚Äôespletazione delle mosse speciali. Il Mondo di gioco √® vario (un villaggio tipicamente del Sud degli States, una palude con alligatori, un quartiere d‚Äôispirazione francese, una distopica Repugia, degli incredibilmente affollati sotterranei‚Ä¶), e pi√π curato nei dettagli. Anche la paletta cromatica √® pi√π ricca nelle tonalit√†, rispetto al predecessore.

[b]Comparto tecnico:[/b] di nuovo il Cel-Shading, ancora un buon lavoro sul fronte ottimizzazione, con frame costanti e una richiesta hardware minimale. Sono presenti stavolta maggiori effetti speciali, texture pi√π rifinite, e particellari pi√π convincenti per l‚Äôacqua.

[b]Comparto audio:[/b] piacevoli i temi musicali, buona l‚Äôeffettistica. Il doppiaggio in inglese √® decisamente superiore alla versione italiana, che non riesce a restituire sempre la verve comica originale.

[b]Commento finale:[/b] Costume Quest 1 era magico. Un po' grezzo, ma alimentato da un‚Äôatmosfera tipica pi√π di un film d‚Äôavventura, con tematiche anche importanti. Questo secondo capitolo perde un pochino quello smalto, pi√π per essere arrivato cronologicamente dopo: non c‚Äô√® l‚Äôelemento novit√†, e le tematiche dei pi√π piccoli ora fanno da cornice (i mostri, le caramelle, i bulli‚Ä¶). La trama principale trae linfa vitale da un diverso spunto narrativo, invero anche efficace.
Se il primo titolo per√≤ riusciva a portare un imprinting narrativo ‚Äî sulla carta ‚Äî poco avvezzo ad un videogame, il secondo punta pi√π a migliorare quanto di buono fatto vedere in precedenza: ampliando il ventaglio dell‚Äôofferta videoludica, anche con meccaniche action senza tuttavia approfondire troppo; curando maggiormente i dettagli tecnici e grafici. 
E‚Äô un titolo caratteristico, ha una sua personalit√† e atmosfera, ma non riesce purtroppo a fare il salto di qualit√† che videoludicamente era lecito aspettarsi dopo la prima esperienza.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976081787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1527299927}
review:
If you have played the first game then you know exactly what to expect from this game. Just like the first game, if you love the classic turn based RPG's and comical adventures, then you should really enjoy this shorter game.

First off, the game continues immediately where the first games DLC ended. Literally starts at that cliffhanger ending. After you have saved Halloween and your friends, you enter a portal to return home but end up coming back a few months earlier. As you start Trick or Treating again you find out about a plot to get rid of the holiday and its costumes. So now you are on a quest to save Halloween again! Unfortunately, the game is really short. It is not too much bigger the the DLC. In my opinion, this would of been a great DLC instead of a sequel.

The levels in the game still have that incredibly detailed cartoonish feel. The level of detain in each area is outstanding. However, there are fewer locations and they are not as diverse. The look of the costumes all look much smoother and better detailed in combat. However, the costumes outside of combat do not look as "horribly made" as the first game. That was one of my favorite elements to the game. The horrible taped up costumes transforming into these colossal realistic versions.

Speaking of costumes, all the costumes you received in the first game are all gone. So you have to acquire a new set. This time around, the costumes are more traditional to the holiday. The superhero and candy corn are back but now there are costumes like ghosts, wolfman, clowns, etc. One of the changes made to this game is that the costumes can be upgraded to make them a bit more powerful.

Also changed is the combat. You no longer have different activations for each costume. Everyone has the same attack activation. However, they have assigned a specific button for each character. so the first character has to use button 1 for their moves and the others use button 2 and 3 respectively. From watching the trailer, you see that the combat is changed up a bit as well. You have to hit the button a the precise moment to do more damage. Later on this will be upgraded to give you two attacks. And the block will work that way as well, to include a counter attack. Stamps are gone from the game and cards are now introduced. The cards can be used in battle to give you character a boost or hurt your enemy. But they all have a cool-down timer that is about 3 fights (not rounds).

Other than that, the game is exactly like the first game. If you enjoyed the first and the DLC, then you should enjoy this little conclusion to the set.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153985977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1447701299}
review:
Just finished the game.In short, this game has a personal style.

Strongpoints:
-The story is simple but the details are intricate.The past causes correspond perfectly to the future ending.
-And one thing interesting about a time travel is that you have many  possibilities to reverse the whole story.
That inspires me to move on and hold on, though some quests & acheivements are miserable to complete.
-The graphic style just like CQ1,I like it very much.
-And I also love the music in CQ1&2.Whenever you guys release a soundtrack I will definitely buy one!
-Comparing to CQ1, this game makes NPCs much more alive &humorous.Alway enjoy talking with them!And quests need you to do that!Or you will miss some quests,espeically the solar system costume.

Shortcomings:
-Some quests & acheivements are miserable to complete.
-Sometime battle speed & waiting the door to open run slowly when I use my laptop to play it;
-Some costume are interesting,but others just look like those old ones in CQ1 with different surfaces.
-Can not avoid the repeated quest &story pattern in CQ1.The secrect's idea is new,but it is boring sometimes.
-It has a much more complex battle system&cards usage,so it takes me a lot of  time to get used to. But you don't have to use cards to win the final battle,so what's the meaning of cards?(except collection)

RatingÔºö 7/10

I love this game&Iook forward to CQ3!Hope CQ3 has a obvious improvement.
( CQ2's DLC is also welcomed :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043924730', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1627442929}
review:
I really liked the first Costume Quest, but I like this one even more! The gameplay has evolved a little bit, with special moves and strengths/weaknesses giving the battles a bit more strategy than they had before. I'm not really a hardcore RPG player, so I wouldn't have wanted them to make things too complicated, but it's enough that it felt like a step up from the first game.

Story-wise, I actually found this entry to push things just a bit further. The story takes more dramatic twists and turns I found far less predictable, the characters felt more "far-out" and less suburban, and some of the later story moments featuring the antagonist made me laugh out loud more than any one moment from the previous game.

If you'd like a not-too-hard, fun little romp that brings back all those warm-fuzzies of Trick or Treating as a kid, you can't do better than either Costume Quest game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073957513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1446527754}
review:
So I can see why Costume Quest 2 is considered not as good as the first. So here is what they did right Vs. What they did wrong.

The right

1. They kept it cute and charming.
2. The story is interesting.
3. The time travel mechanic was done well. 
4. Seeing the characters from past to future was clever. 
5. The new and old enemy designs are cool.
6. The new costumes were innovative and well thought out. 
7. Using Creepy Treat Cards for a benefit in battle was a good change of pace.
8. Certain enemies are stronger or weaker to different costumes. 

The Wrong

1. The change in battle style was unnecessary and was many times just difficult to use. 
2. The ending basically ret¬∑cons everything you do. Making what happened in the first one not even matter.
3. Only 3 of the Creepy treat cards are useful from my point of view. 

What they should have done.

If they changed the fight style the way it is with certain enemies being stronger or weaker to certain types of costumes. Then to balance it with the annoying combat style they should have made it to where you use a turn in the middle of battle to swap your costume. Similar to switching a party member in certain RPGs. 

Still this game took me about 9 hours to complete, it's not that expensive. Granted mine was a gift, and it's fun enough to replay. I give it 3.5 out 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198040446493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1446651214}
review:
Divertente e rilassante come il primo capitolo, si notano gradevoli miglioramenti alla grafica e al sistema di battaglia, una cosa che non √® cambiata √® la lunghezza del gioco : purtroppo decisamente corta anche volendo soddisfare tutti gli elementi secondari.

La storia, sempre molto fiabesca, riprende qualche tratto delle vicende giocate nel primo, senza renderlo per√≤ una necessit√† in termini di comprensione. Il gameplay nei paesaggi √® meno statico e le interazioni con gli npc pi√π utili e poco scontate. I costumi sono pi√π di prima anche se non di molto, per√≤ la possibile di potenziarli e di trovare delle particolari combo con le carte li rende alla fine dinamici,  nelle battaglie sono state introdotte delle azioni aggiuntive ai normali "attacca" e "difendi" rendendo anche pi√π viva la situazione.

Ovviamente √® un gioco che consiglio di giocare, in quanto stacca un po dalle solite giganti lavorazioni che rappresentano un po "il grosso del mercato videoludico", per apprezzare una bella storia in un bel gioco, non servono rendering da cinema.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018455391', 'num_games_owned': 2299, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1665434099}
review:
I don't want to hate on this game. I love the story. I love the characters. I love the dialogue. I love the art style.

I hate grindy JRPG combat.

Where 75% of your game time is spent in combat, it should be engaging; not a throwback to the NES era. After my fourth fight, I found myself avoiding enemies whenever possible. Not because of the difficulty, but because each fight is another 2-3 minute delay from that quest item that I was looking for in the game world. I challenge anyone to convince me that this style of combat makes the game fun.

If there were a quarter as many enemies, and you used puzzle-solving to overcome them, this game would gel a lot better.

I love DoubleFine, and hoped that the sequel would improve this, but it didn't. It's not one I'll be finishing. I finally rage quit it when I forgot what objective I was going for; because another QTE fight interrupted me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031415810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1446637259}
review:
I am a huge fan of Double Fine Productions!
Having 100% The first Costume Quest, I wanted to do that on this game too!


Pros. and Cons.

[u]Pros[/u]
+ Funny dialouge!
+ Great Story
+ Awesome battle concept (Using costume to transform) 
+ Graphics are SO CUTE, The Design is awesome!
+ The timing sequences

[u]Cons.[/u]
- Too short
- Wanted to see more special attacks on characters

If you love Halloween, RPGS and various types of candies, PLAY THIS!

author: {'steamid': '76561198098809106', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1446529819}
review: Finished Costume Quest and bought Costume Quest 2 immediately. This game was fun to play. Some quests were easy to do, others were hard - which required a certain amount of time to explore the whole area. What I don't like about this game is the combat system. I am more on the Costume Quest combat system, which has a variety of different combat combos. This game is just "pressing (the number) at the right time" and done. The graphic was better then the first one, the story took place in different timelines, which was pretty interesting. There was not as many bosses compared to the first one. This made my gameplay less fun. Overall, it is worth to buy and play, but do not expect the combat system to be good.

review: A charming, short RPG that is perfect for all ages. review:
Da ich das erste Costume Quest bereits geliebt habe, musste ich mir den Nachfolger nat√ºrlich auch noch g√∂nnen. Ich finde es sogar einen Zacken besser als den Vorg√§nger und habe ihn einfach mal an einem Tag durchgesuchtet. 

Es macht unheimlich viel Spa√ü, die Kost√ºme sind toll designet und die Story finde ich auch super. An das Kampfsystem musste ich mich erst gew√∂hnen, aber sobald man den Dreh raushat, ist das auch kein Problem mehr. Am besten waren dabei die "Spr√ºche" von Candy Corn (probiert den "Bonbon Modus" schon im ersten Run, ist gar nicht so schwer :D)!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018595337', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1446334967}
review:
After completing Costume Quest 1 earlier this year, I was looking forward to playing 2 and grabbed it in the Halloween sale. If you want to know about that one, I suggest you go read my review on it as a lot is similar.

Just like the first game, this is a wonderfully quirky game with so many jokes that I was frequently laughing out loud. In particular, the Candy Corn costume always made me giggle, despite reading the joke 50+ times. There was less meta-humour in this one than the first, but it was never boring.

The combat is very similar to the first, but improved overall. There is now only a single form of attack (compared to various QTE-styles in the first game), but they've added additional mechanics like countering that add another dimension to combat. They also added 'actor types' which are a basic form of strengths and weaknesses split between 3 classes; it sounds odd, but it's easy to understand and it adds a tactical edge.

Like with CQ1, however, I did tend to stick to the first costume you get and swap out the third as I went (the second was always Candy Corn for the achievement), but as the visuals are interesting and the cutscene moves are now skippable, that isn't too big an issue.

One issue I should mention is this game was very easy. I only failed perhaps two fights (and one was because of a glitch), but I did do some grinding in places for XP and candy (in-game currency). The boss fights were very straight forward and fit SO MUCH better into the flow of the game compared to the almost puzzle-like ones in CQ1.

The story is clever and moves on from the first with just enough nods and references to 1 to induce nostalgia. They would, however, go over the heads of anyone who hasn't played 1, so definitely play that before this. It is a sequel in every sense.

This was a fantastic game that kept all the good feelings I had for 1 and added to them, creating its own individual experience that fits beautifully into the Costume Quest universe.

Well worth your time, money and laughter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086333390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1446287446}

author: {'steamid': '76561198092969507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1446183507}
review: Enjoyed the first one, I played on PSN, and the second one picks right up where it left off. I powered through it in 3 days. Absolutley worth 5$ on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129107378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1452577812}
review: Costume Quest and Costume Quest 2 are adorable Halloween themed games. You can feel a bit of that "made for kids" theme, but it's still enjoyable by adults. The controls are easy to manage (but an official Xbox/Steam controller is a must), the art is wonderful, the music is good but not overbearing, the story is cute, and there are a few chuckle moments. While I recommend them both, I do think 1 is the better of the two, but that doesn't make 2 any less good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990947284', 'num_games_owned': 5370, 'num_reviews': 1354, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1513291267}
review:
Incredible. This successor to Costume Quest is simply amazing and does everything right which the first game didn't (Skippable cutscenes and battle intros, Sprinting with every costume, etc.). 

The storyline is actually a bit weaker than in the first game, but the improved gameplay makes up for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049733975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1445650359}
review: This game has some technical issues. It has the same pacing problems as the first game. Overall, though, I enjoyed it more than the first one. The story comes close to milkman conspiracy levels of weirdness.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971411597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1441625114}
review:
The main difference between the two Costume Quest games mostly lies in story and settings, and not much on gameplay that is very similar.

Since I really liked the first episode, I should have appreciated this one; because once I have found an engaging gameplay, I really like to play it again in sequels. But in a strange way, Costume Quest 2 had a complete opposite effect on me.

Maybe it's because of the long launch, the counter-intuitive main screen, the "knock on doors for candies or combat" part or the "too-fine / too hard" controls, I don't know. I felt the pleasurable experience from the first Costume Quest somewhat vanished.

Even if I do appreciate hard and punishing games that presents tough challenges, doesn't help you a bit, and reward your efforts with mastery; I wasn't expecting Costume Quest 2 to challenge me that much when I only wanted a laid-back, relaxed play time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970878896', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1445287386}
review: If you enjoyed the first Costume Quest on the surface this one feels and plays pretty much the same, so you'll enjoy it too.  That being said this one is much shorter and simpler than the first one.  My 100% completion time was about 7 hours.  Graphically the game looks a bit better, but the quests are simpler, the costumes less nuanced, and the battles too simplified.  I was really excited for Costume Quest 2 after enjoying the first one and am really disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1443041105}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is the second game in this series developed by Double Fine Productions.  You play the role of two twin siblings, Reynold and Wren.  The game follows on from the original game in the story and offers much of the same game play elements.  The game has been released on PS3, 360, PS4, Xbox One, WiiU and all of the PC platforms. 

Like I said, the gameplay is very much the same as the first game, you travel around in your party exploring the world and encounter enemies, which you battle in a turn based fight scene. These fight scenes have an essence of QTEs in them, so if you hit the button at exactly the right time, you'll either do more damage, or block more damage. As you venture throughout the game, you will discover new and interesting costumes to wear - each costume has its own special ability and unique style of play.  There is some real interesting costumes to find, my favorite is the Clown costume, which acts as your early game healer, but you also have tanky classes and damage dealing classes like in other RPG games. 

Graphically, Costume Quest 2 is identical to the original. The art style is beautiful though, I loved the stylized world that you are put in and all of the characters just look gorgeous.  The animation in cut scenes and in the game are second to none too.  The game is so well optimized that pretty much any rig can play this in its full glory. 

The plot is similar to the first game too; you are out to stop Dr. Orel White who has taken over the world and aims to bring an end to the holiday, Halloween! Obviously being the candy loving kids we all are, we can't let that happen and you must stop him.  With an element of time travel to be seen, there is some very interesting plot points throughout the game, and this comes with the inclusion of some brilliantly comical moments along the way too. 

Sadly the game is not voice acted - for me I was hoping it would be given how popular the first game was, but this doesn't take away any of the charm the game has. You can pretty much imagine how each of the characters in the game would sound, and the animation of them all with the facial expressions aids this ten fold too. 

Costume Quest 2 has moments of difficulty; some of the quests are not easily figured out and you have to put a bit of thought into them, or working out where to go next in order to progress the game. Not to mention the boss battles can also get quite intensive too; I actually had to spend a fair amount of time grinding my characters up a few levels just so they were on par with the difficulty of the bosses I was facing. This is by no means a bad thing as with each fight you win, you also get the chance to win a card, which will have a unique effect that you can use in a battle, such as avoiding attacks, doing double damage, or sometimes actually out right killing an enemy no questions asked!

That brings me onto the level design, every single level in Costume Quest has absolutely tons of areas to explore and items to find. You have to destroy typical game world items in order to find the games currency, candy. The candy can the be spent at the vendors which are scattered around the world to purchase costume upgrades, or the above mentioned special effect cards. Each level also has a handful of side quests which you can complete, granting further experience points and candy as rewards. I would recommend people actually focus on the side quests before progressing in the main quest just so you keep up at the right level compared to the enemies. Some of the side quests are linked to the main quest; but a lot can be skipped over if you really want to. 

A full playthrough with completing the majority of the side quests at a leisurely pace took me just under nine hours to complete which is actually a bit of a jump in length compared to the original which only took me five hours to finish. Again though, there is no reason at all to play through Costume Quest 2 for a second time apart from maybe mopping up a few achievements if that's your jam. Much like the first, I would really of liked to have seen a "New Game+" mode just to squeeze a couple more hours out of it, and maybe introducing local co-op too, that would be an almost perfect addition given that you play as twins the whole way through the game. 

I had virtually no technical issues in my run through. I was able to play at 4K resolution with a steady 60 FPS the whole time. I did run into a few bugs where you could actually walk through some walls when interacting with items on the other side of the wall such as ladders and chests, but there are no real game breaking bugs to be found. I played the game with a controller given the amount of QTEs in the game, I felt that would be a better option, but this can just as easily be played with keyboard and mouse too. 

To sum up, I think Costume Quest 2 does exactly the same as the Costume Quest just bigger and better. I can only hope that there is going to be a third game in this series as it just gets better and better with each release. I will go as far to say this is one of my favorite games I have played this year so it gets a strong recommendation from me!

[b][u] Tom's Score Card[/u][/b]
1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
[b][u]4) Highly recommended[/u][/b]
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/275180

author: {'steamid': '76561198195989650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1441671170}
review: There are new cool costumes, and the characters and story are still awesome. The problem is that now you don't have auto heal after battles. Walking back and forth from save points is a little bit annoying. The cards are now to be used in battles, they are not equpments anymore. And all the costumes have the same quick time events in order to land a good attack or defend. I really wanted to like this game, but it was pretty disappointing after such a great experience on the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992208010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1435574456}
review:
Brilliant game, but flawed.
It's hard to review this without the caveat "but if you're a kid".
If you're a kid, probably all the design decisions in this game make sense.
However, if you're over 7, you're going to feel pretty frustrated at times.

I would have no problem recommending this to any of my nephews.
But given that a greater part of the audience is older, and it wouldn't've taken much to accomodate that (a difficulty level selector, for starters), it's definitely not without shortcomings.

First up, the good:
* better than the original - more nuanced battles (once you get further in), better mechanics, the cards are actually fun and exciting to use
* great atmosphere - if you like double-fine's style, this is their best "feel"-wise since Psychonauts, and feels a little similar to grim fandango at points
* better use of costumes - this time, only certain costumes can perform certain actions, and the game takes on shades of (albiet very easy) adventure games - which is great
* Great humour
* Great and innovative level design
* fun!!!

Now, the annoying:
* some random-as cards - "peanut butter bombs" is basically a "win this battle" card. Really weird.
* Bad keyboard choices for PC. Holding WASD direction keys in tandem with 'Q' (required for certain portions of the game) results in stuck keyboard errors on most PS2 keyboards. Not to mention it gets a bit cramped getting your hands in there like that.
* Mouse support is bizarre, and terrible. You can either use mouse or keyboard on the menus, but using mouse, for example, on the creepy cards menu results in weird glitchy selection.
* Inconsistent keyboard use. Depending on the menu/area of game you're in, 'returning' can either be 'esc', 'q', or space. There is no way around this. Also, regardless of how you've set up your keys, the arrow buttons will be used for certain menu actions.


And the bad:

* respawning. Monsters respawn when you leave a level/game, meaning you can basically grind for candy, making getting 'all the stuff' not strategic, but basically boring. Certain candy-hit items like letterboxes etc also respawn their candy. This took away from  the game in a big way, including leaving the player without a feeling of progression.
* no difficulty selection - the game presents little challenge - which is a shame due to the amount of mechanics thrown into the combat
* ridiculously easy end boss


To fix this game they would need to tweak their PC version a little more, throw in a difficulty selection at the start of a game, and basically get rid of the respawning monsters. Then it might actually be worth getting that really cool Creepy card, just to win that final battle.

Still, fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994926259', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 811, 'last_played': 1415241471}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999935168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1189, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1435276098}
review:
If you like the first game you should like this one because it is basically more of the same. The only thing I don't like about this one are the timed attacks in combat. It reminds me of Super Mario rpg and that was about the only thing I didn't like in that game. It's fine though I guess but one other thing that bothers me is that combat takes a long time because you have a follow up attack on each attack that you can do, enemies have a lot of hp, and all attacks from you and the enemies take longer than in most games. Although I wish combat was quicker, it isn't too bad, especially since this is the type of game you only ever really play through once. I like the first game better because it seemed like it had more detail to the story and the world. This one seems to be a toned down version of the game, but it is still a fun game in its own right. Some of the reviews I've seen didn't like this game for whatever reason but like I said its basically about the same formula as the first one.

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198043327000', 'num_games_owned': 1108, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1435160982}
review:
Well as huge Costume Quest fan i had to play this one since i did love the first one, and right now i'm having some mix feelings about it, i finish the game a couple hours ago and i'm not going to lie, CQ2 is pretty much a DLC from the first one since mission, quest even some costumes are the same. The few adjustments that have been made are of little but if you enjoyed Costume Quest and wanted more of the same, you'll enjoy this. 

The story in Costume Quest 2 revolves around a group of kids who must use time travel to deal with the results of a obsessed mother with keeping her son's teeth in perfect condition and with that you will save Halloween. In order to complete this, you will have to knock on doors, jump here and there, grab some costumes part to make a full costume. 

The combat system is the same as in Costume Quest, the only difference is now you can block easily, counter, a nice upgrade here. Still there is one annoying thing that they haven't fix yet, the fact you can't speed up the QTE and battle, trust me you will have to battle LOT and battle are bit slow, this would help a ton. 

Overall, good game if you enjoyed the first one you will most likely enjoy this one, but bare in mind is semi DLC. 

~ 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198012902673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 380, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1435025579}
review:
Costume Quest 2's gameplay changes from the first game are for the better. The rock-paper-scissors mechanics add a layer of complexity, and the follow-up hits and counters are better than the first game's ways of adding interactivity to the fights.

Beyond that, it plays pretty much the same. If you liked the first, you'll enjoy this one as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028261016', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1633993306}

(Story only gets a 9 cause I would like the game to be longer, like a JRPG about Halloween kind of longer :D)

author: {'steamid': '76561198026724823', 'num_games_owned': 1526, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1445637924}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999737264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1434267862}
review:
An extremely dull sequel.  This is the worst kind of boring tripe, it improves on nothing and adds next to nothing (apart from an almost useless map).  It feels just like an expansion pack for the first game.  This is a pure "phone it in" sequel.  The combat is almost identical but they managed to make it worse since you have to now pick a sticker rather than have them on your characters.  The enemies are blander than the first game and your own attacks are duller.  One character even refuses to fight.  It also shamelessly repeats the gameplay from the first game, hint to Double Fine, finding six kids that are NOT hidden at all is not fun.  

All too quickly I became bored and avoided combat.  This is terrible sequel that is mired in its own blandness.

I bought it in the sale and still feel ripped off.  Buy the first game instead (this game assumes you've played that one anyway).

author: {'steamid': '76561198151698234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1433955731}
review:
J'aime:

- l'humour du jeu ^^

-l'ambiance globale et les costumes rigolos 

j'aime moins:
- tr√®s facile, pas de challenge.
- les combats sous forme de QTE

En conclusion un rpg fun sans prise de t√™te, pas tr√®s long. Les succ√©s steam sont aussi simples √† r√©aliser mais attention, il y en a un qui peut √™tre loup√©.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995200857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1432276467}
review:
Mainly recommended for fans of the first game. In some ways it's a little disappointing that this is so close to the original game. Combat is a little bit better and the treats cards are more useful but overall exactly the same as the first game. The format of going to different areas and trick or treating is the same as well but I find it very fun and don't mind it at all. Also, I'm a little surprised that the game didn't expand into new territory in terms of holiday themes. The first game was obviously Fall but the DLC Grubbins on Ice was set in the Winter and had Christmas themes and references. So I expected this to continue that theme and have Spring themes or Easter references, something like that but instead it returns to the original Halloween Fall theme. Which makes a lot of sense I suppose since it is the original premise for the game and where most of the themes come from.

That said though, when the game was starting I was sort of disappointed in the way it looked like the story was being set up. A dentist wants to end Halloween and make candy illegal so everyone can have clean teeth so it's up to the kids to save Halloween. Are you kidding me? That's the most cliched holiday plot I've ever heard. So, I had a bad taste in my mouth starting out. However, I was really won over. The writing is very good. The side quests have really good plots and are fun to do and everything about the cliched main storyline ending up being better than I expected. The evil dentist ends up being a very tragic figure and ends up having a great character arc.

If you're a fine of Double Fine and their writing style this is a very fun game and despite how much it repeats the first oen the combat and overall gameplay is a lot of fun. To really appreciate it you have to have played the first one though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198176977679', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1427022345}
review: The combat for this game was changed up from the predecessor, which I guess a part of me liked. In this one, timing is the focus more than anything. I'd say it's a lot more of a challenging game than the first one, but still just as fun. The story was pretty cool too, time-travel and all. I'd say 8.5/10 is a decent enough score for this game, although I think it's neither better nor worse than the first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144835319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1418785349}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028441242', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1427986159}
review:
Costume Quest 2 is the sequel to the original turn-based soft RPG made by Double Fine around 2012. It continues the story of the two twins Reynold and Wren exactly where the last DLC for the first title ended: after managing to return to their own time, they must resort to time travel to stop the evil plan of Dr. Orel White, a dentist bent on destroying Halloween for good and rule the whole world.

Gameplay-wise, Costume Quest 2 doesn't differ that much from the first game's formula, but manages to tweak several elements along the way. The combat is the feature that recived the greatest overhaul: while the whole turn-based RPG fare with QTEs for extra damage is still there, now the health of the characters doesn't refill itself after combat (forcing you to visit fountains scatterd in the areas or consume a stock of candy to heal up), your attacks can either be nice or amazing and dish out damage accordingly regarding when precisely you press the attack button, you can defend yourself and try to counterattack via QTEs, chains of attacks are available and enemies tend to hurt a bit more and some will respawn to free roam the streets again. The sequel also introduces three classes for enemies and costumes alike, Tech, Wizard and Monster: there is a little weakness/resistance system going on between each to put some emphasis on gear and target choice. Finally, this time around  you can actually buy upgrades for your costume, which either empower the character's attacks or add some useful side effects. While these novelties make the first encounters you'll face very challenging and requiring some demanding good timing, as you progress through Costume Quest 2 and gain the roughly ten levels there are to get you'll become more and more powerful and get used to the QTEs general flow, to the point of making most of the battles trivial (the bosses in this game are especially disappointing because, unlike the first game, they don't display any unique gimmick and all boil down to a very easy dps race).

Aside from the combat, eveything you left in Costume Quest returns in the sequel as you'd expect: in the roughly three main areas you'll visit in the second game there a lot of doors to knock on for trick or treating, obstacles to overcome with the right costume, collectable cards that give you a pletora of effects in combat and a huge crowd of NPCs to interact with. The writing is still funny and charming as you remembered.

In short, Costume Quests 2 is a fairly good attempt as a sequel and feel free to buy it if you enjoyed the first game

author: {'steamid': '76561198079781379', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1512835783}

author: {'steamid': '76561198083072026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1422925530}
review:
Costume Quest 2 has all the charm and humor of CQ1; I found myself laughing out loud a lot. However, the combat is not only just as tedious as the last time, there also seems to be more of it. There's also a huge difficulty spike in the last third of the game that's almost unfair - it's not really fun to hammer away at three enemies with twice your hit points every time you enter a battle. Its charm, however, outweighs that tedium, especially if played with a friend next to you and/or in short play sessions.

Also, the graphics are great - the water deserves a special mention, I spent quite a bit of time stopping to look at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027942416', 'num_games_owned': 779, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1422328467}
review:
Why wait for Halloween to enjoy Halloween!? Now with Costume Quest 2 you can get your trick or treating goodness any time you want on Windows/Mac and LINUX!


Don awesome costumes!

Fight bad guys!

Save halloween!



All without risking a single cavity thanks to Double Fine's virtual candy technology! Order now for your personal copy of Costume Quest 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992694498', 'num_games_owned': 2769, 'num_reviews': 450, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1415194124}
review:
Costume quest is finally back. It surprised me, i was not expecting Costume quest 2. I loved the first game and i instantly fell in love with this one. Again you play as the very cute little kids (i know it sounds creepy coming from a grown man) and running in halloween costumes fighting giant angry moles and snails.

The game didn‚Äòt change much. The core is the same. Simple rpg mechanics, collecting candies, leveling up, collecting new costumes to become a three-headed hotdog. 

The combat system changed a little, you now need to press a button when attacking to do more damage and same goes for defending ‚Äì press the button in time to receive less damage. And there‚Äòs fountains where you can restore your health after the fights. I heard people complaining about it, but i don‚Äòt see the problem here, fountains are always close to you, it‚Äòs easy to go and refill you hp. Other than that the game is same as the previous one ‚Äì great. Yes it‚Äòs very short, but i don‚Äòt know if i would want to play it for 30 hours.

Double fine has done a fine job here. Costume quest 3 next halloween maybe?

author: {'steamid': '76561198016594180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1592797819}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035837834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1420464327}
review:
I've played both games now and gotten 100% completion in both. Overall I enjoyed 2 on it's own merits, but I feel it is a lesser outing than the first. The change in both the battle system and the cards was unwelcome. I'd much rather have passive abilities i can choose and stick with than having to constantly juggle the 8-9 useful cards constantly. Real pain when you forget that a good card is off cooldown. 

The super secret is kinda neat and you'll feel pretty awesome if you figure it out yourself. 

The overall story was short (I did 1 playthrough, and got everything in that one playthrough and did it in 9 hours) but was well written and funny. 

I'd have to say try it but don't go into it thinking it would be like the first. It's not. Worthwhile on it's own but lacklustre compared to the original. 

Also thinking a sequel might help a bit, least for lengthening playtime, more achievements and maybe fixing the battle system? Granted not sure where they could take a sequel, but I think Double Fine could find a way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041014066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1420375062}
review:
The Problem with sequels is that you compare it to the first game. To me Costume Quest 2 on its own is a decent and good game but in case you played the first one, you might have mixed feelings. 

I played both games. My opinion: I don't understand why they changed the battle-system. You don't have the different attack meters anymore, the cards you get need to be activated during the battle and do not give passive bonuses, you should heal after every fight (either with a ability or the fountain which caused me to run back to the fountain all the time). 
Those are my points i didn't like. On The other hand though: The story is still good and funny at times and the little quests too. Plus, you can constantly skate now. Thank god.
I say it again, this game on its own is good but don't expect much after playing the first one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108223735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1420297226}
